LEAD: An investor group that includes Arnhold and S. Bleichroeder Inc., New York, investment bankers, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had reduced its stake in Carson Pirie Scott Inc. to 641,749 shares, or 4.7 percent of the outstanding common stock. The group, which had previously held 5.7 percent, said it sold 139,300 shares of the Chicago retail company in open-market transactions between June 1 and July 18 at $12.50 to $14.50 a share.

LEAD: BAYFIELD PENINSULA is a forest-covered finger of Wisconsin that juts into the awesome, chilly drink of Lake Superior. Its easterly shore helps to shelter and embrace Chequamegon Bay, and clustered around the tip of this digit are the lovely, low-lying Apostle Islands. There are 22 of them, of odd shapes and varying sizes, and they lie hunkering about the peninsula like the bushy pates of a submerged race of giants.

LEAD: LATELY I've done a lot of thinking about ethics in business. This might be because my job is very competitive. I'm in charge of getting new clients for my firm, a medium-sized advertising agency with a reputation for memorable commercials. Trying to win an advertising account in a contest with other agencies has to be one of the most intense forms of business competition.

LEAD: WITH its reputation as a center of manufacturing and finance as well as its proximity to major United States cities, Toronto has emerged as one of Canada's economic bright spots. Last year there was record demand for office space, and as a trade agreeement with the United States nears approval, the business community is geared up for continued economic growth in the 1990's.

LEAD: We experienced the woodchuck invasion last summer and we had a fence. Nothing deterred them. LEAD: Repertorio Espanol is 20 years old this summer, a milestone the company is too busy to observe and one that is unlikely to seize the attention of New York's mainstream theater world. Repertorio, which remains adamantly Castilian in tongue, tone and tune, is one of the more venerable professional repertory groups in the nation, and offers a profusion of plays, dance and musicals that would, in its native land, be at center stage in the cultural scene.

LEAD: Decorative arts of the early Industrial Age - rich in stylistic contrasts, abundant in technological innovation and stunning in materials - fill dozens of galleries and two towers of the Musee d'Orsay. LEAD: THE train skimmed past the freshly mowed hayfields of western Washington in the long shadows and golden light of late afternoon. LEAD: Gail Winnifer Laster and Donald Beaton Verrilli Jr., lawyers and 1979 graduates of Yale University, are planning to be married Aug. 27.

LEAD: To the Editor: Betsy Wade could have added one more caveat. That is, try to travel with friends you already know well. That way you will already know some of their likes, dislikes, prejudices and idiosyncrasies.

LEAD: The most telling sound to come from the confluence of the Ohio, Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers on Friday night was not the succession of roars produced by the big crowd at Three Rivers Stadium. It was a sound that had more to do with the respect the Pittsburgh Pirates have earned than a celebration of what they have achieved.

LEAD: LOOSE CONNECTIONS. By Sybil Claiborne. (Academy Chicago, $16.95.) The connections in Sybil Claiborne's first collection of short stories are loose indeed. Many of the characters have only a tenuous grip on reality; still others inhabit a collapsing world in which a malevolent government, god or military-industrial complex is systematically destroying the populace.

Richard Cockrell. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.

LEAD: THE Casino Pier is one of the major boardwalk attractions here that Kenneth Wynne Jr. and his family built in the last 40 years with quarters and Kewpie dolls, as well as plenty of charm and tenacity.
LEAD: WHEN James E. Carnicelli, a civil engineer, began a part-time business 16 years ago, he said he had his friends to thank for it.

LEAD: COMMUTER rail fares on N. .J. Transit went up again in May, this time between 6 and 20 percent. In the public hearings dealing with its perennial budget gap, N.J. Transit argued yet again that all options necessarily included a major fare increase.

LEAD: During more than four months at trial, the prosecutors of the Wedtech racketeering case have faced a constant, nettlesome problem: how to create a compelling story line out of what one lawyer called ''a monsoon of evidence'' that is by turns either obscure or circumstantial, to convict seven seemingly disparate defendants of conspiracy and extortion.

LEAD: At the end of each inning, John Smoltz would walk slowly back to the Atlanta dugout and, just before stepping down, steal a look into the box seats. There, without fail, he would spot the small knot of family and friends who had traveled halfway across the country to watch his debut in the major leagues.

LEAD: A cost-of-living study has concluded that welfare benefits would have to rise by 30 percent to meet the minimum needs of the 1.3 million welfare recipients in New York State, state officials and welfare advocates said.

LEAD: OUTSIDE, NEW YORK City is sweltering in a heat wave. In an apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, an 11-year-old girl mixes a strawberry daiquiri in a blender, pours a glass for her mother, then sips from her own tall glass of foamy pink fluid.
LEAD: THIS summer, while some youngsters work on their backstrokes and others on building sand castles, a dozen Connecticut youths are making a feature film called ''Fields of Their Youth.''

LEAD: AT THE HEART OF THE WHITE ROSE: Letters and Diaries of Hans and Sophie Scholl. Edited by Inge Jens. Translated by J. Maxwell Brownjohn. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) The anti-Nazi group known as the White Rose consisted of a small circle of students and a teacher at the University of Munich who in May 1942, when Hitler was still triumphant in the war, secretly began to distribute leaflets denouncing the Nazi regime.

LEAD: To the Editor: On my first trip to the Netherlands many years ago, an American friend told me not to miss the ribs at the Bar-Bq Bontje Restaurant, 7 Javastraat, The Hague (telephone 460118). I followed his advice and had the best ribs I had ever tasted. On frequent trips to the Netherlands since then, I have made it a point to return to the Bar-Bq for a feast of their unforgettable ribs.

LEAD: IT could be a proposed home for the mentally retarded or a school for the physically disabled, or it could even be a housing project for low-income senior citizens. Elected officials, at first, respond with a degree of support, and some may even go so far as to express understanding of the need to be addressed by the proposal.
LEAD: LEONARDO DA VINCI Engineer and Architect. Edited by Paolo Galluzzi. Illustrated. 352 pp. Boston: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts/ Northeastern University Press. $65.

LEAD: LAKE travel, the utterly civil and once-popular mode of transportation, probably seems out of pace with America of the late 20th century, gone the way of homemade ice cream and cornet bands and Pullman berths.
LEAD: IT is parade season, and the pipes are calling. From glen to glen, from village to town, the exotic sound of the bagpipe lends a sense of enchantment to familiar streets.

LEAD: All political parties, even in one-party states, have conventions, and the main purpose is the same. It is to gather and energize the faithful, give them the message and send them out to mobilize the masses.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Stowell of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Scott Stowell to Peter Romer Chapman, a son of Mrs. William L. Chapman Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Chapman. The couple plan to marry Aug. 27.

LEAD: The Giants reached terms yesterday with Maurice Carthon, one of the six veterans missing from camp, but they lost a versatile defensive back for the season when Herb Welch suffered ligament damage in his left knee during a training camp drill in Florham Park, N.J.
LEAD: THE SHOOTING GALLERY By Yuko Tsushima. Translated and compiled by Geraldine Harcourt. 138 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Paper, $7.95.

LEAD: Ken Flach and Robert Seguso defeated Christian Miniussi and Javier Frana of Argentina, 6-2, 6-3, 6-4, today to give the United States an insurmountable 3-0 lead and send the Americans into the group of 16 nations that will compete for the Davis Cup next year.

LEAD: ''We're in the danger zone. We are pushing back up to the levels we saw back at the beginning of the decade when we saw more inflation.'' - David Jones, economist with Aubrey G. Lanston, on the industrial capacity data released last week.

LEAD: Ever since the discovery of medical waste on New York and New Jersey beaches and in New England, officials of state health and environmental conservation departments have been getting calls from anglers asking if fish caught in the region's waters are dangerous to eat. The answer is no, or, to be more precise, no more so than before the dumping took place.

LEAD: Under the title ''The Big Squeeze,'' the Serious Fun festival at Alice Tully Hall assembled a diverse passel of accordionists Friday night. The accordion has its ins and outs, and this concert had its ups and downs. The idea was sweet, and with better editing and technical support it might have been outstanding.

LEAD: The marriage of Lynn Marie Carroll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Carroll of Spring Lake, N.J., to John Chauncy Williams 3d, a son of Carroll G. Williams of Middleburg, Va., and Mr. Williams Jr. of Warrenton, Va., took place yesterday at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake.

LEAD: The 1876 ''Portrait of Madame Charpentier and Her Children'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is one of Renoir's most familiar paintings. Its Japanese setting is the Parisian town house of Georges and Marguerite Charpentier, patrons of Renoir and influential supporters of the arts. Mme. Charpentier is sitting on a sofa, her feathery right arm soft and protective, her dark dress settling on the floor like a huge wing.

LEAD: A listing on May 29 with an article about Florence misstated some telephone numbers and a closing day. The numbers are, for Harry's Bar, 296700; the Sabatini restaurant, 282802 and the Excelsior Italia Hotel, 264201. Harry's Bar is closed Sunday.

LEAD: Paradise is a portly angel, completely and vibrantly red, moving against the total whiteness of a celestial garden populated by white bears, herons and monkeys. This image, so striking that it is still being discussed by those who saw it in New York, was created by Robert Wilson and closed his recent and visionary staging of ''Le Martyre de Saint Sebastien.
LEAD: In ''Santa Fe,'' an Austrian Jew who has found refuge in New York during World War II says wearily about his former countrymen, ''They'll never forgive us for what they did to us.''

LEAD: It is no secret among those who live at Battery Park City, the much-acclaimed complex of condominiums, office towers and commercial space in lower Manhattan, that the quality of the apartments themselves is less than stellar. Indeed, except for the spectacular views some of the units have, there is little to distinguish the interiors of most Battery Park City apartments from the insides of the ordinary, developer-built boxes of Second Avenue.
LEAD: A $500 million mixed-use project proposed by the Glick Organization for the Upper East Side has passed its first regulatory hurdle and is scheduled for a public hearing in September.

LEAD: A few weeks ago, the composer Andrzej Panufnik conducted a program of his music at the 92d Street Y, courtesy of the First New York International Festival of the Arts. It was an excellent concert, with Mr. Panufnik's outwardly conservative, accessible yet still searching and original music expertly rendered by the New York Chamber Symphony.

LEAD: Forty-four people were injured yesterday when a tour bus traveling to Atlantic City ran off the Garden State Parkway near Bass River, N.J., and struck some trees. The driver was arrested and charged with possession of drug paraphernalia and driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, the New Jersey state police said.

LEAD: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article reminded me of a technique I've used with groups even as small as two. Each of the possible companions prepares for the others two short lists: Things I Can't Do Without and Things I Can't Stand. If one party refuses to miss the glories of sunrise and another can't bear to get up before 10, best to know it early on.
LEAD: Hetty Fox says she believes a father is like half the universe. If that is true, then she must be the other half for more than 70 children on Lyman Place, a block in the South Bronx.

LEAD: COSMETICS companies have long invested heavily in developing products that promise to moisturize, preserve and otherwise enhance the beauty of your skin. But until only about a decade ago, the industry largely avoided the sun-care market. Now, analysts say, sun-care products represent about 10 to 15 percent of sales for major cosmetics companies, at least twice the level of five years ago.

LEAD: Q. When we decided to close our house for the winter while we were away, we got conflicting advice. One school of thought recommended leaving the heat on at a low setting because otherwise the woodwork, furniture and even the latex paint could be damaged by cold and dampness inside the house. The other school of thought said that dmage, if any, would be negligible, and the worst would be offset by the savings in fuel bills.

LEAD: AS a young Chinese man sat on a sunny deck and described his plan to continue his father's effort to form a theater troupe of deaf performers in China, a dozen American actors - most of them deaf - climbed and swung over a section of metal scaffolding in a shady yard nearby, exercising before a rehearsal.

LEAD: BIFURCATED POLITICS: Evolution and Reform in the National Party Convention. By Byron E. Shafer. (Russell Sage Foundation/Harvard University, $27.50.) This is a profound study of the transformation of national party conventions from meetings where Presidential candidates were actually selected (that last happened in 1952) to political theme parks where all kinds of causes, including the Presidential election, compete for a hearing.

LEAD: The Blanchard-Harrison band, which played at Mikell's Thursday night, has had the luxury of major record-company support, allowing it to perform regularly. The results show: they're now one of the best young bands playing jazz today.
LEAD: The tiny box turtle, barely two inches long, was cleverly hidden deep among the dried leaves in the Massachusetts Audubon Society's Wellfleet Bay Wildlife Sanctuary.

LEAD: GROOM petunias, geraniums, snapdragons and salvias by cutting off or snapping off old flowers to prevent seed pods and prolong bloom; if there is time, remove faded roses and day lilies. Sow ripe columbine seed promptly where it is to grow. Prune hedges to keep them in line, especially if they block street and drive views or hinder foot traffic.

LEAD: To the Editor: The articles about the debate over barbecue (Travel, July 3) certainly hit home - in fact, two homes. My North Carolinian husband, after a dozen years in New Jersey, still refuses to call a cookout a barbecue. It is certainly true that we Jerseyans call the act of cooking any meat on a grill, with or without sauce, a barbecue.

Yanni of Briarcliff Manor. Ms. Campbell, a daughter also of the late Joseph P. Campbell, is a media planner at McCann-Erickson Advertising in New York.

The announcement was expected to ease tensions between Italy and Nigeria and lead to the release of the Italian freighter Piave, which was seized by Nigeria pending a resolution of the waste issue.

LEAD: A new miniseries from Atlanta, called ''Unity Village: The 1988 Democratic National Convention,'' took up four days of prime time last week on CNN and all the major networks. Until Jesse Jackson, playing the part of a spell-binding Baptist preacher, electrified the audience with a 50-minute monologue, only 32 percent of television sets were tuned in.

LEAD: Just three weeks after officials at the University of Illinois said that a former assistant athletic director, John Koenig, had received $11,000 in unauthorized reimbursements, similar overpayments led Koenig to resign his post as athletic director at the University of New Mexico.
LEAD: New Yorkers are adjusting to the city's new anti-smoking law with little argument or incident because it follows a profound social change that has transformed the way people live and work.

LEAD: BASEMENT leaks are cured most effectively by making repairs on the exterior side of the foundation walls. Unfortunately, this is usually a major undertaking, not because of the patching procedure (which in most cases is simple), but because of excavation to expose the areas requiring treatment.
LEAD: REAL MAN TELLS ALL Confessions of an Eligible Bachelor. By Peter Nelson. 168 pp. New York: Penguin. Paper, $6.95.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Zola P. Horovitz of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bonna Lynn Horovitz to Joel S. Finkelstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Finkelstein of Newburgh, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: A couple of decades ago there was a great deal of talk about the domino theory. Under the circumstances of the time, the theory went that if Vietnam fell to the Communists, the rest of Southeast Asia would collapse, country by country, in rapid succession. The double-six in this particular set of dominos was Australia.
LEAD: The imprisoned black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela today accepted an offer from the South African Government and received a visit from his wife and family.
LEAD: LIBRA By Don DeLillo. 456 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

LEAD: EVEN though more than nine months have elapsed since Black Monday, many financial planners are still wary about recommending that clients re-enter the stock market. Conservatism is the byword of the day, as planners continue to urge clients to put a hefty portion of their savings into fixed-income investments ranging from certificates of deposit to bond funds.
LEAD: ONE day in a Baton Rouge, La., high school, David Biele had to contend with a common assignment in freshman-composition classes: putting his thoughts, whatever they were, freely on paper.

LEAD: Laura Herbst [ ''Farmers Adapt to Keep Their Land,'' June 12 ] has shown quite clearly the things farmers have been up against on the East End of Long Island and how they are coping, but a very important factor was not emphasized. That is Suffolk County's program of buying the development rights of agricultural land.

LEAD: The engagement of Sarah Louise Patterson to Robert Rafael Beltran, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Rafael Beltran of Riverdale, the Bronx, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Patterson Jr. of Darien, Conn. Ms. Patterson, who graduated from Williams College, is a television producer at Young & Rubicam in New York, where her fiance, a graduate of Columbia College, is an account executive.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: FOR Karl D. Bays, figuring out what he wanted to do with his life was never much of a problem. There was really just one career that interested him. ''All I ever wanted to be was a manager,'' said Mr. Bays, a husky, cigar-smoking Kentuckian.

LEAD: EVERY morning, when Denise Pfister walks three blocks from her home on Breton Harbors Drive to the community tap, carrying three one-gallon plastic milk containers, she is reminded of just how furious she is at some of her neighbors.
LEAD: A RECENT newspaper article warned of a pending national crisis that could jeopardize our economy and change our life styles: gridlock at airports.

LEAD: AFTER the critical drubbing and commercial defeat suffered by the recent musical ''Beetle Bailey,'' Candlewood Playhouse audiences are ready for the reassurance of a proven hit, and in ''La Cage aux Folles,'' they have just the one: a guaranteed good time.
LEAD: Selling Co-op Rights
LEAD: AN OLD-TIME COWBOY AND his hat seldom parted company.

LEAD: In the Connecticut Q&A, which appeared on May 22, Leo V. Donohue, the Democratic State Auditor, discussed the budget process and annual versus biennial budgets. Both he and the Republican State Auditor Henry J. Becker have been recommending a return to biennial budgets for over 10 years and the rationale put forth appears to have merit.

LEAD: Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. $391,000 10 Warren Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old contemporary; family room, deck, 2-car garage, cul-de-sac, 2.9 acres; taxes $6,333. New Rochelle, N.Y. $350,000 71 Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, dining room, finished basement; taxes $3,191.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Raphael P. Nenner of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter Lisa Marilyn Nenner to Dr. Arnold Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Goldman of New York. The wedding is planned for November.
LEAD: AS beauty experts and dermatologists extol the virtues of pallor, a large number of the nation's sunbathers are sending a different message: The popularity of tanning will never fade.

LEAD: A series of seemingly contradictory forecasts and drastically revised estimates of the AIDS crisis in New York City has bewildered and upset even some experts. All sides agree that AIDS will continue to inflict a rising toll of suffering and death for at least the next several years, but there is less agreement as to the potential extent of the problem - and a continuing dispute over the methodology that should be used in estimating it.

LEAD: TOO busy to pack sun lotion? You could wear a pliable plastic bracelet that snaps open to dispense an ounce of waterproof suntan oil. Called Handy Tan - and available in four colors at some convenience stores and health food outlets - the item can be strapped onto the wrist or ankle or worn in the hair.
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding barbecue, I was surprised that you left out fine barbecue in your own backyard: Stick to Your Ribs in Bridgeport, Conn.

LEAD: Even had they wanted to, the members of the Preservation Hall Jazz Band probably couldn't have done anything at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night to shake off the stereotypes of age, entertainment, race and geography that make New Orleans jazz seem such a cliche today.

LEAD: Name the greatest prodigy in the history of music. Mozart? Mendelssohn? Korngold? Wrong. He was Charles Camille Saint-Saens, who was composing at the age of 3 1/2. If you find this hard to believe, go to the Conservatoire in Paris where the manuscript is on display. The child was playing the standard repertory with mature violinists before he was 7.

LEAD: Saul Bellow, Toni Morrison, Paul Bowles - hardly your average television personalities. But they are popping up on some home screens this month. Of course, they are not available on either commercial or public television. They happen to be part of a series of ''Profiles'' being offered Thursdays (with repeats Sundays) on the pay cable Bravo service.

LEAD: Partly it is the setting that gives the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago a distinctly festive air. Unique among American cities - and comparable to the famed waterside esplanades of Geneva and Montreux - Chicago has developed much of its lakefront as a vast park dotted with beaches, fountains and statuary.
LEAD: Recently you printed some most interesting letters about the social problem of educating the handicapped.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Jessica Anne Spohn and Clifford Scott Kayhart were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by Judge Richard B. Lowe 3d of New York City Criminal Court.
LEAD: INFINITE IN ALL DIRECTIONS By Freeman J. Dyson. 321 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $19.95.

LEAD: THE ELIZABETH STORIES, by Isabel Huggan. (King Penguin, $6.95.) Elizabeth is forced to play the only male role in a ballet recital and discovers that her father really wanted her to be a boy. Last year, our reviewer, Ellen Currie, said that in these stories about a Canadian girl's troubled adolescence ''Isabel Huggan is superb at establishing that helpless awareness of capture and duress that is the character of our experience when we are young and have no power because we have no information.
LEAD: WILL the price of oil rise in the next few months or fall? Probably both, sharply, and several times, if the recent past is any guide.
LEAD: WHERE do the memories go? I try to tidy up, but how do you prune away the past?

LEAD: As law-enforcement officials continued to assert that Glenda Brawley would be arrested when she returned to New York State, her advisers said yesterday that Mrs. Brawley was ''somewhere south of Canada'' and would come back within two weeks in a ''challenge'' to the authorities.

LEAD: For a brief moment, it looked as if Steven Rooks would be the man in the yellow jersey, the overall leader of the Tour de France. But his lead was short-lived, and as a question of a fellow rider's drug use was resolved this week, it became clear that Rooks could finish no better than second when the three-week bicycle race ended in Paris Sunday.

LEAD: Q. When we decided to close our house for the winter while we were away, we got conflicting advice. One school of thought recommended leaving the heat on at a low setting because otherwise the woodwork, furniture and even the latex paint could be damaged by cold and dampness inside the house. The other school of thought said that dmage, if any, would be negligible, and the worst would be offset by the savings in fuel bills.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: NEXT month, Audi of America will introduce the Audi 100 and 200, two new models whose success or failure will reach far beyond industry sales charts. If the cars are a hit, the beleaguered luxury division of Volkswagen of America may be able to restore its image as a producer of refined luxury-performance cars.

LEAD: In his 26 years of unchallenged rule in Burma, U Ne Win, whose name means ''Brilliant as the Sun,'' has preserved the facade of Burmese independence while turning a country with extraordinary economic potential into one of the poorest nations in Asia.
LEAD: THE ANTIPEOPLE By Sony Labou Tansi. Translated by J. A. Underwood. 170 pp. New York: Marion Boyars/Kampmann & Company. $18.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Anne Frances Ackerley, an associate in investment banking at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, and David Lawrence Lewis, a staff writer in Yonkers for Gannett Westchester Newspapers, plan to marry Aug. 28.

LEAD: The residents of Seoul don't just walk the streets. They attack them, barreling along with elbows and chins out, almost defying anyone to get in the way. There is nothing hostile in this. Restraint is simply not a conspicuous element in the city's character.

LEAD: For 20 years, Basil Pascali has meticulously recorded his observations of the mundane activities on a sun-drenched Aegean island and sent them to the Sultan in Constantinople. But as World War I approaches and the end of Turkish rule on the Greek island looms, this man of inaction is tortured by questions.

LEAD: For many years, the symbol of suburban life has been that oasis of privacy and refuge from urban crowding, the single-family home. But in the New York City suburbs, more and more of these snug houses harbor more than one family, almost always illegally.
LEAD: THE PLAYER By Michael Tolkin. 193 pp. New York: A Morgan Entrekin Book/ The Atlantic Monthly Press.

LEAD: AS a person who has always acquired and stockpiled junk with alarming regularity, periodically I am forced, due to lack of space, to find ways to alleviate the pressure building up in my closets, drawers, bookshelves, attic and garage.

LEAD: JUST as the New Jersey Democratic Party chairman, Raymond M. Durkin, was about to speak on party unity Monday morning to his state's delegates at the Democratic National Convention, loud cries came from the back of the room.

One school of thought recommended leaving the heat on at a low setting because otherwise the woodwork, furniture and even the latex paint could be damaged by cold and dampness inside the house. The other school of thought said that dmage, if any, would be negligible, and the worst would be offset by the savings in fuel bills.

Republic Pictures Home Video. 124 minutes. $79.95 separately; $139.90 when purchased as a package with ''Tampopo.'' In Japanese, with English subtitles.

LEAD: Perhaps the only consolation that the Colombian drug kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas could find at his sentencing in Florida last week was that the judge did not quite throw the book at him. Prosecutors had asked Federal District Judge Howell W. Melton to sentence Mr. Lehder to life in prison without parole, plus 150 years, following his May conviction for smuggling 3.3 tons of cocaine into the country.
LEAD: FROM HERE IN THE Irish Republic,'' wrote Francis X. Clines in The New York Times, ''Northern Ireland can sometimes seem a place more of relentless torpor than Yeatsian gyre.''

LEAD: RUTGERS-NEW BRUNSWICK is in the throes of its 1988 Summerfest, which means that at the university's arts center, on George Street at Route 18, there are concerts most days through the month of July and an occasional theatrical performance by students. Though music has the upper hand, the visual arts are not neglected, for in the Walters Hall Gallery is ''Art After Silence,'' a show organized by Francis Morelli of the university's Mason Gross
LEAD: WHAT is a stamp worth?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Polaroid is in play. After months of speculation that the photography company was a takeover target, Roy Disney announced that his Shamrock Holdings held 8 percent of Polaroid's stock and was willing to buy the rest for $2.3 billion, or $40 a share. Polaroid had been selling for about $30 a share in February before the first takeover rumors began.

LEAD: Most of the people of the vast desert state of Sonora have always regarded the Mexican Government's war against the drug trade as something that has little to do with them and their daily lives. But not any more, not after what happened here just after dawn one spring morning.

LEAD: HOLIDAY WATERCOLORS The New Britain Youth Museum has added a series of art exhibits to its schedule, beginning with a display of Tasha Tudor's original illustrations for ''A Time to Keep,'' for which she also wrote the text. Her watercolors depict the holiday celebrations of a single New England family during one year.

LEAD: The Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Campbell Williamson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Geiger Williamson of Short Hills, to Thomas Alan Holman, a son of Sandow Holman of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Vivian Barnett Holman. The Rev.
LEAD: Color commentator. BOB HOFFMAN Larchmont, N.Y.

LEAD: THE Department of Transportation cannot guess how many unaccompanied children are traveling by air on United States airlines these days. But as a general indication, two years ago United Airlines said it carried 500,000 over the summer. Piedmont said it carried 212,293 last year and expected 230,000 this year.
LEAD: JOHN McGRAW By Charles C. Alexander. Illustrated. 358 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.
LEAD: AT the Ensemble Company for the Performing Arts, which sponsors the Summer Cabaret at Yale University in New Haven, the administrators take pride in taking risks.
LEAD: Michael Dukakis's speech accepting the Democratic nomination Thursday conveyed no strong organizing theme - yet the whole convention did and it was a startling theme indeed: children.

LEAD: LIKE the monster in Mary Shelley's novel ''Frankenstein,'' automation can sometimes run amok. We're left behind, watching helplessly as the motorized innards of our cameras take on wills of their own.

LEAD: YOU MIGHT SEE IT AS EITHER A dark day or the coming of the light; night baseball is dawning at Wrigley Field. On Aug. 8, at 7:05 P.M. C.D.T., when the Chicago Cubs take to their venerable home diamond to face the Philadelphia Phillies, baseball's most famous anachronism will be history. Night games at Wrigley, which was built in 1914 (the Cubs moved in two years later), were made possible last February when a City Council vote cleared the way for the installation of lights.

LEAD: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass., Rebecca Gilman White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. White Jr. of Manchester, Mass., was married yesterday to Christopher Wood Dilworth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warden Dilworth of Groton, Mass. The Rev. James Hughes Purdy performed the ceremony.

LEAD: IT is a forest island, rising like a green castle from the blue lake, its beaches the color of sunshine. The evergreen woods, sand dunes, inland lakes and wetlands are rich in small wildflowers and fruit - buttercups and blackberries, pink bean peas and waterlilies, tiny woodland orchids, blueberries, primroses, strawberries and creeping snowberries, jewel weed and yarrow.

LEAD: SINCE the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the United States Postal Service, with more than 800,000 employees and $33 billion in annual sales, has been the largest business enterprise in America. The framers of the Constitution realized that few freedoms are as fundamental to democracy as guaranteeing the universal exchange of information and ideas through the mail service.

Set in New Orleans around the time of the French Revolution, it has everything M-G-M's moguls wanted in a musical: a lightly baked plot, generous doses of romance and idealism (offset by both swashbuckling and comedy) and a frothy, lyrical score packed with hit tunes (''Stouthearted Men,'' ''Lover, Come Back to Me'' and ''One
LEAD: It will come as no surprise to those who have followed his career, but according to one medical specialist, William Perry suffers from an eating disorder.

LEAD: To hear David Zinman tell it, turning 50 a couple of years ago wasn't all that bad. For one thing, it gave him the courage of some still-unorthodox Beethovenian convictions - like observing the composer's metronome markings, phrasing in a style closer to Mozart than to Mahler, even adding Baroque-style ornaments in the earlier symphonies.

LEAD: FROM Sue Gleason's view from the docks at Smitty's Marina here in Woodport on a recent sultry afternoon, Lake Hopatcong, New Jersey's largest lake, resembled a silent and ominous mural. Ms. Gleason, a Woodport native and co-manager of Smitty's Marina Restaurant, said that as a result of the lake's low water level - two feet below normal - many boat owners had hauled their boats to shore.

LEAD: In a parting toast at a banquet in Beijing, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China told Secretary of State George P. Shultz that ''the door of China is forever open to you.'' President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines said goodbye by lauding him as ''our true and trusted friend, a friend to me and our people.
LEAD: THE 80's is the decade of medical show and tell. I'm sick of it.

LEAD: After years of resisting the idea of joining the European Community, neutral Austria is seriously considering full membership as the organization's 12 members move toward the goal of a single market by 1992, according to Austrian officials and politicians.

LEAD: IT'S the last week of school and I want to give my 11th- and 12th-grade students something, something that isn't a reading assignment, essay or vocabulary test. I'd like to hand out a rosary bead of truth that they can touch in future bad times for wisdom and comfort. But what would be appropriate?

LEAD: Q. When we decided to close our house for the winter while we were away, we got conflicting advice. One school of thought recommended leaving the heat on at a low setting because otherwise the woodwork, furniture and even the latex paint could be damaged by cold and dampness inside the house. The other school of thought said that dmage, if any, would be negligible, and the worst would be offset by the savings in fuel bills.

LEAD: Karen Berger of New York and Quogue, L.I., and William H. Berman of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Staci M. Berman to John Robert Barber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Barber of New York. The couple plan to marry Sept. 10.

LEAD: A chart on third world missile deployment in The Week in Review on July 3 was incorrectly labeled. The headline should have said that the chart listed only ''nuclear capable'' missiles (defined as those with a range of greater than 190 miles and a payload of greater than 1,100 pounds), and the footnote should have said that countries listed with question marks were reported to be seeking the missiles indicated, not that they already had them.

LEAD: IT IS WELL WITHIN THE REACH of most white-collar criminals to assume an air of irreproachable virtue, especially when they're about to be sentenced. But there was something unusually compelling about the bearing of Niels L. Hoyvald and John F. Lavery as they stood before Judge Thomas C. Platt of the United States District Court in Brooklyn last month - especially in light of what they were being sentenced for.

LEAD: After months of controversy, the Federal Government is beginning human trials of a potential AIDS drug, dextran sulfate, which is already being used by thousands of desperate patients who purchased it abroad or from covert suppliers.
LEAD: Both China and the Soviet Union have given assurances that they are willing to help resolve the war in Cambodia, the Indonesian Foreign Minister said today.

LEAD: Dr. Norma Foreman Glasgow, the State Commissioner of Higher Education, has called attention to a problem which has begun to worry employers and government and community leaders - the migration of Connecticut college-bound youth. [ For College Students, the Grass May Be Greener at Home, June19 ] Statewide the figure is 53 percent; however, Fairfield County loses over 60 percent of its students to outofstate institutions of higher learning.

LEAD: By almost any standard, it was a remarkable statement. In the equivalent of a fireside chat except that it was read for him by a radio announcer, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in effect told the Iranian nation last week that it had lost the war with Iraq and must now turn its attention to salvaging what is left of the decade-old revolution he brought about.
LEAD: Because of Paul Kerzner, 7,000 more trees are cooling the streets of western Queens in the humid summer, brightening them in the autumn, and diminishing air pollution year-round.

LEAD: A team of United Nations experts is scheduled to arrive in Teheran today to begin an investigation into the plight of tens of thousands of prisoners from the Iran-Iraq war and to look into the possibility of prisoner exchanges, United Nations officials said yesterday.

LEAD: In the last decade, rap has become as much a symbol as a musical style. For those who revel in it as well as for those who can't stand it, rap holds all the tensions of urban life - tensions between sexes, generations, races and classes. Its electronic crunch and sonic collages, its jolts and shouts, echo an urban streetscape that some city dwellers want to flaunt or exorcise, others to escape.

LEAD: Dark Eyes Starring Marcello Mastroianni, Silvana Mangano, Marthe Keller, Elena Sofonova, Pina Cei. Directed by Nikita Mikhalkov. 1987. CBS/Fox Video. 116 minutes. $89.98. In Italian, with English subtitles. Not rated.
LEAD: Ever since their revolution in 1974, the Portuguese have been trying to undo their complicated, leftist-oriented Constitution.

LEAD: Last week, the Federal Communications Commission said it would take another look at whether telephone companies should be allowed to enter the cable television business. For that to happen, Congress would have to repeal laws that prohibit ''cross-ownership.'' Also, Judge Harold Greene, who has presided over the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, would have to lift his prohibition against former Bell operating companies participating in information service businesses.

LEAD: ''SIDE BY SIDE BY SONDHEIM'' is a collage of music and lyrics by the American musical theater master Stephen Sondheim. Devised by the English actor-director Ned Sherrin, it had its premiere in London in 1976 and transferred to Broadway the following year. Now, this celebration of the work of Stephen Sondheim is the highlight of the Arena Players Repertory
LEAD: GOING FOR BAROQUE

LEAD: A night of Duke Ellington's music at the ''Jazz in July'' festival at the 92d Street Y on Thursday evening balanced polished treatments of familiar Ellington tunes with an assortment of fascinating, rarely heard Ellingtonia, highlighted by the emergence of two stellar performers.

LEAD: Emerson Fittipaldi, a 41-year-old Brazilian driver, captured the pole position today in qualifying trials at the Meadowlands and will start in the No. 1 position Sunday in the $700,000 Marlboro Grand Prix auto race.

LEAD: >GLITZ has overtaken tradition as the decor of choice in the lobbies of Manhattan's new higher-income residential buildings. Entrances are awash in the riches of the material world, with majestic works of art, modern statuary and glistening fountains set off by decorations faced with marble and detailed with gold leaf.

LEAD: Julianne Helen Dow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orrin B. Dow of White Plains, and Francis Oliver Lynn, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis Lynn of Philadelphia, were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at Friends Meeting in Bloomington, Ind.

LEAD: In a move to ease summer congestion, the Italian Transport Ministry has opened five former military air spaces to commercial flights, allowing more air traffic from northern Europe. It has also limited the number of flights at Linate International Airport in Milan to 32 an hour, giving preference to commercial flights and moving charter and private flights to Malpensa Airport and Orio al Serio Bergamo

LEAD: Rain and cooler temperatures blessed the Middle West and South last week, giving hundreds of thousands of farmers hope that their withered crops might recover from the worst drought in half a century. But the moisture did nothing to deter members of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees, who are eager to approve a drought relief bill this week that would be the most generous farm disaster legislation ever considered.
LEAD: The revival of a lawsuit over whether a patient retains rights to his blood and tissue has rekindled fears among scientists that legal constraints could hamper medical research.

LEAD: In the small Eastern Cape town of Grahamstown, Constable David Patrick Goosen of the South African police was sentenced in May to death for the murder of a black teen-ager, whom he killed while on duty in July 1986. A month or so earlier on Durban's Golden Mile, the country's most popular beach strip, a university dropout named Robert M
LEAD: Tim Leary finally believes in himself, and he's making believers of the rest of the National League as well.

LEAD: The marriage of Linda Caren Seale, a daughter of L. Jason Seale of Harvey Cedars, N.J., and the late Esther S. Seale, to Jerome I. Baron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Baron of Deerfield Park, Fla., took place last evening at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan. Jean S. Kotkin, a senior leader of the American Ethical Union, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: IT was early spring in the Scottish Border country. Tulips and daffodils were showing their colors, hill shepherds were at the tag end of their lambing and the fields were dotted with wee white bouncing things, baaing and bleating after Mom.

LEAD: WITH its reputation as a center of manufacturing and finance as well as its proximity to major United States cities, Toronto has emerged as one of Canada's economic bright spots. Last year there was record demand for office space, and as a trade agreeement with the United States nears approval, the business community is geared up for continued economic growth in the 1990's.
LEAD: MANHATTAN clones in the Hamptons are commonplace. The frame storefront on Main Street in Bridgehampton that housed the Stage Deli last year is now the home of Mel's Restaurant and Bar.

LEAD: Farm-to-town-house conversions along the Hudson River in upstate New York have become as common as factory-to-loft conversions along Hudson Street in Soho. Most recently, Otto and Henry Frank decided it was time to retire and sell the Frank Brothers Farm just east of downtown Poughkeepsie on Route 44.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about management of the Federal malaria vaccine research program misidentified the professional society that coordinates the research for the Agency for International Development. It is the American Institute of Biological Sciences.

LEAD: IT is one of the great family dynasties in corporate America. McGraw-Hill Inc., the publishing giant founded in 1909, has had a McGraw at the helm through two world wars, the Depression and into the electronic era.

LEAD: At 8:30 P.M. on May 5, a guard came to the cell of Pablo Prieto Castillo at the Combinado del Este jail outside Havana and took him to the administration compound where he was given new clothes and led outside to a small, windowless van.

LEAD: Thoughts of the actor Jackie Mason on the three greatest challenges of his starring role in ''Caddyshack II,'' the film that had its premiere Friday:

LEAD: BASEBALL caps, as beloved as the game itself, are still fashion champs. While the sun-shading design has remained unchanged over the years, fabrics have gone from wool to cotton to nylon, and logos have reached out from the major leagues to include fishing clubs, school bands and postal workers.

LEAD: Victoria English, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore English of Grafton, Mass., was married in London yesterday to William David Turner Ellington 3d, a son of Mrs. James G. Downward of Hilton Head Island, S.C., and the late Jesse T. Ellington. The Rev. David Usher performed the ceremony at the Rosslyn Hill Unitarian
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An attendant at a Harlem Hospital parking lot was shot in the face and killed early yesterday morning, and another attendant critically wounded, when they stopped a car that had been stolen from the lot several hours earlier, the police said.
LEAD: ''You'll never hear that 'L' word - liberal - from them.
LEAD: ''It's reached a point in this country where Rosa Parks is a heroine to everyone.''

LEAD: Caroline Kent Erisman and John J. Silberstein, who are lawyers, are planning to marry Sept. 10. The parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Otis William Erisman of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced the engagement.

LEAD: In an age of atomic bombs and intercontinental ballistic missiles, old-fashioned cannon still pour out of the Watervliet Arsenal, which this month is celebrating its 175th anniversary of producing arms for the United States Army.

LEAD: The National Ballet of Canada gave a polished account of John Cranko's ''Onegin'' on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The dancing was smooth and clear, and the performance revealed that this is a very carefully trained company. But it also revealed how great an artistic distance there can be between studio and stage, for despite their technical competence, several leading dancers failed to be dramatically convincing.

LEAD: Daniel Patrick Moynihan's article ''Debunking the Myth of Decline'' (June 19), reminds us, usefully, that the Federal budget and trade-balance deficits are, in large measure, the consequences of bad policy, which can be corrected.

LEAD: Because of a transcription error, a quotation in a review of Gerald Clarke's biography ''Capote'' June 12 was incorrect. The passage, from Harper Lee's novel ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' describes a character whose ''hair was snow white and stuck to his head like duck fluff.''

LEAD: ANY GRANDFATHER might be pleased to be invited to join his son's family on a sailing expedition. Any 62-year-old man contemplating mortality and Social Security might leap at the chance for a late-life adventure - three weeks on a 38-foot boat, crossing the Pacific Ocean from Hawaii to Tahiti.
LEAD: THE CRYPTO-AMNESIA CLUB By Michael Bracewell. 111 pp. New York: Serpent's Tail/Carcanet. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: Michael Pollan's article ''Gardening Means War'' (June 19) was a direct hit. I sat reading it, and laughed until I nearly cried, while, outside, a mother woodchuck was training her three youngsters in guerrilla tactics in my garden. We have put the garden in a new spot this year. Last year, after we jammed boulders into the gaping holes surrounding our vegetable patch, the resident woodchuck set up new underground quarters - with its main entrance in the middle of the snap beans.

LEAD: The Democrats emerged from their national convention this week united in support of their ticket and upbeat in their assessment that the gathering in Atlanta improved Michael S. Dukakis's chances in November.

LEAD: When her husband left last year, Mattie E. Johnson found she could not single-handedly support her four children. Bills went unpaid and before long, the family was evicted for failing to meet the rent.

LEAD: The head of the Food and Drug Administration told an AIDS conference in Boston today that the agency would allow Americans to import unapproved drugs from abroad in small quantities for their personal use.
LEAD: LADY BIRD JOHNSON AND THE ENVIRONMENT By Lewis L. Gould. Illustrated. 312 pp. Lawrence: University Press of Kansas. $29.95.

LEAD: Continuing to be unintimidated by the pressures of leading the world's most prestigious women's golf championship, Liselotte Neumann of Sweden today equaled the 54-hole record score to take a two-stroke lead into Sunday's final round of the 43d United States Women's Open.
LEAD: Iran said Iraqi troops backed by tanks, warplanes and chemical weapons pushed nearly 40 miles across the border today, and it called on all able-bodied fighters to rush to the front.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis struck a richly patriotic chord today before a cheering, flag-waving crowd in this central California city as he continued a cross-country swing to assert his claim to the votes of Reagan Democrats.

LEAD: A BENT-OVER man with gray hair is mopping the once-elegant lobby floor as if he were sowing seeds of ammonia. The fumes rise to our eyes as we walk by him. My Aunt Bertie has lived in this place for 50 years. At one time, the elite of Brooklyn would announce the name of this building with a sense of aristocratic snobbery, as if they were giving a Park

LEAD: The Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist John Hersey last week ended a literary brouhaha he helped create. He did that by publicly apologizing for liberally using, without attribution, another writer's material in a magazine article he had written. Mr. Hersey's article, an essay about the critic and writer James Agee, appeared recently in The New Yorker, and borrowed heavily from Laurence Bergreen's biography of Mr.

LEAD: ''YOU can drive yourself crazy reading through all these annual reports unless you learn a few tricks,'' one of my first bosses cautioned. ''The first thing I do is glance at the accountant's message at the back. If it's one or two paragraphs long, everything is on the up and up. If it goes to three paragraphs there may be some hanky-panky going on, so then you turn to the president's picture to see if he's smiling.

LEAD: ALREADY the most densely populated state with 7.6 million people living in its 8,204 square miles, New Jersey is facing increasing pressures from haphazard growth as it nears the end of the century.

LEAD: The year was 1905. Willa Cather had just finished an unflattering depiction of a woman with a disfiguring scar on her face, a character based on Evelyn Osbourne, an acquaintance. Seeking comment, Miss Cather had sent to the story to Dorothy Canfield Fisher, her colleague and confidante. Mrs. Fisher was horrified.

LEAD: This year's college graduates received higher salary offers than last year's graduates, especially in business fields, but the number of offers declined slightly, according to a survey made public today.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Orders for machine tools rose 17.8 percent in June. The amount of total orders, $382.5 million, was up 88.6 percent from a year earlier. Experts said the increase reflected strong capital spending as businesses gained confidence in the economy. [ Page D1. ] Trucking companies are struggling to recruit drivers.

LEAD: The Washington Square Music Festival will offer a salute to Norway in its free chamber-orchestra concert tomorrow at 8 P.M. The concertmaster of the Royal Norwegian Opera Orchestra, Ole Bohn, will be the soloist for Niels Wilhelm Gade's Violin Concerto in D minor, under the direction of Henry Schuman.

LEAD: The residents of a decayed South Bronx apartment building have settled in for a siege. Manning fire escapes and courtrooms, they are waging war with the owner of the building, who has declared them squatters and is fighting to evict them.

LEAD: We have been treated recently to a rash of stories about how Julie Christie is making a television movie. The implication is that television should be grateful for snaring a film star of such established magnitude. Perhaps, but don't hold your breath. As it happens, Miss Christie can be seen on Showtime, the pay-cable service, in a German mini-series made in 1986 for television.

LEAD: Golf

LEAD: Interest rates are likely to continue their lazy upward drift, pushed higher by continued worries about inflation and an economy that shows little tendency to cool off, according to credit market analysts.

LEAD: This article is based on reporting by Ralph Blumenthal, Philip S. Gutis and Sam Howe Verhovek and was written by Mr. Blumenthal.

LEAD: Governor Dukakis talked a lot about ''unity'' and ''issues'' at the Democratic convention, but this campaign promises to be about as intellectual as a prize fight. Dukakis praised President Reagan's nuclear reduction policy, but was not so gentle on Vice President Bush. And Dukakis clearly is going to make a personal issue between his own shirtsleeves background and the silver foot in

LEAD: Lost Code, the leading handicap horse in the East, will undergo surgery Monday to remove a bone chip from his left knee and will be sidelined for at least two months, his trainer, Bill Donovan, said today.

LEAD: When he chose Senator Lloyd Bentsen as his running mate, Michael S. Dukakis did more than guarantee that this state, with its 29 electoral votes, would be one of the prime battlegrounds in the Presidential election.

LEAD: Many of them are experienced and familiar. The United States Olympic track and field team is in good hands with reliables like Carl Lewis and Edwin Moses, Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Evelyn Ashford, Willie Banks and Henry Marsh, Valerie Brisco and Francie Larrieu Smith, Steve Scott and Sydney Maree.

LEAD: Few younger pop singers have devoted themselves more assiduously to discovering worthy new material by contemporary songwriters than Marti Jones, a vocalist from Cleveland who has yet to achieve the commercial success that her talents merit. Ms. Jones recently released her third album, ''Used Guitars,'' which includes songs by more than half a dozen talented writers of varied stylistic hue.
LEAD: A bus carrying 47 people from a family reunion struck a bridge abutment this afternoon, injuring 35 people, including a Virginia woman who was reported in critical condition, the police said.
LEAD: Joseph H. Baum thinks the serpent in the Garden of Eden may have been the first restaurant consultant. ''He was suggesting a menu,'' Mr. Baum pointed out.
LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools jumped 17.8 percent in June from the previous month, a report to be released today by the industry's trade association says.

LEAD: The Berkshire Opera is a great idea waiting for its execution to hit stride. Now in its fourth season of trying to add opera to the multitude of artistic diversions available to the affluent vacationers who flock to this region each summer, the company has moved to the auditorium from which the Bible Speaks organization once hoped to build an empire of television evangelism.

LEAD: In response to expressions of dismay and disapproval from many art museum professionals, the trustees of the New-York Historical Society now say they will consider changing the institution's bylaws governing the use of proceeds from the sale of works of art from its collection.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For 60 years, since the dawn of contract bridge, the most difficult events to win in New York City have been the knockout team championships, scheduled two or three times a year at regional tournaments. The best performance ever on such an occasion by an all-woman team was achieved on July 17. Kathie Wei, Judi Radin, Karen McCallum and Kitty Bethe, all of Manhattan; Carol Simon, of Summit, N.J., and Susan Green, of Alexandria, Va., won their semifinal match with some help from the diagramed deal.
LEAD: President Saddam Hussein thought it would be a blitz, like Israel's 1967 war, when he sent Iraqi troops across the border into Iran in September 1980.
LEAD: International A2-11

LEAD: A man who was rehired by Honeywell Inc. after serving four years in prison for strangling a co-worker has been charged with killing another co-worker, a woman he allegedly stalked and threatened for weeks, the police said.

LEAD: ''New Directors/Newer Films,'' a two-week series of film screenings, many featuring works that have had their premieres at the New Directors/New Films series at Lincoln Center, is to begin Aug. 12 at 6:15 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Each program is to feature an early film by a particular director, followed by a later work.
LEAD: Roland D. Pampel, who resigned a week ago as president and chief operating officer of Apollo Computer Inc., has been named president of Honeywell Bull Inc.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When 20th Century-Fox gave Bruce Willis $5 million to star in ''Die Hard,'' the studio was gambling that, in return, the actor would entice customers into 1,258 theaters when the movie opened on July 15.

LEAD: The D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles media department, in its publication Insights, recommends that its clients not advertise in Whittle Communications' new Whittle Special Reports, the six specially made consumer magazines that will be circulated in doctor's offices.

LEAD: S.I. Newhouse Jr. makes no apologies for the abrupt changes at Vogue magazine. It was time to ''reposition Vogue for the 90's,'' the chairman of Conde Nast Publications said in an interview last week.
LEAD: ''Dukakis is good for the country,'' Governor Cuomo proclaimed yesterday on national television. ''Competence for a change.''

LEAD: At the Women's National Democratic Club in Washington, Martha Priddy Patterson was married yesterday to Laurence I. Barrett. Judge Abner Mikva of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit officiated.

LEAD: Late last month, as the approval process for Governor Cuomo's agreement with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant began to gather momentum, Wall Street reviewed the settlement and declared it highly favorable to Lilco.

LEAD: Two Palestinians were killed in clashes with soldiers in the occupied West Bank today as widespread violence marred the first day of the Moslem holiday Eid al-Adha and the Jewish holiday of Tisha b'Ab.

LEAD: Hundreds of people forming a human chain on the shore of Sylt Island in West Germany to protest the dumping of industrial waste into the North Sea. Deteriorating environmental conditions because of industrial pollution are being blamed for the recent deaths of 3,000 seals in the area. (AP)
LEAD: In his elegant modern headquarters here, the world's biggest soybean farmer tiptoed around the subject of his swollen profits as if worried that boasting would bring bad luck.
LEAD: Parts of southeast Brooklyn are sinking. They have been for years, and now, even as the city begins to repair the damage, the neighborhoods continue to sink.
LEAD: Luigi Lucioni, a realist painter known for his landscapes and portraits, died Friday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 87 years old.

LEAD: An Air France Boeing 747 jet carrying 275 people swerved off a runway at New Delhi's airport and crashed into a field today after the pilot aborted takeoff because he thought an engine was on fire, airport officials said. No one was seriously injured in the accident, the Airport Authority said. Indian news agencies said several passengers on the flight, which had been bound for Paris, were treated for minor cuts and bruises after evacuating the plane through emergency chutes.

LEAD: The fir-covered slopes of the High Sierra of California are teeming with blacktailed and mule deer now, and when fall replaces summer here the hunters will come to shoot them just as surely as the winter snows will follow.

LEAD: Two years after the House of Representatives voted to remove him from the bench, an impeached Federal district judge who served 17 months in prison for tax evasion sought Friday to resume practicing law in Federal court.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: A FEW years ago, a 1959 Cadillac Eldorado convertible with low mileage and in good condition could be bought for under $10,000. Earlier this year, one brought $67,000 at an auction and dealers in collector cars say $100,000 is in sight.

LEAD: Chemical Bank customers at five branches found their banker and a full-service broker under one roof last week. It was the latest step in the trend toward one-stop shopping for financial services and in the banking industry's drive to compete head-on.

LEAD: The SSC Holdings Corporation is issuing $500 million of debt in three tranches through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The first tranche of 13 percent senior subordinated extendible notes is priced at par and due in 1998. Due in 2000 will be $125 million of 12 1/2 percent notes and $175 million of 13 1/4 percent notes.
LEAD: Interagency rivalry took on a sartorial note last week during the dedication of a portrait of William H. Webster commemorating his tenure as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LEAD: A reflective, even melancholy Mayor Koch expressed some wistfulness today that Michael S. Dukakis had failed to select him as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention and expressed hope that Dukakis forces in New York would seek to use him in the Presidential campaign.
LEAD: In a city known for cigar-chomping politicians and smoke-filled rooms, a prohibition on smoking in many public places, ranging from taxis to train terminals, took effect today.
LEAD: ''We certainly have an affliction.'' - Dave Johnson, manager of the Mets, after second straight loss to last-place Braves. [ C3:5. ]
LEAD: Getting stuck in traffic on the way to Martha's Vineyard is one of Boston's unifying experiences.

LEAD: Michel Dion knew he had two strikes on him, so to speak, when Gary Carter joined the West Palm Beach Expos of the Florida State League in June 1972. Dion was the backup catcher with the Class AA team, and as soon as he saw Carter in action, he realized he did not have any future with the Montreal Expos.

LEAD: TOM SEAVER was late and Jay Horwitz, the Mets' director of media galvanization, was concerned on this gray Sunday morning. He peered out the door of the Diamond Club on the ground level of Shea Stadium with a troubled arch to his pensive brow.

LEAD: Mike Greenwell drove in one run with a triple and set up another with a double and Wade Boggs had three hits as the Boston Red Sox streaked to their 11th consecutive victory today by defeating the Chicago White Sox, 3-2.

LEAD: The marriage of Marianne Catherine Poltronieri, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Poltronieri of Richmondtown, S.I., to Roger John Pellegrini, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Pellegrini of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, took place yesterday at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens.

LEAD: U Ne Win's decision to step down after 26 years as Burma's leader and his call for a referendum on the country's one-party system has produced political uncertainty in a nation that traditionally favors harmony and stability, experts said yesterday.

LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. told its employees Friday that it could no longer be certain that it would receive 24 hours' notice before the Securities and Exchange Commission brought charges against it.
LEAD: Nancy Reagan being greeted by Rex as she and the President returned to the White House yesterday from their ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif., where they had spent an eight-day vacation. (AP)

LEAD: The members of the Supreme Court were assembled in conference one day not long ago, in the inner sanctum where they cast their votes on the claims of Presidents and paupers alike. Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall had the floor.
LEAD: Steve Sax had three hits and drove in both of the Dodgers' runs, and the rookie Shawn Hillegas limited Pittsburgh to one run over six innings as the Dodgers beat the Pirates, 2-1.

LEAD: A former E. F. Hutton broker was sentenced Friday to three months in prison and fined $3,000 for his part in a money-laundering scheme at the firm's Providence office. Brian J. Lareau, 46 years old, could have been sentenced to six years in prison and fined $6,000, but under a plea bargain prosecutors had recommended no more than six months in prison.

LEAD: IF you relish seafood and have had a series of boring days uselessly flogging ocean or bay for striped bass or bluefish, try clamming. Clams stay put. Once you have located them, they are yours, and the same is true of mussels.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: SKIP STORCH renewed an intriguing relationship 14 months ago. It began accidentally in college, broke off without reason for a decade, and resumed after Storch turned 30.

LEAD: UNLIKE most communities in the desert states of the Sun Belt, the summmer is kind to the economy of this mountain city. Interstate 40 slices through the southern tip of the main business district, bringing tourists in search of one of the Seven Wonders of the World.
LEAD: Three members of a jury that convicted a Mexican migrant worker of murder have formed a support group for the man after voicing doubts about their verdict.

LEAD: Chess players in Washington Square Park using an umbrella during their Sunday afternoon contest. But it was the sun they were warding off, not the rain that has persistently pelted the area for the last week. Today should be mostly sunny again, with a high in the mid-80's. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: Major Robinson, a journalist and public relations figure who helped originate Jet magazine, the Johnson Publishing Company's pocket-sized weekly, died Tuesday at Veterans Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: William N. Pennington, one of two partners who turned a money-losing pink Las Vegas casino into a casino-hotel company with a value of nearly $1 billion, has announced that he intends to sell a sizable portion of his Circus Circus Enterprises holdings and retire from his position as president.

LEAD: Iraqi troops started pulling back today from Iranian territory that they had occupied, according to information from both warring Persian Gulf neighbors, as the fierce fighting that flared between them last week appeared to subside.

LEAD: IN the last four years, one program, ''The Cosby Show,'' has essentially rearranged the network television business. The show brought NBC from last to first, its enormous popularity cannily exploited to build an empire of hits and to ruin the strategies of the opposition. Producers lucky enough to have shows proximate to ''Cosby'' on the NBC schedule are now Hollywood moguls.

LEAD: At St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I., Amanda Elissa Hodgson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. S. Hodgson of Port Washington, was married yesterday to John Thomas Hompe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harold Hompe of Stanley, Wis. The Rev. Joseph C. Coschignano performed the ceremony.

LEAD: About a week ago, the small United States diplomatic mission here invited about 20 Cuban human rights advocates and a few foreign diplomats to a cocktail party at the apartment of one of the Americans.
LEAD: Al Unser Jr. cut Emerson Fittipaldi off at the pass today and went on to win the Marlboro Grand Prix at the Meadowlands.
LEAD: Indian Army troops were instructed today to maintain order in parts of the western state of Gujarat after a revolt there by thousands of police officers.
LEAD: The Federal Hall National Memorial, which is being renovated for next year's bicentennial of Washington's inauguration, will house a new museum. Page B3. (NYT/Fred R. Conrad)

LEAD: South Korea's new President, Roh Tae Woo, has wisely and boldly scrapped the substance and liturgy of South Korea's longstanding policy of totally shunning the Communist North. Earlier this month, he called for massive exchange of visits between the Koreas and for open trade frontiers, as within a single nation.

LEAD: His number retired, Tom Seaver climbed into a black convertible near home plate yesterday to finish his ceremonial lap of Shea Stadium. The car, with Seaver perched on top of the back seat, slowly circled the stands as the crowd mustered one last ovation.

LEAD: Riverside Church, an institution born of wealth whose programs to fight poverty and injustice are models for churches around the nation, is desperately trying to cut costs and raise money to avert what its interim senior minister calls financial ''disaster.''

LEAD: Bill Parcells may remember this as one of the more forgettable training camps in his six seasons as the Giants' head coach. Downpours, illnesses and holdouts dashed the Giants' hopes for a quick start.

LEAD: Parties that formed Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda's coalition Government won 58 percent of the votes in Sunday's parliamentary elections, paving the way for General Prem's return to power, official results showed today.

LEAD: After three tortuous months of jury selection, the longest in the memory of Bronx court officials, opening arguments will begin tomorrow in the latest trial of Larry Davis in the Bronx County Courthouse.

LEAD: * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, a bank holding company, elected as a director Frederick P. Stratton Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Milwaukee-based Briggs & Stratton Corp., a producer of air-cooled gas engines for outdoor power equipment.

LEAD: Tom Seaver and his wife, Nancy, waving to the crowd yesterday at Shea Stadium, where his number was retired. Seaver's presence wasn't sufficiently inspiring for Mets, who fell to Braves, 4-2. Page C3. (The New York Times/G. Paul Burnett)

LEAD: Matthews & Wright Group Inc. has disclosed that a Federal grand jury in the Southern District of New York has been investigating certain municipal bond issues underwritten by the New York-based investment concern.

LEAD: Serious Living By Tom Lorenz 213 pages. Viking. $17.95. Speaking in Tongues By Linda Ashour 223 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

LEAD: A 40 percent increase in the United States' sugar quota will benefit the Dominican Republic, the Philippines, Brazil and 36 other countries and is bringing praise from large United States sugar users.

LEAD: ALL-INCLUSIVE package plans at ski resorts have been around a long time. Even nonskiers usually know of ski weeks or weekend vacations that include lodging, meals, skiing and ski instruction. It's only logical that this kind of package plan would sooner or later be available for summer activities at ski resorts.

LEAD: Ceaseless fund-raising events at the Democratic Convention produced a slew of $100,000 checks for the Dukakis campaign. The process and the money make clear that fat-cat donors, limited after Watergate by Federal restrictions and new laws on public financing, are once again a major factor.

LEAD: Treasury offerings this week include a two-year note sale and a one-year bill auction in addition to the regular sale of three-month and six-month bills.

LEAD: A new report by a committee of the National Association of Securities Dealers strongly criticizes proposals to halt trading in volatile markets. The report comes when a consensus is growing among major exchanges and market experts that such a plan should be adopted.

More than 360,000 copies of the $45 book, first published in 1969 and updated every few years, have been sold.

LEAD: Christian Lacroix, who propelled poufs and brief skirts into the mainstream of fashion with his first couture collection a year ago, proved today that there are more strings to his lyre. LEAD: Where is the safest place to be in an electrical storm? One must be the Empire State Building. It has been struck as many as eight times in a single storm yet no one inside gets hurt.

LEAD: Larry A. Myers's aim as the director of recruiting for the Jones Motor Group is to find enough new truck drivers to support the company's ambitious growth plans. But his real problem is simply keeping up with the turnover in Jones's current pool of 350 drivers.
LEAD: Jeannie Longo of France won her second consecutive women's Tour de France today.

An attending physician said Mr. Clements, who is 71 years old, was ''in excellent condition,'' according to Cheryl McEntire, a s pokeswoman for the Seton Medical Center. The Governor said he felt good enough to campaign vigorously for Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign.
LEAD: Under the tutelage of her American cousins, 8-year-old Kia Lor is learning about soap operas, baseball, hair styles and even this odd custom, she confided, of painting one's fingernails.
LEAD: Susan Louis Schwartz and Andrew Schuyler Lynn were married yesterday in Mystic, Conn., at the Inn at Mystic. Judge Angelo Santaniello of the Connecticut Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Yvonne Scott Burgess and Barrington Neville Wright were married yesterday at Alder Manor at Elizabeth Seton College in Yonkers. Justice Daniel W. Joy of State Supreme Court officiated. He was assisted by the bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. George Wilson of the Seventh Day Adventist Church.
LEAD: Mystery on Channel 13
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TWO retired women from the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn recently were discussing the exercise video they had produced. ''I think we made the video because we were retired and wanted something to do,'' said Belle Joseph, who is 72 and proud of it. ''We were feeling guilty about not doing anything.
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on July 13 about models' product scruples referred incorrectly to a modeling agency, L'image. It is not defunct; it remains in business.

LEAD: One of the most intense personal and political feuds in Britain in the 1980's turned into a public uproar this weekend after former Prime Minister Edward Heath attacked his successor as Conservative Party leader, Margaret Thatcher.

LEAD: The track and field team that will represent the United States in the Seoul Olympics could win as many as 32 medals in 42 events, including 14 gold. That would be eight fewer over all than Americans won in the Los Angeles Games four years ago and two fewer gold.

LEAD: Anyone who has ever watched a group of 8- , 9- and 10-year-olds try to play organized baseball has a good idea of the meaning of eternity. Even with the shortened distance of 45 feet 6 inches from the pitching mound to home, few 10-year-olds are able to get the ball over the plate with any consistency.

LEAD: Buddhist rebels shot and killed five Moslem settlers and wounded three others in an ambush Saturday on a ferry in southern Bangladesh, the police said today. The rebels opposed a Government program resettling Moslems from the plains to hilly land. They attacked a boat ferrying 50 settlers near the hill town of Rangamati, about 120 miles southeast of Dhaka, a police officer said.
LEAD: Despite the gallons and gallons of mineral water consumed, the daily showers in warm spring water, and the occasional mud bath or two, the Queen is showing her age. The Queen of Spas, that is.
LEAD: Steven Spielberg's multimillion-dollar home was damaged today in a fire that spread to another oceanfront estate, the authorities said.
LEAD: The senior contra guerrilla leader says he hopes a new round of negotiation with the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua can be held next month.
LEAD: Ling-Ling, the nation's famed female giant panda, may be pregnant again, a zoo spokesman said today.

LEAD: Leonard Bernstein is to conduct three concerts in Moscow this week, tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday. He will lead the Schleswig-Holstein Music Festival Orchestra, which is made up of 119 young musicians from 18 countries. The concerts are to be televised in the Soviet Union in observance of Mr. Bernstein's 70th birthday, which is Aug.
