LEAD: The Fashion Channel Network Inc., which sells clothes through cable television, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company said Friday that it had ''severe liquidity problems'' but supplied no financial data. The Fashion Channel said it intended to keep distributing the program through its present cable systems.

LEAD: Richard D. Hueltje sat at a small truck stop here just after 6 A.M., dividing his attention between his hearty breakfast of toast, eggs and home fries and the log book that he is required to keep by the United States Department of Transportation.

LEAD: The steel industry is battling to win a bigger piece of the beverage can market it once dominated. Steel makers say that higher aluminum prices and better technology have made their product competitive again.

LEAD: JUST what is it that Jim Pierce, Bill O'Malley, Dean Brackley and Henry Schwalbenberg have in common? Three are bearded. One is black. But all are Jesuits - three priests and a brother - and they all star in a sophisticated print advertising campaign intended to attract other men to their ranks.

LEAD: Tom Seaver returned yesterday to Shea Stadium, where the pitcher's No. 41 was retired by the Mets in a ceremony before the game with the Braves. Seaver's old number was painted on the outfield fence, but all this was not inspiring enough for the Mets, who were beaten by Atlanta, 4-2, their second straight loss against the last-place team.

LEAD: Like a runner who stumbles and falls only to pick herself up and win the race, Liselotte Neumann of Sweden bounced back from a potentially disasterous four-putt double bogey today to win the 43d United States Women's Open championship with a record score of 277.
LEAD: It was Sunday morning and Michael S. Dukakis was occupied in the same way as much of middle America. He was in church, with his wife, listening to a sermon about loving one's neighbor and God.
LEAD: Finishing a Tour de France shaken by a dispute over his drug use, Pedro Delgado cruised across the finish line in Paris victorious this afternoon.

LEAD: Fourteen years after he resigned in disgrace from the Presidency, Richard Nixon has emerged as a senior statesman and American oracle on important foreign policy issues. LEAD: Comic-book readers know Marvel for its gripping tales of Spiderman, Captain America and other heroes. Now, the Marvel Entertainment Group itself is the star of a saga.

LEAD: PROGRAMS like Sublogic's Flight Simulator II and Microsoft's Flight Simulator put you behind control panels so realistic that you actually do have to learn how a plane is flown and what its many instruments do. LEAD: The Alltel Corporation has offered to acquire the CP National Corporation in a stock swap that values the telephone utility company at about $280 million. ''Family Viewing'' was shown as part of the recent ''New Directors/ New Film'' series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 23. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema 1, at La Guardia Place. Video cameras and monitors watch over the characters in Atom Egoyan's ''Family Viewing'' with the patience and passivity of vultures, but without the enthusiasm. The advent of this modern technology seems to have drained all vitality out of the participants in Mr. Egoyan's very peculiar black comedy, and it's their listlessness that makes them so funny and sad.

LEAD: An article on June 29 about a Soviet newspaper's publication of a plea for legal vindication of Trotsky briefly described Trotsky's politics. LEAD: Approval of a proposal to transplant foreign genes into the blood cells of human patients was deferred by a Federal advisory panel today until further data from animal research becomes available.

LEAD: A professor convicted of killing and dismembering a teen-age male prostitute with a chain saw was sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison. The 58-year-old defendant, Max Bernard Franc, taught political science at Fresno State University until his arrest last August. His secret life as a homosexual voyeur was disclosed at his trial for the killing of Tracy Leroy Nute, 18, a runaway from Kansas City, Mo.

LEAD: A Canadian zoologist has developed a chemical contraceptive for males that he contends is ''safe, simple and cheap.'' The compound, which has been tested in rats, rabbits and monkeys, appears to stop sperm production without diminishing sex drive or causing unwanted side effects.

LEAD: We hear a good deal of third-world music in New York, but while the sounds of certain countries are heard regularly enough to have acquired a certain familiarity, every now and then a concert is presented that reminds us how diverse the musical universe is. The New York Open Center offered one such reminder last Saturday evening with a program called ''Traditional Music of Cambodia,'' performed by a quintet led by Sam-Ang Sam, a young doctoral candidate at Wesleyan University whose specialty is the music of the Khmer civilization.

LEAD: Pearson P.L.C., the British conglomerate that publishes The Financial Times, said it had sold its British oil subsidiary, Whitehall Petroleum Ltd., to Amerada Hess Ltd. for $162 million in cash. Lord Blakenham, chairman and chief executive of Pearson, said that Whitehall's oil interests had potential but that Pearson would have to make a substantial capital investment and wait for years before it would make a significant contribution to the conglomerate's profit.

LEAD: A forest fire burning at the outskirts of Rapid City on Thursday. Officials reported yesterday that the fire had been 90 percent contained and that they hoped to have it under control by Sunday. The fire, which has been called the work of an arsonist, has been burning since Tuesday and has consumed about 3,000 acres of timber and destroyed 15 homes on the western edge of the city.

LEAD: THE long-awaited decision by the Supreme Court of New York came last week and so we are going to see in September perhaps the strangest race ever staged on land, sea or air between humans, animals or machines.

LEAD: THE next phase in the development of the compact disk is interactive compact disks or CD-I. These disks, which are still in the developmental stages, allow the user to, in essence, ''talk back'' to a television set to get information. Philips and Sony are among the companies working on making CD-I available for the mass-market; they hope to have their products in stores as early as next summer.

LEAD: Sara R. French, a daughter of Naomi French of Brooklyn and the late Emanuel French, and Laurence S. Margolin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Margolin of Great Neck, L.I., were married last evening. Rabbi Myron Fenster officiated at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: WHEN a golf shot struck and killed one of a gaggle of Canada geese on the seventh fairway at the Shorehaven Golf Club in Norwalk recently, the greenskeeper, Bobby Shipps, was anything but sad.

LEAD: One year after sponsoring an accord to end the conflict in Sri Lanka, India remains mired in its island neighbor's bloody civil war with little prospect of ending the violence, imposing a settlement or bringing home its 50,000 troops.

LEAD: IT may well be that nothing funny happened to Willie Stargell on his way to induction today into the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, but something passing strange seems to have affected at least a few of the people whose votes helped put him there. I should know. I was one of them.
LEAD: It was our first substantial, grown-up-and-married purchase. We made it with trepidation and a slightly inflated sense of the importance of the event.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson returned to the stump today, proclaiming the victories he won this year, declaring he would probably run for President again and, by the way, urging a vote this fall for Michael S. Dukakis.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Owen Moore Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Moore's daughter Elizabeth Christian Gray to Leonard Jerome Buck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Austin Buck of Bernardsville, N.J. The couple plan to marry Oct. 1.

LEAD: Two Iowa Interstate freight trains collided head on today northeast of Des Moines, killing two railraod workers and injuring two others. The crash near the suburb of Altoona, Iowa, started a fire and caused at least one tank car to overturn, said a spokesman for the Polk County sheriff's office.

LEAD: Dianne Wiest intended but didn't get a chance to see Christopher Hampton's ''Liaisons Dangereuses,'' which closed rather abruptly when the Royal Shakespeare Company vacated Broadway's Music Box Theater after four months in 1987. LEAD: THE Norfolk Chamber Music Festival, which wraps up its 48th season this weekend, has emerged as so important an adjunct of summer music in Connecticut that we tend to forget that its original raison d'etre was to provide a home and a focus for the Yale Summer School of Music.

LEAD: King Hussein signed a decree today dissolving the lower house of Jordan's Parliament, which represents the interest of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the official Jordanian press agency announced this afternoon.

LEAD: The moves by King Hussein of Jordan to reduce his role in the West Bank will complicate American efforts to arrange Arab-Israeli peace negotiations, but do not necessarily kill the American peace plan, according to American officials and foreign diplomats.

LEAD: RENT regulation extends a broad hand over New York City housing, determining to a great degree how much residents in more than one million apartments will pay in rent each month. Even so, more than half a million apartments spread throughout the five boroughs are unfettered by government strings and rent for what the market will bear.

LEAD: For the first time in more than 18 months, the families of Americans held hostage by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon say they have allowed themselves to be optimistic that their loved ones will be released.

Spartan fishing villages give way to towns with boutiques, restaurants and galleries. Simplicity and sophistication coexist along this 161-mile stretch that is Maine's midcoast region. The best way to get a feel for the terrain is by car, a trip that can take a few hours or a few days, preferably accompanied by DeLorme's Maine

LEAD: Don Elster spent the first three innings pacing in the stands behind home plate. His wife and his daughter-in-law were late arriving at Shea Stadium Friday, no minor worry for out-of-towners in the place called Fun City.

LEAD: As technicians corrected malfunctions at the launching pad, officials said today that they expect to resume an often-delayed countdown rehearsal in time to ignite the space shuttle Discovery's main engines in a key test on Thursday.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Burke of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Spencer Burke, to Michael Joseph McNamara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. McNamara of Waltham, Mass. Miss Burke and her fiance, graduates of Middlebury College, plan to marry Sept. 10.

LEAD: ONE OCTOBER EVENING 21 months ago, my husband and I went out to dinner and to see ''La Traviata'' at the Metropolitan. We ate at a favorite restaurant and he said that I looked beautiful in my new wool suit. Since my outfit was a decade old, I smiled and thanked him for his compliment: we'd been married for 21 years.

LEAD: Legislation is pending in Congress that would mandate 10 weeks of leave without pay for parents, after which workers would have a right to reclaim their jobs. William C. Dunkelberg, dean of the School of Business at Temple University and chief economist of the National Federation of Independent Business, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman about the economic impact of extended periods of parental leave.
LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis laid responsibility for the Pentagon fraud scandal at the feet of President Reagan and Vice President Bush today, asserting, ''A fish rots from the head first.''

LEAD: Aleksandr Askoldov, the Soviet director of ''Commissar,'' was able to endure Moscow's 21-year suppression of his film by refusing to give up hope for its eventual success, only to find at its screening at the Library of Congress that it had been cut by its American distributor.

LEAD: The Divinyls, a rock band from Australia, came on stage at the Ritz on Friday night without much fuss. It's that sort of a group: instead of the canned drama that usually precedes mainstream rock acts, it generates excitement in other ways.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Pollis of North Attleboro and West Falmouth, Mass., have announced that their daughter Ann Margaret Pollis and Jonathan O'Herron Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Herron of Darien, Conn., and Woods Hole, Mass., plan to marry Sept. 24.
LEAD: Eddie Murphy Raw With Eddie Murphy. Directed by Robert Townsend. 1987. Paramount Home Video. 90 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

LEAD: HOW European is Britain anyway? Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had head-shaking continentals asking that question last week after she launched a sizzling attack on one of her favorite whipping boys, Jacques Delors, president of the European Community's commission.

LEAD: Last quarter, the gross national product grew by 3.1 percent, down from recent quarters but still fairly healthy. Strong growth combined with high levels of capacity utilization and low unemployment is the classic formula for inflation. But commodity prices have recently begun to fall due to a stronger dollar and the return of rain to the Middle West.

LEAD: To the Editor: During a recent visit to Moscow and Leningrad to present a film about the Broadway theater to Soviet high school students, I was eager to experience as much Russian theater as possible. I found that the Intourist sevice desk at my hotel posted lists of over 30 state-supported theaters presenting musical and dramatic attractions on a daily basis.

LEAD: Sometime in the late 1920's, Horace Pippin, a black American veteran of World War I, began to write his memories of his war. It must have been difficult: Pippin was not a writer and was not very well educated. Even the physical act of writing was hard for him, for his right hand and arm had been crippled by a sniper's bullet and he could scarcely hold a pen.
LEAD: It was W. H. Auden who pointed to a special meaning of ''new.'' ''For many of us,'' he observed, ''our most important 'new' experiences are discoveries about the hitherto unknown past.''

LEAD: ''Meet me at Stop No. 6,'' urges the friendly voice on the Metropolitan Museum's audio-cassette tour. ''It's Edouard Manet's 'Boating.' You'll find it by walking past Manet's 'Woman With a Parrot' to the other side of the gallery.'' Museum visitors who arrive at the rendezvous wonder if they've been stood up.

While no other citizens are afforded similar privileges, journalists have often seen themselves as unelected public servants, members of a special Fourth

LEAD: A bomb exploded at a crowded shopping center in a white suburb of Johannesburg today, killing a woman and wounding at least 56 other people, the police said. The authorities said most of the victims were white, including the woman who died.

LEAD: The engagement of Patricia Ann McGinley to Scott Murray Quackenbush, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert G. Quackenbush of Orlando, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. McGinley of Short Hills, N.J., and Hobe Sound, Fla. An October wedding is planned.
LEAD: Germany invented them, France exploited them and America bought them with a fervor that has yet to subside. But automobiles came late to England.

LEAD: NEXT month's ''Twelfth Night'' performances in New Haven represent coincidental celebrations of contrasting scope: the city's 350th anniversary and the fifth year of its free outdoor series, Shakespeare on the Green. Ironically, the city's costly commemorative festivities almost prevented the show on the green from going on, according to its director, Amy Seham.

LEAD: Millions of substandard nuts and bolts have been used in everything from military equipment and weapons to the space shuttle and commercial trucks, a Congressional committee said in a report issued today.

LEAD: Dr. Eric Werner, a musicologist and an authority on sacred music, died of heart failure Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A table on July 10 with an article about Savoy Hotel P.L.C. gave incorrect figures for the company's second-quarter earnings per share for 1988 and 1987. For the 1988 quarter, the earnings were 57 cents; for the 1987 quarter, they were 51 cents.

LEAD: My horse is galloping down the line as I prepare for a neck shot to theleft from the off, or right, side of the horse. The sky is clear and the day warm for early December. A small crowd is gathered at the perimeter of the field watching the six riders of the green and yellow teams clash on the dusty terrain.

LEAD: TOMORROW, Warner Books, one of the biggest commercial publishers in the United States, marks the official publication date of ''Batman: Year One,'' a 96-page color comic book about a neurotic superhero who is a successor to the original caped crusader. This event follows the success of the 1986 Batman book, ''The Dark Knight Returns,'' which has sold 85,000 copies.

LEAD: I don't wish to deny Mary Anne Dolan's experience as the editor of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, but it doesn't necessarily follow that capable women promoted to positions of power become backstabbers (''When Feminism Failed,'' June 26). Her attempt to turn her newsroom into a matriarchal family failed because of some fatal errors in concept and execution.

LEAD: In Gorongosa District, Mozambique, July 28 - In the heart of Mozambique, a beleaguered group of anti-government rebels facing almost total regional and international isolation continues to plot the destruction of this country's ailing transport and electricity network from the seclusion of their shifting forest headquarters.

LEAD: IMPROVISATION: Music From the Inside Out. By Mildred Portney Chase. (Creative Arts, Paper, $7.95.) Improvisation, as we are often reminded, is concert music's lost art. Two hundred years ago, cadenzas in concerto movements served to launch the individual performer's flights of fancy; cadenzas today are simply repetitions of what someone else has already written out.

LEAD: Ferdinand E. Marcos said he is willing to forget the whole thing, support the Philippine President and stay out of politics if he can just go home. But whatever the offers of ''reconciliation,'' as he put it last week, the Government of Corazon C. Aquino denied that any negotiations were under way.

LEAD: AS recently as four years ago, New York City stood as the most expensive office center in the world. But the sagging fortunes of the dollar and the growth of other cities as money-market rivals make Manhattan look like an international bargain today.

LEAD: A caption in The Times Magazine last Sunday with an article by Tom Wicker about a family voyage misidentified the site in the illustration. It was Hawaii, the starting point of the family's ocean adventure.

LEAD: Henry James, who on another occasion admitted to a perpetual love affair with Venice, once described the city as a vast museum where the little wicket that admits you is perpetually turning and creaking, a place you march through with a herd of fellow gazers.

LEAD: A number of military contractors are contending that a new Pentagon policy requiring them to certify that they have not received inside information in the bidding process is overly restrictive and could leave them in a legally untenable position.
LEAD: Three contract bridge titles were sought here today, the second day of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

LEAD: Reviews arouse resentment. The most common kind is anger at what is perceived as excessive or misguided negativism: an artist or his admirers protests (to the critic directly but more commonly among themselves) about the critic's ignorance or intemperance or penchant for personal vendetta.
LEAD: Iran said today that its troops drove Iraqi soldiers occupying four towns back to the border and blunted a new Iraqi offensive elsewhere. Iraq said it withdrew from occupied areas.

LEAD: Linda Joyce Grinage by any other name and 19 years later was still a hijacker, Federal authorities said last week as they arrested a 39-year-old woman using the name Haziine Eytina in Albany. No statute of limitations applied, they explained, as she already had been indicted in the hijacking of an Eastern Airlines jet that was forced to land in Havana in 1969.

LEAD: The series ofarticles on the Soviet Union (Travel, May 22) was most informative. In ''The key to a successful trip...'' reference was made to the presence of giardiasis in the water of Leningrad with advice to drink only bottled water, which I always adhere to when traveling.
LEAD: Britain plans to evacuate 10 embassy workers and their dependents from Afghanistan next week because of fears of increased guerrilla attacks on Kabul, the Foreign Office said today.

LEAD: Inside Venice, for us, was located only two brisk turns behind San Marco, ''the central building of the world,'' in the city that in certain moods looks as if it might still, for coherent beauty, rank as the central city of the world. In 1987, when we were looking for a pied-a-terre in Venice, we were unexpectedly offered one, gratis, by a learned and charming Bolognese doctor, at that time unknown to us, who happens to agree with Ruskin about San Marco and the esthetic perfections of La Serenissima - the most Serene, an old name for Venezia.

LEAD: BACK in the days of yesteryear, when I bought my first single-len reflex, cameras came with single-focal-length lenses. Usually you started out with a lens of about 50 millimeters, since that was what the camera makers and photography magazines called ''normal.'' I certainly wanted to be a normal photographer, so that's what I got.

LEAD: Tennis Agassi to Face Annacone: Second-seeded Andre Agassi advanced to the final of the Volvo International tournament in Stratton Mountain, Vt., yesterday, using his powerful forehand and a looping topspin to beat 12th-seeded Dan Goldie, 6-3, 6-3. Agassi's opponent today will be 13th-seeded Paul Annacone, who returned to his chip-and-charge game to defeat ninth-seeded Darren Cahill, 6-4, 6-3.

LEAD: Deborah Louise Scattergood and James Daniel Chastain were married yesterday at Christ United Methodist Church by-the-Sea in Vero Beach, Fla., by the Rev. James E. Ulmer Sr. and the Rev. Dr. Julius G. Rice.

LEAD: AS soon as drugs emerged as a big issue in this year's American election campaign, nervous Latin American governments braced themselves for more accusations, aware that vote-seeking politicians in the United States would once again blame the supply of cocaine, heroin and marijuana from the south for the devastating impact of drugs in the north.

LEAD: WHEN one thinks of hammer blows, the image that comes to mind is that of a mating attack sweeping through all resistance, yet positional play in which the safety of the enemy king is not an issue can also evince extraordinary force.

LEAD: My generation finds itself wedged between two opposing traditions. One is the tradition we know in such wonderful detail from the enormous recorded legacy that tells anyone who will listen that jazz broke the rules of European conventions and created rules of its own that were so specific, so thorough and so demanding that a great art resulted.

LEAD: Revco sought bankruptcy protection, burdened by the huge debt load that management took on when it bought the drugstore chain in a $1.3 billion leveraged buyout 19 months ago. Revco's chairman, Boake A. Sells, said most of the 2,000 stores were profitable but the company could not generate enough cash to cover both operating expenses and $150 million a year in interest payments.

LEAD: Suddenly, a season of peace seems to be warming the world. The last few months have seen five bitter and protracted conflicts brought suddenly closer to peaceful resolution. In the Middle East, Asia, Africa and Central America, populations stunned and bleeding by endless regional war look up and hope.
LEAD: Court officials are setting up special sections of New York City Civil Court to handle eviction cases filed against suspected drug dealers by the Manhattan District Attorney.

LEAD: The Sugar Cubes, who had been kept from playing here in June by visa problems, finally made it to New York and played their debut performance to a packed audience at the World on Thursday night. The group, from Iceland, has a good idea: it mixes a touch of punk noise and anarchism with a new-wave, near-folk melodicism.

LEAD: TOPSY TURVY. Written and illustrated by Monika Beisner. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. (All ages) The rich and witty illustrations that accompany this collection of short verses, adapted from the German by Daniel Huws, are full of topsy-turvy incongruities. A little girl sits on the lap of her wooden doll, kites dance on the ground while children fly in the sky, a cuckoo hatches kittens from her eggs.

LEAD: The first week of the United Nations-sponsored Persian Gulf peace talks ended today with Iran and Iraq still deeply divided over whether to hold face-to-face negotiations on ending their eight-year-old war.

The parochial nature of United States sports means that domestic sports such as baseball overshadow international competitions such as track and field.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., Anne Theresa Murtagh, an associate at Brown & Wood, and Gerard V. Hannon, a partner in Coudert Brothers, both Manhattan law firms, were married yesterday by Msgr. William B. Smith.

LEAD: CAROLYNE ROEHM has been going to Southampton since summer 1973, the year she arrived in New York with a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from Washington University. ''I ate my first lobster, I breathed the fresh air, I saw the ocean for the first time,'' she said the other day in her Seventh Avenue showroom.

LEAD: SALAMANDER: The Story of the Mormon Forgery Murders. By Linda Sillitoe and Allen D. Roberts with a forensic analysis by George J. Throckmorton. (Signature, $17.95.) Mark Hofmann, a premed student, decided at age 25 to become a professional forger of old documents. For several years in the early 1980's he had outstanding success as he turned the Mormon world upside down while he picked its pockets and cast doubt on some of its fundamental beliefs.

LEAD: The leadup to the Olympics is exhilarating, as so many facets of so many athletes can be explored and uncovered. Although the spectrum of events, such as steeplechase, crewing and water polo, is not necessarily top-of-mind, these sports are fascinatingly refreshing.

LEAD: The thrust of Peter Schmeisser's article on American cigarette exports was predictable from its title, ''Pushing Cigarettes Overseas'' (July 10). However, whether one likes or dislikes a product is a matter quite apart from whether or not it should be treated equitably in world trade. Some people think we would be better off without televisions and motorcycles, but the existence of those products worldwide is a matter of everyday reality.

LEAD: Sometimes thought to pass judgment only on the follies of private developers, the New York City Planning Commission will meet Wednesday after a month's break, with schools and housing for the elderly topping the agenda.

LEAD: A professor convicted of killing and dismembering a teen-age male prostitute with a chain saw was sentenced Friday to 25 years to life in prison. The 58-year-old defendant, Max Bernard Franc, taught political science at Fresno State University until his arrest last August. His secret life as a homosexual voyeur was disclosed at his trial for the killing of Tracy Leroy Nute, 18.

LEAD: A bill that would require a person's written consent before he could be tested for the AIDS virus and that would set rules for confidentiality of test results appears virtually certain to be enacted by the New York State Legislature.

LEAD: Elegant in the clinging draperies of her period, but looking sturdy enough to have pulled a plow back home on Mount Olympus, a 2,400-year-old goddess believed to be Aphrodite has been causing a stir in the world of classical art. The J. Paul Getty Museum announced last week that it had acquired the marble-and-limestone statue of the goddess, seven and a half feet tall, for an undisclosed price.

The Rev. Stephen M. Rozzelle performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: The banner, made up of individual placards and subject to change with each batter, hangs above the loge seats in right field. Last night, it read: SSSSSSSSSSSSSID, with each of the first dozen letters designating a strikeout. For Sid Fernandez, it is not the standard spelling of his name. It is, though, an increasingly common way of summarizing his game.

LEAD: If style and its permutations, fashionability and taste, are major topics of late 80s art, then Robert Mapplethorpe is perhaps the most topical artist of the moment. Less than 20 years since he first decided to make art with a camera, his elegant but often provocative photographs are being heralded as exemplars of the new stylish sensibility.

LEAD: Old master paintings have been at home in London for close on 400 years, but right now there is what might be called a new nonchalance in the way in which they come into view. It is not that they are taken for granted - how could they be, when so many of them have been made new for us by recent cleaning?

LEAD: To the Editor: Odessa and Yalta, both Urkranian cities, were identified as Soviet cities. This is a similar to saying that Paris or Rome are in Europe without bothering to indicate the countries in which they are found.

LEAD: THE American electronics industry is in distress and vulnerable. The distress is most visible in the dwindling market and technological position of the computer chip industry. Vulnerability is clearest in the dependency of most American electronics systems producers on inadequate supplies of Japanese memory chips.

LEAD: IF RESEARCH by Dr. Francis A. L'Esperance Jr. succeeds, people with bad eyesight will be able to see clearly without glasses.

LEAD: South Africa has wisely suspended temporarily a proposal that would require some journalists to register or face heavy fines or jail. But the proposal is only suspended, not shelved, and it's hardly reassuring that Home Minister Stoffel Botha cites ''practical considerations'' as grounds for his decision.

LEAD: Yes. But for objective media coverage I have to turn to sources other than the home press and television. The domestic media continue to report on the Olympics with a parochial fervor that borders on arrogance.

LEAD: AL FRESCO SHAKESPEARE According to the Performance Studio of New Haven, even small children enjoy a taste of Shakespeare as presented by the six-year-old troupe in al fresco settings for an audience of picnickers.

LEAD: Kimberly Susan Castor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Castor of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy James Kristof, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Kristof of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Robert Childs officiated at the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn. Mrs. Kristof is a marketing development manager for the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting and consulting firm in New York.

LEAD: In the contemporary design world, black conjures up images of sleek, high-tech objects and stark spaces. But countless old-fashioned decorative accessories are black, too. Indeed, black can be as romantic and alluring as it can be gloomy, perhaps because it is an earth pigment that in the color spectrum expresses violet.

LEAD: A table last week with an article about McGraw-Hill Inc. mislabeled the company's second-quarter results for 1988 and 1987. For the 1988 quarter, revenues were $443.8 million, net income was $44.8 million and earnings per share were 92 cents. For the 1987 quarter, revenues were $425.9 million, net income was $40 million and earnings per share were 79 cents.

LEAD: What is the National Ballet of Canada? For nearly three decades it seemed to model itself after Britain's Royal Ballet; then suddenly, a few years ago, it began to resemble American Ballet Theater. Nowadays, it looks, believe it or not, like the National Ballet of Canada - a company that has finally found its true identity.

LEAD: Lilian Mary King and Allan Dodds Frank were married yesterday at the Players, a club in Manhattan, by the Rev. David Good, a Congregational minister.

LEAD: Jose Quintero's article ''Carlotta and the Master'' (May 1) was most interesting. However, the credit line for the portrait of Carlotta and Eugene O'Neill should have read ''Photograph by Ben Pinchot.''

LEAD: Several times this year a group of residents here on Martha's Vineyard have been driven through town on a flatbed truck, some of them dressed in bandages made to look bloody. It is not a pretty sight. But then, some residents said, neither is the plethora of accidents on motor-driven bicycles, or mopeds, that prompted the display and a campaign to ban moped rentals.

LEAD: America may pride itself as socially advanced, but to read two recent studies from the Alan Guttmacher Institute is to conclude that when it comes to sex and its consequences, this country is downright backward.

LEAD: The other night at the Cat Club, David Thomas of Pere Ubu was introducing ''Final Solution,'' a song about a teen-age wallflower the band recorded a decade ago and had disdained until other groups revived it. ''They all pronounce the words so that they can be understood,'' he said, and paused, deadpan.

LEAD: A NEW edition of ''Summer Cooking'' by Elizabeth David has just been published by Penguin ($8.95, paper). First published in 1955, it remains as fresh as ever. ''A grilled chicken is perhaps one of the nicest foods at any time,'' is a statement that could be written today.

LEAD: THE owner of the Seattle Mariners announced that he would not take immediate advantage of an escape clause in his lease with the Kingdome that would allow him to move the team to another city next season. The statement by George Argyros came after considerable speculation in Seattle that he would invoke a provision of the lease that allows him to seek a new site for the team if attendance fails to average 1.4 million for two consecutive seasons, an average the Mariners failed to acheive.

LEAD: After holding the National Horse Show in one Madison Square Garden or another for 104 years, show officials have decided that it has become too expensive. The horse show officials have approached officials of the Meadowlands about the possibility of moving to Byrne Meadowlands Arena for the 1989 show.
LEAD: It is an exquisitely vexing debate over cable television and the First Amendment. Trouble is, the First Amendment seems to be on both sides.

LEAD: THE argument over the height of 116 John Street, which was built 58 years ago, sounds just like the current zoning dispute case at 108 East 96th Street, a dispute that has caught the public's attention because it is so unusual.

LEAD: The president of Westfield State College resigned Thursday after questions arose over his use of trust funds for personal expenses, becoming the second top official in two years to leave the institution amid investigations of alleged misconduct.

LEAD: After three months and three tries, including two mistrials and the winnowing of a pool of more than 1,000 prospective jurors, a ju y was finally put together and testimony began last week at the trial of Larry Davis in the Bronx County Courthouse. He is accused of the attempted murder of nine police officers in a shootout in 1986.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Wendy Lian Williams is talented enough to be considered a strong medal candidate in Olympic platform diving. She is attractive enough to have been featured in Mademoiselle. She is stubborn enough to have forged a teen-aged life away from her family and overcome growing-up problems that might have broken someone not as determined.

LEAD: ROBERT J. CARBONELL remembers it all too well. About 12 years ago, Standard Brands Inc. (now a part of RJR Nabisco Inc.) was talking to a since-disbanded branch of the Soviet Union's agricultural ministry about producing high-fructose corn syrup in Russia. Soviet officials broached the idea, so presumably they did all they could to ease the company's path.
LEAD: Getting Around In China Gets Easier

LEAD: A glossy black-and-white photograph came across the desk showing an aerial view of Wrigley Field in its new nighttime garb. A longtime Wrigley Field fan and a keeper of the flame for old-time virtues looked at it. ''I hate it,'' he said. ''It looks beautiful.'' Indeed it did. There was the flush of light on the ball field and this was set against the black velvet background of the surrounding city streets with their own diamond-sprinkle of lights.

LEAD: With the Mets allowing the Pirates to be in a pennant race, how can I find the time to follow the Olympics leadup? Hopefully by the time the Olympics take place in September, the Mets will have clinched the National League East, and I'll be able to concentrate on Carl Lewis, et al, for a few weeks.

LEAD: FOR busy Connecticut people with no time to go grocery shopping, drop off and pick up dry cleaning, walk the dog or arrange an elaborate dinner party, a core of small-errand businesses is at hand.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WEBSTER'S defines propaganda as deception or distortion. Usually it is gross and unsubtle. The propaganda stamps printed by both the Axis and the Allies in World War II were among the most gross.

LEAD: While vacationing recently in Vail, Colo., Kirk Bloede, a New York investment banker, decided to phone home. Using his A.T.&T. credit card, he completed the call from a pay phone in a tavern, and as he said later, ''I thought no more about it.''

LEAD: Shelby LaMotte, a landscape designer, and James Michael Giannone, a landscape foreman, both at Leisure Life Gardens in Essex Junction, Vt., were married yesterday at the Pound Ridge (N.Y.) Community Church by the Rev. Richard Monkman. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. LaMotte of Bedford, N.Y.
LEAD: THIS summer's dollar rally caught most forecasters and traders by surprise and it certainly got the attention of many corporate executives. But not for long.

LEAD: The mass of hot, dirty air that has lingered over much of the country this summer increased ozone pollution in many cities to the highest levels this decade, according to preliminary readings from government monitoring stations.

LEAD: THE gulf between word processing programs and desktop publishing systems has been getting narrower in recent months, and the recent introduction of Wordperfect version 5.0 brings the two classes of software even closer together.
LEAD: The sky was clear, the sun shimmered invitingly on the water and temperatures were in the 90's, but most beachgoers did not go swimming yesterday at Rockaway Beach.

LEAD: President Reagan renewed his plea for Congressional support of rebels in Nicaragua today and linked a top official of the country's Government with the illicit drug trade.

LEAD: EVER since February, when the Pillsbury Company's board forced chief executive John M. Stafford to resign, Pillsbury-watchers on and off Wall Street have been debating who the next chief of the floundering Minneapolis-based food and restaurant giant would be. Several logical contenders are said to have turned down the job.

LEAD: As a believer in the conservation of our natural resources, I have always been enthusiastic about the benefits of recycling empty bottles and cans. So it was a sad day recently when I nearly gave in to the temptation to simply throw away my returns rather than go through what was turning out to be an exasperating procedure for a cleaner environment.

LEAD: THE Kouros Sculpture Center in Ridgefield, is still a work in progress and at 14, the number of artists is pretty much the same as it was when the reviewer visited two years ago. Three of the names are new, though, and thecollection, seemingly larger, has settled into the hundred rolling acres at its disposal.
LEAD: In a decidedly non-Super Bowl setting, the Jets' third-stringers outlasted the Redskins' third-stringers, 49-41, in the teams' annual scrimmage today.

LEAD: A pledge to manage rather than quickly sell more than $1 billion in foreclosed real estate held by the First Republicbank Corporation was key to the regulators' decision to allow the NCNB Corporation to acquire the ailing Texas banking company, the chairman of NCNB said today.
LEAD: THERE were fears of an environmental catastrophe when a barge containing 394,000 gallons of heavy oil sank in a pristine area of Rosario Strait, near Anacortes, Wash.

LEAD: Frank Cooley's law office in the center of Meeker, Colo., faces a sandstone bluff on the edge of the Piceance Creek Basin, an area geologists say contains the richest oil-shale deposit in the world.

LEAD: Since entering first grade in 1930 until my recent retirement as a professor of English, I have twirled about in six decades of education fads. Some of these hoola hoops were productive, some regrettable, some destructive - but all were well-intentioned. And in each decade the educators were absolutely certain that they at last had the correct philosophy.

LEAD: William Bolcom began his ''Twelve New Etudes'' for piano - the works that won him this year's Pulitzer Prize for music - in 1977, and almost didn't complete them. ''I was composing them for Paul Jacobs,'' he explained in a telephone interview the day the Pulitzer was announced, ''but by the time I had completed the first nine of the 12, Paul had become ill and could no longer play them.

Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony.

LEAD: In the South, as in many parts of the United States, regional cooking has given way to Chinese, Japanese and Mexican takeout, nouvelle French or what passes for it, and almost anything but what transplanted Virginians and Carolinians will tell you was standard fare in their childhood kitchens or the dining room of the local hotel.

LEAD: The Fleas Wore Guccis WHILE most eyes were focused on the horses, Gloria Deal's were focused on the 100 percent wool handwoven sweater-jacket for $368. ''I think this may be too bulky,'' she said as she emerged from the cramped paddock-area dressing room. ''Do you think I can carry it?''

LEAD: SKULLDUGGERY, by Peter Marks. (Carroll & Graf, $4.50.) For years amateur historians have tried to discover who perpetrated the hoax of the Piltdown man by planting the bones that tricked anthropologists into believing they had found the missing link. Last year, our reviewer, Patrick McGrath, said the imaginary solution offered in this novel was unconvincing but that Peter Marks ''displays a masterly grasp of the scientific subtleties [ and ] an extensive familiarity with the lives and works of the famous men who grace his pages.
LEAD: Because he suffers from Morquio's syndrome, a disease that makes the body grow too quickly, 12-year-old Steven Vasquez of the Bronx must use crutches.

LEAD: Jamaican Rastafarian culture, represented by Andrew Tosh and Judy Mowatt, made its way to New York on Wednesday night. At S.O.B.'s, both Mr. Tosh and Ms. Mowatt mixed Rastafarian songs with pop tunes; the contradictions between the asceticism of the religious compositions and the unabashed desire to entertain bothered neither the musicians nor the packed audience.

LEAD: Both men and women can make one shirt look like several with button covers that snap over standard buttons. Fifty different styles, selling for $20 to $60 in pairs or sets of six, have been introduced by Linda McDowell and her Los Angeles-based company, Click It, since last fall.

LEAD: It was late afternoon on a tributary of the Amazon, muggy and still, and eight of us in a rubberized Zodiac inflatable boat were heading upstream in search of we knew not what. The whine of the outboard motor seemed an intrusion.

LEAD: One might think, from a glance at Renata Rainer's coming lecture schedule, that the accomplished photographer, art historian and teacher had hung up her camera, spilled out her darkroom chemicals and turned her lab into a library.

LEAD: When Robert B. Parker came out with ''The Godwulf Manuscript'' in 1974, it was immediately apparent that an important contributor to the private-eye genre had appeared. Mr. Parker's hero, Spenser, a Boston detective, was big and tough, yet literate - and a gourmet cook to boot. Some splendid books ensued.

LEAD: FOR too many months, it seems, Fidel Castro has been hearing echoes in Cuba about the virtues of changes that have been sweeping the Soviet Union, his economic and military supporter for nearly 30 years.

LEAD: In 1936, Duke Ellington began taking members of his orchestra into the studio to make small-group recordings that appeared under their names, but under his direction. The pieces he constructed, riff by riff, melody by melody, solo by solo, are some of the most brilliant music America has produced.

LEAD: Atrists heading home from the recent American Psychiatric Association convention in Montreal. As it lumbered down the runway, I felt, as I always do in planes, the stunning sensation of no sensation at all: no fear. I used to be terrified of flying.

LEAD: AT night I dreamed of flying. Not on one particular night, but every night. One night I was chasing the Red Baron above the trenches of the Western Front, the next I was an owl soaring from tree to tree.

LEAD: NOBODY would expect a student who has not mastered arithmetic to solve a calculus problem or one who cannot spell to write an editorial. The same is true in bridge: A non-expert is most unlikely to make an expert play.

LEAD: IF there is a silvery glint in the eyes of music sellers and listeners, it is the reflection of millions of compact disks being popped into compact disk players. About seven million compact disk players have been sold since 1983, the year they were introduced. Over the past five years they have been selling better than video cassette recorders, of which 1.1 million were sold from 1983 through 1987, according to Link Resources, a New York-based market research group.

LEAD: The engagement of Diedre Anderson Maclean to William Woodard Granger 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Granger Jr. of Norfolk, Va., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alan C. Maclean of New York, parents of the bride-to-be.

How can you account for this? -L. B. H., Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Answer: It looks as though lack of demand has forestalled attempts to run group tours to the Stratford Festival from New York.

LEAD: In a nation where soldiers are everywhere, the South Korean Olympic team is going to boot camp.

LEAD: Cliches are the mother's milk of political rhetoric, and the battle for the best of them in this election year is heating up.

LEAD: A CROQUET set, Lorna R. Cameron thought. Yes, a croquet set would be an inspired house gift for the weekend she was invited to her friends' new place in the Poconos. There, she was led to believe, she would find a lovely green ''English-type rolling lawn'' in front of the house.

LEAD: IN recent months, holders of the American Express card have seen a change in their billing statements. In the past, the bills came with a bulky packet of paper receipts of purchases. Today those slips have been supplanted by neat laser-printed sheets containing as many as eight reduced images of the original receipts on a single page.

LEAD: IN this seaside resort, the last of five textile mills closed earlier this year, and the century-old wooden structure will soon be converted to an inn, retail shops and offices.

LEAD: Enrique Camarena, a Federal drug agent slain while investigating a narcotics ring in Mexico, died a barbaric death in a torture chamber, a prosecutor said in his opening statement in the trial of three Mexican nationals charged in the case.

LEAD: TOWARD THE end of a steamy afternoon at the United States Olympic track and field trials in Indianapolis two weeks ago, Jackie Joyner-Kersee listened intently as her coach and husband, Bob Kersee, talked about the 200-meter sprint, her next task in the seven-event, two-day heptathlon. Run the curve as if it were the straightaway, her coach told her, and the straightaway will take care of itself.

LEAD: Research into chemical and biological weapons could be dangerous to surrounding communities, according to a safety review, but the Pentagon said Thursday that its precautions were enough to protect against accidents.

LEAD: LONG RIDE BACK. By John Jacob. (Thunder's Mouth, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95.) If you want to know what it felt like in the Vietnam War to itch and to sweat, to fear and to kill, the poet John Jacob's first novel will give it to you straight - too straight, perhaps. ''Long Ride Back'' provides a lot of action, but not much reflection.

LEAD: In the Navy of the 21st century, submerged submarines will be able to shoot at airplanes, stealth fighters that evade radar will be flown from aircraft carriers and laser beams will protect warships, according to the chief of naval operations, Adm. Carlisle A. H. Trost.
