LEAD: LONG RIDE BACK. By John Jacob. (Thunder's Mouth, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95.) If you want to know what it felt like in the Vietnam War to itch and to sweat, to fear and to kill, the poet John Jacob's first novel will give it to you straight - too straight, perhaps. ''Long Ride Back'' provides a lot of action, but not much reflection.

LEAD: THOSE WISHING TO find His Majesty Mohammad Zahir Shah must negotiate a series of country lanes in a wedge of suburban Rome that is still mostly pasture and forest. Since he was overthrown in 1973, the former King of Afghanistan has accepted the genteel irrelevance of a deposed monarch - living quietly in Rome, confining his plotting to the bright red display of his electronic chess game.

LEAD: Offering his own suggestion as to why the third President remained wholly preoccupied with building himself a house for nearly all of his long life, Jack McLaughlin says that the creation of Monticello might have been a form of adult play. In the light of his entrancing study of the bricks-and-mortar Thomas Jefferson, this is not at all a farfetched conclusion.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration and people who usually oppose arms sales to Arab countries are negotiating a compromise that would permit the United States to sell $1.9 billion worth of warplanes, missiles and bombs to Kuwait.
LEAD: Communities need to broaden their ''safety nets'' of services to cope with a rising number of suicides among psychiatric outpatients, a state mental health commission said this week.

LEAD: For the better part of an hour last Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Judge Leonard B. Sand seemed to be weighing alternative sanctions in his two-year effort to force Yonkers to comply with a housing-desegregation plan.

LEAD: When the end of World War I was announced, 10-year-old Louis Albert Taube climbed into the driver's seat of a horse-drawn fire engine, pulled the steam whistle and decided he was going to be a fireman.

LEAD: In the Navy of the 21st century, submerged submarines will be able to shoot at airplanes, stealth fighters that evade radar will be flown from aircraft carriers and laser beams will protect warships, according to the chief of naval operations, Adm. Carlisle A. H. Trost.

LEAD: Albertson $247,000 45 Woodhollow Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, family room, basement, attic; taxes $2,500. Brightwaters $299,000 285 Windsor Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 67-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, sun porch, 3-car garage; taxes $5,600.

LEAD: The marriage of Sarah Elizabeth Aldrich, a daughter of Mrs. Charles D. Aldrich of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Aldrich, to Stephen Sheals Murray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Murray of Morristown, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge.
LEAD: WE CAN ALL agree: the 1988 Democratic National Convention was Michael S. Dukakis's.
LEAD: FINAL WARNING The Legacy of Chernobyl. By Robert Peter Gale and Thomas Hauser. 230 pp. New York: Warner Books. $18.95.

LEAD: If you were to go to the Museum of Broadcasting this week to watch and listen to all its television and radio programs end to end, without sleeping, you would not finish by the time the museum moves to its new building on West 52d Street, two years from now. This preposterous suggestion is only meant to hint at the magnitude of the museum's latest undertaking: Tomorrow, to coincide with the construction of the building, the Museum of

LEAD: Click, click, click. Mark Bellarmie kept snapping his camera, capturing the Pro Football Hall of Fame's silver anniversary fanfare that provided some golden moments today when Fred Biletnikoff, Mike Ditka, Jack Ham and Alan Page were enshrined.

LEAD: Heidi Lawrence Winslow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Laverack Winslow of Essex, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen Mirick Butts, the son of Joan Foster Butts of Weston and Chatham, Mass., and the late M. Parker Butts. The Rev. George I. Hunter performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Emmanuel Church in Manchester,

LEAD: What disappointed me with Ms. Dolan's article was the absence of the other side of the story. Can women make a difference, not only in changing management styles, but also in broadening the definition of news? I say yes on both counts.

LEAD: HOSPITALS around the state, which alone cannot handle the expense of buying some of the most modern, and expensive, health-care equipment, are forming partnerships to buy or lease the material jointly. Purchasing such advanced equipment can cost about $2 million an item. A pact has been announced for the first lithotripter in the state.

LEAD: Not so long ago, Union City, N.J., was the only community between the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels that had not seen a great deal of residential construction and conversion. While nearby cities like Weehawken and Hoboken have sprouted new condominiums and cooperatives whose marketing is directed at New York City across the harbor, landlocked Union City seemed to remain insular, concentrating on its own commercial districts along Bergenline Avenue and Kennedy Boulevard.

LEAD: WHAT SHOULD WE DO ABOUT DAVEY? By Julius Fast. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) Oh, the trials of Davey Quinn, that good-looking, sexually obsessed, socially inept 16-year-old. Older women invite him in for cake and cookies -and seduce him. Big brother Sam is forever telling him he's a slouch. Even Dad, hoping for the best for his son, is heartbroken as Davey bungles another after-school job (caught sleeping with the librarian this time).

LEAD: As a professional woman and (formerly) the first national coordinator for women's health of the National Organization for Women, I have to agree, sadly though, with Mary Anne Dolan's observations of women today in the marketplace. But as a sociologist, I disagree strongly with what I see as her conclusion that the increased presence of women in the work place is the causal factor for the American romance with power and greed.

LEAD: One architect's presence hovers over all of the sprawling exhibition, ''Chicago Architecture 1872-1922: Birth of a Metropolis'' that has just opened at the Art Institute of Chicago. It is not Louis Sullivan or Daniel Burnham or even Frank Lloyd Wright, prominent though they all are in this show. None of these great men of history holds a position here quite equal to that of Stanley Tigerman, the

LEAD: On Friday evening, May 20, Barbara Mezo zipped up her son's Yankees jacket, gave her daughter a little white stuffed bear and sent them off for a weekend visit with their father, Abdelaziz Elmergawi, an Egyptian physician.

LEAD: As a mariachi band struck up ''The King'' and loyal political supporters waved banners proclaiming him to be ''a man who lost his freedom but not his dignity,'' Jorge Diaz Serrano emerged from prison this morning, five years to the day after he was first jailed on charges of defrauding Mexico's state oil monopoly of $34 million in an elaborate kickback scheme.

LEAD: NOT every restaurant makes its own desserts and salad dressings. Bruce's in Wainscott does. Still fewer bake bread, churn ice cream and roll fresh pasta. Bruce's does all five, plus makes sausages; smokes fish; sun-dries tomatoes; cooks up batches of jam, jelly and chutney and even ketchup.

LEAD: OLD-FASHIONED double-hung windows, found mostly in homes built before World War II, depend on heavy counterweights to allow the sashes to be raised and to prevent them from sliding downward when released.
LEAD: Former Representative Barbara Jordan was hospitalized in critical condition today after she was found unconscious in a swimming pool at her home, the authorities said.

LEAD: Elizabeth Ann Daley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Daley 3d of New Haven and Rye Beach, N.H., was married yesterday in Rye Beach to John Richard Ward, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ward of Darwen, Lancashire, England. The Revs. Thomas R. Hennigan and Gordon R. Allen performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St.
LEAD: The Capezio Ballet Makers Dance Foundation has awarded a total of $85,000 in grants to 71 regional and national dance organizations for community and social projects and performances.

LEAD: Martin Lowenfish of the Yonkers Canoe club canoeing on the Hudson Rover. The club is to compete today at the Atlantic Division championship at Harriman State Park and at the Empire State Games in August. (NYT/Suzanne DeChillo)

LEAD: It has been 20 years since an impish-looking boy with dark eyes, curly hair and an infectious grin was chosen from hundreds of Soviet children by the director Alexander Askoldov to play the leading child in his 1967 film, ''Commissar.'' No sooner was the film finished than it was banned by the authorities for its frank treatment of Soviet anti

LEAD: FOR years, scientists who wanted to do research involving human embryos and fetuses have found themselves in a Catch-22 situation. They could do their work with impunity, and receive Federal funds for it, so long as an ethics advisory board approved their proposals. The catch is that the board does not exist, and has not for nearly a decade.

LEAD: IT was high tide on a Sunday afternoon and the fishermen were lined up along Bayville's beach. The swimming season had not yet begun, and out-of-towners were still welcome. There is something reassuring about a group of men standing or sitting quietly at the waterfront, attending to their fishing rods with calm, deliberate motions, ignoring the passage of time.

LEAD: CONSTRUCTION has begun on a $40 million residential and commercial development adjacent to the Kings Bay Naval Submarine Base in anticipation of rapid growth in the coastal area of southern Georgia and northern Florida.

LEAD: MANDELA Starring Danny Glover, Alfre Woodard (in photo), Warren Clarke, John Indi, John Matshikizia, Nathan Dambuza Mdledle. Directed by Philip Saville. 1987. HBO Video. 135 minutes. $79.99. Not Rated.

LEAD: To the Editor: Ray Warners's letter (Travel, May 29) expressing disappointment due to unfufilled promises from Intourist during a Soviet tour is no surprise to anyone who has been there. The Intourist attitude is arrogant and often misleading.

LEAD: A LITERARY essay published in the Middle East in 1952 created a stir among Arab intellectuals for its description of an empty cloak of leadership waiting to be placed on some hero somewhere in the vast, leaderless world of Islam.

LEAD: After spending just one night in the Albany County Jail, the Rev. Al Sharpton was released on bail yesterday pending appeal of his 15-day sentence for disorderly conduct during a demonstration on behalf of Tawana Brawley in April.

LEAD: A NEW match is being made of compact disks and computers. It's called CD-ROM, for ''compact disk-read only memory'' and it can drastically increase the storage capacity of a computer. A CD-ROM is a 5 1/4-inch laser disk that contains the same amount of information as 1,200 floppy disks.
LEAD: The Communist leadership ended a meeting today with a threat to take tougher action against unrest in the southern province of Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians are demanding greater autonomy.

LEAD: The concept of the Olympics celebrating the promotion of peace and understanding through international amateur-athletic competition, has disappeared. During the past five Olympics, including 1988, the Olympics have been reduced to a forum for politics, professionalism, nationalism and terrorism, all elements contrary to the spirit of the
LEAD: At the height of Texas's late great boom, all roads led here to the overheated oil town that defined the state in the 1970's.

LEAD: Venice offers such extraordinary works of art in diverse settings that even the most ambitious sightseer must make choices. For those who appreciate viewing art in the context of history, three museums will provide insight into the development of this island city. These are the Correr Museum in the Piazza San Marco, the Museum of the Venetian 18th Century in Ca' Rezzonico on the Grand Canal, and the Naval Museum near the Arsenal, at the eastern end of the city.

LEAD: UNTIL recently, the 115-acre property in Litchfield County on which Winthrop Hill, a stately mansion, sits was to be subdivided for houses. Instead, the mansion will be used by Combustion Engineering Inc. of Stamford as a corporate education and hospitality center and the land and outbuildings will remain intact.

LEAD: In a land where weather vanes are akin to crown jewels, city leaders and firefighters here are at odds over a gilded prize that caught the winds of New Hampshire's capital city for roughly a century.
LEAD: While King John prepares for a summer stint in Central Park, the City University of New York is planning some Shakespeare of its own.

LEAD: At St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge, Mass., Anne Robertson Dowden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald S. Dowden of Islip, L.I., was married yesterday to Franz Ferdinand Colloredo-Mansfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Colloredo-Mansfeld of Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. John E. MacInnis performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Jean-Paul Bourelly opened a blues show at the Central Park Band Shell on July 23 with a version of Memphis Slim's ''Mother Earth.'' Mr. Bourelly, who is one of the most exciting young guitarists in New York, owes a lot to Jimi Hendrix, not so much in his improvising as in his group conception and his singing.

LEAD: Alice Chasan, a daughter of the late Harriet and Raymond Chasan of Jersey City, and Jeffrey Charles Kanige, the son of Mr. and Mrs. and Charles Kanige of Center Moriches, L.I., were married yesterday in Princeton, N.J. Mayor Barbara Boggs Sigmund of Princeton Borough performed the ceremony in her office at Borough Hall.
LEAD: An article last Sunday about an Austrian move to consider full membership in the European Community misidentified the Austrian Chancellor. He is Franz Vranitzky.

LEAD: SCORES of people gathered around a small potted evergreen and a much-larger, eight-foot-tall cedar tree last Saturday outside the summer home of Dick and Janet Miller to celebrate ''Christmas in July'' on Cedar Island off Clinton.

LEAD: BY chance I visited three doctors in one day recently - one for a mammography, one to examine a lump on my first rib, and one to X-ray that lump. That meant that I had the opportunity to wear three types of hospital gowns in one day, making me realize that no major changes had occurred in gown design in recent years, despite great progress in so many other areas affecting women.

LEAD: Even at practice, the Indy-style cars whirled around the track sounding more like a swarm of enraged hornets than precision-engineered race cars. Ten-year-old Russell Decker of Clifton covered his ears, his grin a partial grimace. ''Wow, Dad! Did you see that! How fast are they going, how fast?'' Michael Decker, 42, a machinist in Little Falls, shook his head.
LEAD: UPPER MONTCLAIR

LEAD: ''There can no longer be any doubt about the link between diet and disease,'' Surgeon General C. Everett Koop said last week upon release of his encyclopedic ''Report on Nutrition and Health,'' which urged drastic overhaul of America's high-fat diet. But why doesn't Dr. Koop link that authoritative advice to a call for more stringent food labeling rules?

LEAD: Larchmont, N.Y. $510,000 37 Glenn Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 61-year-old stone and stucco English-style house; living room with fireplace, sun room, basement with playroom; taxes $6,442. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $244,900 160 Old Roaring Brook Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, living room with fireplace, attic, 1-car garage, 1.75 acres; taxes $3,824.
LEAD: Black clothes complement nearly every woman's skin. Still, they can make pale complexions look slightly washed out.
LEAD: Barely six weeks after the Oct. 19 stock-market plunge, a new investment brokerage firm here opened its doors for business.
LEAD: Lucille S. Hurley Thompson, a nutrition scholar whose research linked some dietary deficiencies of expectant mothers with birth defects, has died at age 66.
LEAD: Carney Lansford would like to forget three weeks in June. If not for three weeks in July, Tony Gwynn might as well have forgotten the season.
LEAD: New Deck for Building
LEAD: Contract talks between scriptwriters and movie and television producers collapsed today, erasing earlier optimism that weekend negotiations might end the 21-week strike.
LEAD: KENNESAW, Ga., not only lets residents keep a gun in the house; it is against the law not to have one there.

LEAD: THERE is no Cuisinart cookware in Jeffrey and Judy Kalin's kitchen. Or Calphalon, or Teflon, either. Instead, the Kalins prefer to use cooking pots made in the traditional style of the American Indians.

LEAD: If Kamal Meattle has his way, small laminated pouches carrying printed images of deities and filled with sacred water from the Ganges River will replace the traditional brass and aluminum containers used to sell sacred water.

LEAD: Roy Orbison, who played at Pier 84 Wednesday night, got right to the point: he opened his show with his hit ''Only the Lonely,'' setting the open spaces in the tune's arrangement ringing with his quivering, over-ripe falsetto.

LEAD: An article and a headline on July 10 about the marriage of Marianne Carroll Jones and William Smithers McNee identified the bridegroom incompletely. He is a marketing representative in New York for Comshare, a software company specializing in executive information systems.

LEAD: EFFECTIVE July 1, all permanent Connecticut state employees are entitled to 24 weeks of family leave within any two-year period, upon the birth or adoption of a child or the serious illness of a child, spouse or parent of the employee. A medical leave of absence of 24 weeks is also permissible if the employee should become seriously ill.

LEAD: During his monthly statewide radio program last week, Governor Cuomo defended his plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, making a rare direct emotional plea to the public: ''All you people on Long Island, listen to me.''

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Jordan should continue to take part in any Middle East peace negotiations, even though King Hussein of Jordan has given up his claims to the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
LEAD: The growth rate of the nation's economy slowed slightly in July, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, which is scheduled to be released today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHILE he and his wife were strolling in Manhattan one hot summer evening a few years ago, Leonard Schwartz, the Pittsburgh psychiatrist who invented Heavyhands, spied a runner with the hand weights. But instead of pumping the weights up and down as he ran, the young man was merely carrying them.

LEAD: Swimming heads the list of 40 participant sports in a survey taken in 1987 by the National Sporting Goods Association. More than 66 million Americans took the plunge last year, and swimming was followed in the poll by exercise walking (58.1 million), which drew the most new participants (7.2 million).
LEAD: One man was shot dead and another wounded in a dispute in Times Square early yesterday, the police said. A third man was arrested and was being questioned about the shootings.

LEAD: AGB Television Research, which took on the A. C. Nielsen Company in a costly war for the business of measuring the American television audience, has surrendered and will suspend its ratings operation in the United States.
LEAD: A woman who won $5 million in a Canadian lottery in 1984 has had her house seized for back taxes and has been arrested and accused of plotting to kill her daughter-in-law.

LEAD: Watching the New York City Opera's current production of ''La Traviata'' on Saturday evening at the New York State Theater, I couldn't help wondering who the company imagines its audience to be. Directed by Frank Corsaro, the production is a superficially traditional look at the Verdi opera, with sets and costumes that are a mismatched, historic pastiche, and with blocking that is unlikely to awaken new insight into the characters for operagoers acquainted with the work.

LEAD: The United States has received a private response to American messages sent to Iran, Administration officials said today, and Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated his willingness to meet with Iran's Foreign Minister if the Iranians asked for such a meeting.

LEAD: American Samoa's delegate to the House of Representatives and his administrative assistant conspired to defraud the Government of more than $130,000 and will plead guilty of the offense, the United States Attorney's office has announced.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued subpoenas to the R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company of Chicago in the expanding inquiry into stock trading apparently based on leaks of information in Business Week magazine, people familiar with the investigation said yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When Brian Friesen was driving to work last Monday in the Vancouver, British Columbia, suburb of New Westminster, a radio news report quickened his pulse. In trading in Toronto the Canadian dollar had reversed its steep climb of the previous months against the United States currency and tumbled nearly a full United

LEAD: Jack Morris won for the first time since June 27, and Dwayne Murphy had two hits and scored the winning run on his first day with the Tigers as Detroit beat the Texas Rangers today, 5-1. It was the sixth victory in seven games for Detroit.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Dodgers put Fernando Valenzuela on the 21-day disabled list today, and the 27-year-old left-hander will miss his turn in the rotation for the first time in his eight-year career.

LEAD: The Teamsters and Basic Crafts Unions have agreed to extend their contract with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers on a day-to-day basis. The contract with studio drivers, plumbers, electricians, plasterers and laborers was to have expired at midnight Sunday. A joint statement released Sunday afternoon said negotiations would resume Wednesday, ''with the expectation of negotiating to conclusion.

LEAD: DONNY LALONDE carries a gym bag, not a brief case, when he goes to work. He eschews three-piece suits and ties in favor of sweatpants and 10-ounce gloves. While others might punch computer keys, LaLonde earns his living punching opponents.

LEAD: Broderick Montgomery, an 18-year-old with a gold tooth in his smile and a baseball cap on his head, walked into a youth employment agency in Brooklyn recently looking for a job. Mr. Montgomery, a 10th-grade dropout with no skills to speak of, said he wanted to earn $5.50 or $6 an hour, maybe ''lifting boxes.
LEAD: Because of the crabbed, resentful public attitude toward paying public servants, voting themselves a raise can be hazardous to the political health of senators and representatives.
LEAD: With a rescue plan finally in place at the First Republicbank Corporation, bank regulators have removed one of the darkest clouds over the United States banking system.

LEAD: Heidi-Rachel Webb, a daughter of Dr. Gertrude Mikels Webb and J. Chester Webb of Waltham, Mass., was married in the garden of her parents' home yesterday to Dr. Andrew Millard Singer, the son of Lucille Singer of Stamford, Conn., and the late Edwin Singer. Rabbi Herman Blumberg performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Koch administration officials are split over a draft proposal to require all candidates for police, fire, sanitation and certain other ''public safety'' jobs to disclose if they have received a diagnosis of AIDS or AIDS-related complex.

LEAD: If any company represents the new wave in European industry, it is probably European Silicon Structures. For a host of reasons, many industrialists point to this computer chip maker as a model for what European companies should become as the European Community prepares to end all of its internal trade barriers in 1992.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Former Representative Barbara Jordan was ''vastly improved,'' her doctor said today, a day after she nearly drowned in her swimming pool.
LEAD: Residents clashed with the police early yesterday morning in an East Village park that has come to symbolize the neighborhood's resistance to gentrification.
LEAD: Harvey Mandlin and one of his salespeople, Marc Marshall, were discussing a business deal: as much as 1.2 million pounds of frozen Australian goat meat was up for sale on the West Coast, cheap.
LEAD: Forget Michael S. Dukakis. If this town voted today, Joe Morgan would be president.

LEAD: High demand for workers because of rapid economic growth pushed Japan's unemployment rate down to 2.4 percent in June, its lowest level in 67 months, the Government announced Friday. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for June was a tenth of a percentage point lower than in May and sixth-tenths of a percentage point below the previous year's level, the Management and Coordination Agency said.
LEAD: King Hussein of Jordan tonight abandoned to the Palestine Liberation Organization any claim to the Israeli-occupied West Bank his Hashemite family ruled between 1948 and 1967.

LEAD: Today's regular weekly Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills heads a light calendar of new offerings. On Wednesday, the Treasury is scheduled to announce the terms of its mid-quarter refunding auctions, which would be held next week.
LEAD: The striking gold dome of the State House has long been the architectural focus of this smallest of capital cities.
LEAD: Of every 30 people sentenced to death since the death penalty was reinstated by the Supreme Court in 1976, 10 left death row and one was executed, the Justice Department said today.

LEAD: The game is almost six months away, nobody knows which teams will be playing in it, and the tickets haven't even been printed. Even so, football fans with a little bit of foresight and a whole lot of wherewithal are reserving their seats for the 1989 Super Bowl at Joe Robbie Stadium in Miami next Jan.

LEAD: In recent years, the Polish Government official who has dealt most intensively with the Reagan Administration has been Foreign Minister Marian Orzechowski, and on Friday, at the conclusion of five days of meetings here, he remarked that there had been ''certain progress'' toward normal relations.

LEAD: For more than 20 years Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, under its various guises, has handled assignments from the Nestle Foods Corporation. Now it has been tapped to work for Nestle Enterprises' newly formed subsidiary, the Fresnes Corporation, based in Solon, Ohio, which will begin testing a line of grocery products next month.
LEAD: It was only a scrimmage against the Super Bowl champions, but the Jets' defensive problems couldn't have been more evident.

LEAD: * China's ability to pay back its $20 billion to $30 billion external debt was rated ''satisfactory'' by Standard & Poor's. It was the first time the rating service had evaluated the country's debt. The rating corresponds to the lower third of S.&P.'s investment-grade category. The rating was influenced by China's economic changes over the past decade, in which market forces have replaced some central planning.

LEAD: TAXES seldom take a holiday. Indeed, one of the intentions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was to halt such perceived abuses as tax breaks for schoolteachers, who, having spent some time in summer strolling down the Champs-Elysees, claimed an educational-travel deduction for their newly acquired aplomb and panache.

LEAD: Orel Hershiser pitched a five-hitter today to become the National League's second 15-game winner and John Shelby had a two-run single as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated Houston, 6-1, to snap the Astros' four-game winning streak.

LEAD: Amy Diane Rosenbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Robert Rosenbaum of Los Angeles, was married there yesterday to Daniel R. Jacobson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Jacobson of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Leonard Beerman performed the ceremony at the Regency Club.

LEAD: Calling negotiations with Hollywood's 9,000 striking writers ''hopelessly deadlocked,'' the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said today that the talks with the Writers Guild of America in the 22-week strike were permanently ended.

LEAD: The presence of the general manager gave the weekend a sense of urgency, as if the Yankees were feeling the need to make a deal. But Bob Quinn said today he was merely here to meet with Lou Piniella and discuss the state of the pitching staff. There was a lot to talk about. With one pitcher disabled, two others hurting and another in the minors with a sore elbow, the Yankees are suddenly strapped for strong arms.

LEAD: The New York City Correction Department could save $1.25 million a year by hiring 145 full-time correction officers and by establishing permanent hospital duty posts for them, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said in an audit released yesterday.
LEAD: Considering the condition of their pitching staff, the Yankees felt a collective sense of relief today.

LEAD: Bank Outlook Brightens A plan to rescue First Republicbank of Dallas removes the darkest cloud over the banking system. News analysis, page D1. The War Over Shoreham A battle of rare political intensity is raging on Long Island over the agreement to shut the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

LEAD: The Congressional Budget Office has warned Congress that it may soon face a choice between reducing the size of the armed forces or making them less ready for combat because operational and support funds are being held down in favor of buying more arms.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Greg Walker, the Chicago White Sox first baseman, suffered a second seizure this morning, but was stabilized without further complications, club officials announced.
LEAD: For centuries the diplomatic pouch has guarded the confidentiality of official messages exchanged between governments and their envoys stationed abroad.

LEAD: In a ceremony that seemed as inevitable as one of his extra-base hits, Willie Stargell completed his journey from rookie to renown today, becoming the 200th man to be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

LEAD: James (Buddy) McGirt retained his International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title when he knocked out Howard Davis yesterday at 2 minutes 45 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 15-round bout at the Felt Forum.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The euphoria of attempts by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to revive Soviet society, the intoxicating swirl of political debate and cultural experimentation, seems each month more in danger from the mundane miseries of the unyielding Soviet economy.

LEAD: Movie maker Steven Spielberg, now in England filming ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' has embarked on a crusade of his own. With the help of British and American investors, he is trying to prevent Britain's legendary Elstree Studios from being razed for commercial development.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from King Hussein's address today, as translated from the Arabic by The Associated Press:
LEAD: West Germany outdistanced the United States as the world's biggest exporter for the second year in a row, according to the International Monetary Fund.
LEAD: * Marc Goldstein has joined Lintas:USA as senior vice president, director of national broadcast media and programming, for both Lintas:New York and Lintas:Campbell-Ewald.

LEAD: With a conservatism born of adversity and an apparent resistance to pressure to quicken the pace, space agency managers and engineers are moving gingerly in preparing for the first flight of a space shuttle since the Challenger disaster two and a half years ago.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: For Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos's New York office, last week was one of those in-and-out kind of times so typical of the give-and-take agency business.

LEAD: Dr. Lucille S. Hurley Thompson, a nutrition scholar whose research linked some dietary deficiencies of expectant mothers with birth defects, died after open-heart surgery Thursday at a Sacramento hospital. She was 66 years old.
LEAD: AFTER more than 55 years of catching everything from giant bluefin tuna to tiny brook trout, I know that I will never become a consistently successful angler.
LEAD: Seven years ago, Ashby Harper, who was 65 years old, told a friend that he planned to swim across the English Channel.

LEAD: Andrea Bass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin L. Bass of New York, was married yesterday to James J. Glickson, the son of David Glickson of St. Paul and the late Sarae Glickson. Rabbi Henry Glazer performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

LEAD: Italy's top anti-Mafia prosecutor has unexpectedly quit his post, joining a protest by Sicilian law enforcement officials who have accused the Government of hindering their efforts to fight organized crime.

LEAD: A committee in the House of Representatives charged today that the airline industry had failed to hire enough blacks as pilots, as managers or for other positions requiring advanced education and skills.

LEAD: EARLIER this month, in the middle of the three-week ''up front'' period when advertising agencies buy most of their network time for the new television season on behalf of their largest clients, Young & Rubicam issued a forecast consistent with those of the rest of Madison Avenue. ''We do not see any innovative or 'breakthrough' hits among the crop of new shows,'' it said, ''either in program type, content or rating success.

LEAD: The Robert V. Goldstein Award for Distinguished Service as an Advertising Council Campaign Director has been established by the Association of National Advertisers, of which he was chairman, and the Advertising Council, of which he was a director. It honors the memory of a man who was among the advertising men killed in the tragic white-water rafting accident a year ago in British

LEAD: The new Philadelphia office of Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson will be handling the central Pennsylvania McDonald's co-op, made up of 53 restaurants. The ad budget is $2 million, bringing the office to $12 million.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he has accepted a request from Governor Cuomo to try to make peace with Mayor Koch, whose sharp attacks on Mr. Jackson dominated the New York primary in April.

LEAD: The Federal racketeering law, created to help fight organized crime, is now being used primarily by private individuals and corporations trying to extract large damage awards from legitimate businesses.
LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 1, 1988: MONDAY

LEAD: Dave Archer sped into the end zone with 1 minute 28 seconds remaining to give the Miami Dolphins a 27-21 victory over the San Francisco 49ers in an National Football League preseason game at Wembley Stadium tonight.

LEAD: In the treaty eliminating Soviet and American intermediate-range missiles, the iron law of negotiation was demonstrated once again: The side in a hurry makes the concessions. Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in a hurry; President Reagan was not. So Mr. Gorbachev made the concessions and agreed to a treaty that he and his three predecessors had denounced as a wicked ploy to achieve American military superiority.

LEAD: The marriage of Felice Sarah Locker and Robert Henry Fenwick-Smith, who both received M.B.A. degrees in June from Harvard University, took place yesterday at the Richmond County Country Club in Todt Hill, S.I. Cantor David Benedict and the Rev. Peter Brennan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: RON DARLING, cover boy for men's apparel magazines and family newspapers and Ivy League periodicals, appeared instead yesterday as if he should be featured on the cover of Tales From the Crypt. He was dressed to kill, more or less. He went out to the mound with baseball cap yanked at a serious, not to say sinister, level to his eyes, his knickers at close to an all-time unfashionable low to his baseball shoes and with a facial stubble that had not felt the scrape of a razor in six days.
LEAD: Ask Albert Wimmer what he thinks about changing the name of the South Bronx, and he'll say, ''That's like trying to change the name of a fish.''

LEAD: Although 98 percent of House members have been returned to office in recent elections, some contests do make a difference. One primary race this year already appears critical to the fate of the legislation requiring large employers to give 60 days' notice of a plant closing or large-scale layoff.
LEAD: At a time when bicycle thieves are able to break through the toughest of locks, the idea of a folding bicycle - one that you can carry with you - begins to make sense.

LEAD: Tennis Agassi Wins in Vermont: Andre Agassi won his fifth Nabisco Grand Prix singles title of the year yesterday, defeating Paul Annacone, 6-2, 6-4, at the Volvo International in Stratton Mountain, Vt. Agassi, 18, seeded second, used a powerful forehand passing shot and a backhand lob to earn $114,000.

LEAD: Dr. Joanna Lisa Fine, a child psychiatrist, and Stephen Michael Harnik, a lawyer, who graduated together from the Dalton School in 1971 were married yesterday at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Jerome Raik, the president of Ansche Chesed Congregation in Manhattan, officiated.
LEAD: Grey Advertising, Young & Rubicam and Biederman & Company announced new assignments last week.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Meryl Ilene Stone and Michael H. Cohen were married last evening at the Short Hills, a catering establishment in Short Hills, N.J., by Rabbi Irving Block.

LEAD: Across the New York metropolitan region this summer, health experts are reporting a surge of concern about Lyme disease, a vexing and potentially crippling illness that is spread by a tiny tick.

LEAD: All of Wagner's mature operas are ghost ships, fated to sail about the world in search of the ultimately convincing interpretation. Vain voyages. For any important work there is no final port to be reached, at least not while the culture that produced it survives. Certainly there is life enough left in ''Der Fliegende Hollander,'' Wagner's first great experiment in psychological music drama.

LEAD: The marriage of Bonnie Lee Reid, the daughter of the late Patricia Lee Reid and the late Harry Emery Snook, both of Charlotte, N.C., to David Bokman, a son of Salomon Bokman and Hilda Aronson, both of New York, took place yesterday. Justice Sondra Miller of State Supreme Court in White Plains officiated at a private home in Pound Ridge, N
LEAD: Placing greater emphasis than ever on their more profitable older books, publishers are reissuing or introducing the works of dead authors with greater regularity.
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: At the age of 5, Richard Williams visited a movie theater in Toronto with his mother and saw ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.'' ''She said I was never the same again,'' recalled Mr. Williams with a laugh. ''It just knocked me out. I said 'That's what I want to do; that's what I have to do.' ''
LEAD: The conversion of Mayor Koch on Northern Ireland was lampooned today in Britain.

LEAD: The House Ways and Means Committee acted wisely when it voted a year's extension of the housing tax-credit program. This useful measure is the only low-rent housing production program still on the books after eight Reagan years. It deserves final approval by the full House and Senate.

LEAD: The opening lines of ''The Journey'' serve as a kind of warning, or, perhaps, a reassurance, depending on your political point of view. Peter Watkins, the British narrator - and co-producer with the Swedish Peace and Arbitration Society - of the 14-hour series on the nuclear arms race, expresses the hope that the viewer will not ''feel there is anything objective about the information I'll give you.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: To Robert Morris, the outlook seemed bleak, despite the hustle and bustle surrounding him on a ramp at the Kansas City International Airport. On Aug. 31 much of that activity will be ended by sharp service cuts announced by Eastern Airlines.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz disputed a report today that two Central American nations opposed a proposed joint communique circulated by the United States that denounced Nicaragua for inviting Soviet-bloc intervention in regional affairs.
LEAD: At a time when the boom in personal computer magazines is thought to be over, the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company is gambling that there is room for one more.
LEAD: Forstmann Little & Company and the Pullman Company have reached a definitive merger agreement under which Pullman would receive about $650 million.

LEAD: Roman Catholic bishops and other church leaders who label a political candidate ''pro-abortion'' or who otherwise praise or condemn those running for public office jeopardize the tax-exempt status of the Catholic Church, according to a Catholic memorandum.

LEAD: It's not easy to stay the course in the Big Apple, and when the founding and sustaining sponsor of the Mobil Big Apple Games decided to move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Fairfax, Va., it sounded like a death knell to the games.

LEAD: Charles Horton, who is 8 years old and will be a third grader at Central Park East School in East Harlem next month, stood on a chair and released a paper cup connected with plastic straws to a small patch of green plastic. It plunged rapidly to the floor.

LEAD: * American Savings and Loan Assn. of Florida, Miami, named as directors Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of a financial services firm, Blackstone Financial Management, and general partner of the Blackstone Group, and Donald M. Kaplan, managing director and a founder partner of the financial consulting firm of Kaplan, Smith & Associates Inc.
LEAD: Arthur Klein, an educator who worked in the New York City public-school system for 50 years, died of cancer Friday night in a Pittsburgh nursing home. He was 90 years old.
LEAD: After analyzing and debating King Hussein's moves to cut his links to the West Bank, neither Israelis nor Palestinians in the occupied territories were quite sure today what to make of it.

LEAD: Anne Alexandra Tyno, the daughter of Marion Tyno of Rye, N.Y., and the late Stephen Tyno, was married yesterday to Jeffrey John Baum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Manfred Baum of Bergenfield, N.J. Rabbi Jerome Blass performed the ceremony at the Fair Lawn (N.J.) Jewish Center.

LEAD: Defying the maxim that liquid assets are the worst defense against inflation, Brazilians with the money and skill to play the local financial markets are profiting handsomely from rocketing prices here.

LEAD: Senate Democrats are preparing legislation that would immediately provide the Nicaraguan rebels with funds for food, clothing and medical supplies and are considering future assistance for arms and ammunition, Congressional staff members said today.

LEAD: QUESTION: If Jim Plunkett doesn't retire, Tim Brown makes the cut, Marcus Allen stays healthy and Bo Jackson joins all three when the baseball season ends, the Los Angeles Raiders will have four Heisman Trophy winners on their squad. Has a team ever had that many before?
LEAD: A 13-year-old Brooklyn girl was fatally shot yesterday when a handgun some youths were playing with discharged and she was struck in the chest, the police said.

LEAD: ''Mushrooms'' - that's the drug gunman's brutal slang for innocent bystanders who pop up unexpectedly in his line of fire. In the past year 10 New Yorkers have been killed and more than 20 wounded by drug criminals' stray bullets, and the lethal fire is hardly unique to New York.

LEAD: Police officer in East Jerusalem standing guard outside the Arab Studies Center, which was ordered closed after the arrest of its director, Faisal Husseini. Mr. Husseini was detained yesterday after meeting with Israeli dissidents in a West Jerusalem theater and calling for direct peace talks between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
LEAD: The preference of Japanese industry for home-grown expansion and its disdain for American-style mergers and acquisitions appear to be changing.

LEAD: Jeb Bush, who is expected to play a major role in helping to court the Hispanic vote for the Presidential campaign of his father, Vice President Bush, tried to have the White House nominate the Cuban-American president of a Florida university as the new Secretary of Education.
LEAD: ''We respect the wish of the P.L.O., the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people to secede from us in an independent Palestinian state.'' - King Hussein of Jordan. [ A1:6. ]

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 King Hussein yielded to the P.L.O. all claims to the West Bank. The action by the Jordanian ruler, whose family ruled the territory from 1948 to 1967, reinforced doubts on an American peace plan. Page A1

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis, determined not to squander the momentum achieved in Atlanta, has become increasingly aggressive in recent days, turning up the heat on both President Reagan and Vice President Bush.

LEAD: Nancy Joan Weiss, the dean of the college and a professor of history at Princeton University, and Burton Gordon Malkiel, the William S. Beinecke Professor of Management Studies and a professor of economics at Yale University, were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel by Rabbi Ely E.

LEAD: ON Thursday afternoon, the fourth day of instruction, it did not appear that anyone would learn how.
LEAD: Agricultural universities and private farm research centers are working with a new urgency on hundreds of projects to help American farmers sustain harvests in droughts.

LEAD: For years television was known as a ''drop dead'' business. Profits rose so predictably that a station manager could drop dead and the station would run itself.

LEAD: Darryl Strawberry leaned back in his chair and said the Pirates had nothing to be ashamed of. Bob Walk sat silently in the trainer's room in the Pittsburgh clubhouse, understanding full well that there was nothing for the Pirates to feel particularly proud of, either.

LEAD: Poppe Tyson, a subsidiary of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, has acquired Williams, London, Marchin, Weltman & Associates, an agency in West Orange, N.J., billing $15 million, and Young & Rubicam has acquired Arthur E. Wilk Inc., a health-care agency in Chicago billing $20 million.
LEAD: Banana Diplomacy The Making of American Policy in Nicaragua 1981-1987. By Roy Gutman 404 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: Recently declassified documents show that Edward Teller had viewed the nuclear X-ray laser, a disputed ''Star Wars'' weapon, as potentially vastly more powerful and flexible than had been discussed publicly.
LEAD: A couple were shot to death as they sat in a parked car in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday in what the police believe were drug-related murders, the police.
LEAD: ''The alliance is run by the Germans,'' said Manfred Worner, breaking into English and a smile. It was just a little joke, and, he acknowledged, hardly true.

LEAD: Loyal readers of Variety, the weekly newspaper of show business, have traditionally opened each issue first to ''the grosses'' - the listing of box-office receipts for movies and plays around the nation. That Pavlovian reflex may have changed of late, because the most dramatic news in the industry now, the struggle with AIDS, is spotlighted on the obituary pages.

LEAD: The Turk Group, which has been part of Kornhauser & Calene, is splitting with the parent company to become part of ABP International.

LEAD: Katie Monahan Prudent of Middleburg, Va., rode Mrs. W. Averell Harriman's The Empress to win the $50,000 Chrysler-Gucci Hampton Classic Grand Prix. The 24-year-old rider edged out Greg Best and Santos, over a shortened second-round course. Jeff Welles was third on Webster, and Christian Currey, fourth, on

LEAD: For years, the outside world thought that gorillas were extinct here. But Jacob Osang and Napoleon Mkpe knew better, and whenever they spied an adult gorilla in the thick rain forest here they saw $200 worth of walking restaurant meat.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The NCNB Corporation is counting on its new stake in the First Republicbank Corporation of Texas to contribute an immediate and steadily rising share of NCNB profits - 38.5 percent by 1994.

LEAD: The Times Mirror Company said a deal to trade its cable television operations in Arizona for cable properties owned by Tele-Communications Inc. and United Artists Communications has collapsed. The decision to call off the deal, which was announced in March and was valued by analysts at about $740 million, ''was a mutual agreement between all three parties,'' Times Mirror, owner of The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and The Baltimore Sun newspapers, said Thursday.
LEAD: There is nothing coy about Kitty Dukakis.

LEAD: A senior member in the pro-Iranian Party of God said today that an American who was supervising a United Nations peacekeeping force was on a spying mission when he was abducted in southern Lebanon last February.

LEAD: Rescue workers in the city of Butterworth, in northwestern Malaysia, carrrying a body from the rubble of a pier which collapsed yesterday on thousands of people waiting for ferries to Penang Island. At least 30 people were killed and more than 300 injured when a section of the structure suddenly gave way.
LEAD: A headline in some copies Saturday, with an article about Japan's new tax plan, misidentified the Japanese Prime Minister. He is Noboru Takeshita.

LEAD: The Bavarian State Opera has always been assiduous in its loyalty to Richard Strauss, who counts as a hometown boy despite his longtime residence in Garmisch in the nearby Alps and his lifelong activity in Vienna, Berlin and beyond.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Quotation of the Day yesterday was misattributed. It was Sister Christine Tan, a nun who lives in a Manila slum, who said: ''I had thought freedom was more important to people than rice, but it isn't. Rice is more important. These people just want to survive, survive, survive.

LEAD: THE baseball exploded off Darryl Strawberry's bat, and when it hit the digital clock in Busch Stadium, time was perhaps the only thing that didn't stand still. Players stopped in their tracks; images were frozen in memories, and an imposing precedent was set.

LEAD: Things are not the way they were when Imelda Marcos was here. As a fresh breeze gusted off the sea today outside Lindenmere, her erstwhile country place at the edge of this Suffolk County town, members of the Philippine Presidential Commission on Good Government sat around the kitchen table, eating cake.
LEAD: Players from Washington, New York City, Philadelphia and Los Angeles won major titles at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Saturday night.
LEAD: Bobby Allison returned home to Alabama today, six weeks after he was seriously injured in a crash at Pocono International Raceway in Pennsylvania.

LEAD: BASEBALL pilgrims rivaling the United Nations in geographic diversity are visiting the national baseball museum and library here to worship at the shrine of the national game and, at the same time, pick up expertise that may be used when baseball becomes a gold-medal sport in the 1992 Olympics.
LEAD: Technical market factors are expected to temper any upward pressure on interest rates that results from the release of a number of economic reports this week.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The political wrecking crews are tearing down Vice President Bush and Governor Dukakis. ''Our wimp can beat your shrimp,'' says one Republican campaign button. On the other side, the Democrats say Bush won't pick Senator Dole as his running mate because Bush would then have to spend four more years playing No.

LEAD: Even though harness racing in the metropolitan area suffered a severe setback with the closing of Roosevelt Raceway on Long Island, there is plenty of optimism at Yonkers Raceway and the Meadowlands.

LEAD: A skateboard rider surveying work of Rico Fonseca as he followed his friend along MacDougal and West Fourth Streets in Greenwich Village. The artist's work was for sale, but it was not clear whether the riders were buying or browsing. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: John E. Jacob, president of the National Urban League, speaking at a news conference opening the group's four-day meeting in Detroit. He criticized the Reagan Administration and called for racial parity by the year 2000. He also said that Vice President Bush declined an invitation to address the gathering ''just as Ronald Reagan didn't come in 1984.
LEAD: The sense of crisis surrounding the savings and loan industry is bubbling up to the attention of some big thinkers who are looking forward to the next administration.

LEAD: Seagate Technology Inc., the largest independent manufacturer of hard disk drives, said today that it had reduced its Asia production schedules because of high inventory levels of finished goods, and had lowered its shipment rates.

LEAD: AN analysis of samples extracted from wells has convinced geologists that a crater 20 miles wide was formed some 66 million years ago when an object two miles in diameter struck what is now Iowa. The crater, long since filled in, is the largest known impact structure in the United States.

LEAD: A decade ago, the Canadian Brass was a fairly good ensemble, as brass quintets go - which is to say that it played its constricted repertory of Baroque transcriptions, marches and ragtime works with polish and panache. Since then, the quintet has discovered that cutesiness and middle-brow comedy are more lucrative than straightforward musicianship, and as its sound grew tarnished, it devoted itself to such gimmicks as dressing in tutus to play ballet medleys and recording an execrable disco track called ''Boy Mozart.
LEAD: One of the most solidly grounded generalizations in chess is that the bishop pair is stronger than two knights, yet there is the occasional dramatic exception.

LEAD: Circular loops were tried and rejected decades ago because roller coaster cars moved too fast at the bottom and too slowly at the top. The rapid upward climb created excessive centrifugal force that pressed riders into seats uncomfortably. But the slowdown at the top could let upside-down riders fall out of their seats as centrifugal force weakened and gravity became the cominant force.

LEAD: The temptation is to dismiss talk of a Jesse Jackson-Edward Koch peace conference, engineered by Mario Cuomo, as just election-year politics. LEAD: The French gypsy guitarist Bireli Lagrene made a small tactical error at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night. Though he opened with ''Blues for Ike,'' a composition by Django Reinhardt, Mr. Lagrene spent most of the set playing anonymous fusion on his electric guitar. To make things worse, the band, featuring an electric bass, an instrument nearly impossible to make swing, was obviously unrehearsed and had the rhythmic surety of goats on ice.

LEAD: Yasir Arafat says that before he became chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, he was a wealthy, free-spending tourist who traveled through Europe and lived the good life.

LEAD: There is a sense of fear among Jews in Moscow these days, a disquieting feeling that the changes taking place in Soviet society, changes that seem to encourage more openness and tolerance, are somehow stimulating the anti-Semitism that has deep historical roots in this country.

LEAD: The seventh annual series of ''Film and Video on Art'' continues this weekend at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street. The program of 14 films and 13 videotapes includes profiles of Alice Aycock, Jennifer Bartlett, Romare Bearden, Alfred Stieglitz and others. A tape on the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and a filmed interview with the architect Frank Gehry are complements of their work now on view.

LEAD: While it's easy to name a recent Broadway play or two as awful as ''Checkmates,'' it may be necessary to get out the scrapbooks to recall one quite so amateurish and boring. ''Checkmates'' is a comedy in which the characters say such lines as ''A man's home is his castle'' and ''It's a whole new ball game'' - and aren't joking.
LEAD: Robert E. Page, the publisher and president of The Chicago Sun-Times Inc., resigned yesterday.
LEAD: The Ladies Professional Golf Association is faced with the challenge of reshaping its image and operating procedures as it begins the search for a new commissioner.

LEAD: Negotiators from the House and Senate today agreed on the final version of legislation to provide financial assistance to farmers, agriculture businesses and others who have been hurt by the drought. The panel excluded the largest and richest farms from benefits.

LEAD: Howard P. Allen, the chairman and chief executive of SCEcorp, one of the nation's largest utilities, lives 10 miles from where he was born in Upland, Calif., a onetime citrus-growing region 45 miles east of Los Angeles.

LEAD: An investigation will continue even though a man has pleaded guilty and been sentenced to life in the death of a former boarder whose head was found buried in the defendant's yard, the police said today.

LEAD: JUST by its nature, the programming of a concert series always indicates ideological intent - which apples are included, which oranges get left out in the cold. Classical Jazz, a five-night series opening tonight at Lincoln Center, doesn't mince words, announcing its intentions in its title. Mostly programmed by Wynton Marsalis, the jazz trumpeter, critic and artistic adviser to the series, and Alina Bloomgarden, the producer, Classical Jazz is heavy with tributes: the composers Tadd Dameron and Duke Ellington, and the drummer Max Roach are all given a night.

LEAD: Alan Trammell drove in five runs with two doubles tonight as the Tigers beat Boston, 11-6, ending the Boston's seven-game winning streak and regaining sole possession of first place in the American League East.

Lynn R. Williams, the president of that union, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman about managed trade, steel imports and competitiveness.
LEAD: An article in this section last Sunday about the National Black Arts Festival in Atlanta incorrectly described Alain Locke. He was the first black American Rhodes scholar.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Wojak of St. Louis have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wojak's daughter, Kristina Ellen Weisenstein, to Waddell Watters Stillman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gordon B. Stillman of New York and Wrightsville Beach, N.C. Ms. Weisenstein and her fiance, both 1983 cum laude graduates of Yale University, plan to marry Oct.

LEAD: In its excellent coverage of Assemblymen Menendez's, Kenny's and Charles's bill on anti-bias violence (in the July 10 article ''Tougher Law Asked in Attacks on Indians,'' July 10), the New Jersey Weekly mentioned that the bill was modeled on similar legislation currently pending in the New York State Legislature.

LEAD: Women directors are in the ascendancy at Stratford this season. Last year, Deborah Warner made her Royal Shakespeare Company debut with her stunning production of ''Titus Andronicus'' (starring Brian Cox). That production has since moved to the small Pit theater in the company's London home, the Barbican.

LEAD: The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians, defying solution for 40 years now, has its basis in a difficult reality: the attachment of both peoples to the same piece of territory. But compromise might have been possible if vision had not been obscured on all sides by illusions.

LEAD: SUSPECT Starring Cher (in photo), Dennis Quaid, Liam Neeson, John Mahoney, Joe Mantegna (in photo), Philip Bosco. Directed by Peter Yates. 1987. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 121 minutes. $89.95. Rated R. As Kathleen Riley, a smart, hard-boiled, bespectacled public defender who sets out to clear a homeless deaf-mute of a murder charge, Cher gives a ''crisply compelling performance'' in this courtroom thriller, said The Times's reviewer, Janet

LEAD: COMMIT A CRIME, they say, and the world is made of glass. I have long believed it. As a teen-ager in the Navy, I walked off my ship one shore liberty with half-a-dozen blank notebooks, property of Uncle Sam, hidden beneath the civilian clothes in my bag. At the end of the gangway, a crusty master-of-arms singled me out of the stream of shorebound sailors (most of them, I thought, with a lot more evil in their eyes than I), glared at the bag and asked me to open it.

LEAD: SOME words, by definition, have a bad reputation. Take procrastination for instance: no one wants to have a whiff of that word smelling up letters of recommendation or hovering around evaluation forms. Procrastination is kid stuff. Grownups know those nasty things called responsibilities will always get you in the end, so why struggle against the inevitable.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As the barge glided along the Hudson River, 10-year-old Shawn Coleman lip-synched and danced to Michael Jackson's ''Bad'' on the upper deck. Later, he would go to the lower deck - to get a dental checkup.
LEAD: A man who said he would ''have to kill everyone who was not a born-again Christian'' tried to storm the cockpit of a jetliner as it was preparing to land, the authorities said.
LEAD: If experience is the best teacher, then Marc N. Turk didn't learn a great deal from his tragic automobile incident [ ''The Dream That Fell to Earth,'' July 31 ] .

LEAD: ''Cream pies and existentialist philosophy'' is how ''Voidville'' has been described by its director, Michael Patrick King. He also calls it ''vaudeville for the 80's.'' But the revue is at its best when it settles for simply being a satirical revue and drops the pretentious act of mixing ''Sugar Babies'' with Kierkegaard.
LEAD: Your article made it clear that more needs to be done for the refugees and displaced persons living in border encampments along the Thai-Kampuchean border.

LEAD: AT HAMPTON University in Virginia, learning pays - literally. Entering students whose combined Scholastic Aptitude Test scores exceed 1200 (out of a possible 1600) get free tuition; those with scores over 1300 get free tuition, room and board. Students who qualify for the honors dormitory on the city's Hampton River waterfront pay lower rent and enjoy other amenities, such as a swimming pool.

LEAD: Walker Starring Ed Harris, Richard Masur, Rene Auberjonois, Peter Boyle, Marlee Matlin, Blanca Guerra, Gerrit Graham, William O'Leary, Keith Szarabajka, Sy Richardson, Xander Berkeley. Directed by Alex Cox. 1987. MCA Home Video. 94 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.
LEAD: The winding Saco River meets the sea at this southern Maine city and it is here that John Cadwallader fishes for brown trout, striped bass and bluefish. But he yearns for an Atlantic salmon.
LEAD: IN the past, shopping center developers benefited from the nation's move to the suburbs and had their pick from among vast expanses of inexpensive land in new markets.

LEAD: THE OBJECT OF MY AFFECTION, by Stephen McCauley. (Washington Square/Pocket, $6.95.) Nina, an aspiring psychologist, becomes pregnant and asks George, her homosexual roommate, to help her raise the child. Stephen McCauley ''brings his characters, his world astonishingly, captivatingly alive,'' Susan Fromberg Schaeffer said in The Book Review last year.

LEAD: COMEDY AND DANCE Premiere performances of an off-beat comedy and an unusual dance-theater piece are being presented this week and next week by the River Arts Repertory Theater in Woodstock, N.Y. ''Tales of the Lost Formicans'' is a send-up of the American suburbs through the eyes of a couple of anthropologists from outer space; and ''La Goulue'' traces the flamboyant career of the Parisian can-can dancer who achieved immortality as the subject of paintings by Henri de Toulouse

LEAD: LATE at night, television off, family asleep, streets empty, I hear the lonely wail of a train whistle in the distance. That sound, poets and writers tell me, is supposed to awaken in me a longing for romance, adventure and far away places. But as the grade crossings are eliminated, no matter what the images, even the whistle of the L.I.R.R.

LEAD: Some Cuban exiles here say they are planning an invasion of Cuba. But these Cubans say that their invasion, unlike previous attempts by small bands with rifles and explosives, will be carried out with television signals.

LEAD: Although there is nothing amazing about the Amazing Pink Things, the mild-mannered musical comedy quartet currently appearing at Dannys' Skylight Room (346 West 46th Street), in one respect the group does live up to its name. Its garish costumes are encrusted with little pink nubs and beads that enhance its image as a quartet of living dolls.

LEAD: If American Samoa's non-voting Congressional delegate, Fofo I. F. Sunia, came to Washington promising to create jobs, he has kept his word. In fact, say Federal prosecutors, Mr. Sunia, with the help of his assistant, created 14 jobs on his Washington staff. The trouble was, he never bothered to fill some of the positions and failed to notify the House finance office when some of his staff members quit.

LEAD: An article July 17 about plans to build a replica of the inventor Guglielmo Marconi's yacht Elettra misstated the time it took for the first trans-Atlantic radio message to travel from England to Newfoundland. The transmission of the signal was virtually instantaneous; however, it took three days for Marconi's receiving equipment to register the message in Newfoundland.

LEAD: As an open launch approached the northern beach of Monomoy's north island, the passengers crowded into the cockpit raised a dozen pairs of binoculars to a dozen pairs of eyes. It was low tide. To the south and west on the tidal flats of Nantucket Sound, an immense congregation of shore and sea birds probed the shallows with bills of every contour and size.
LEAD: REPETITION By Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 246 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

LEAD: THE Reagan Administration and members of Congress from coastal states are at odds over a proposal to clean up 10 polluted bodies of water in the country, including the New York Bight, which has been plagued by sewage, hospital waste and other debris.

LEAD: A new system that could go far toward conquering a persistent threat to aviation safety was put spectacularly to the test one day last month when three loud beeps summoned the Denver airport tower to action.
LEAD: For an encore, Keith Hernandez sat in the dugout tonight, rested his tender hamstring muscle and watched the Mets defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates for the fifth time in six games in two weekends.

LEAD: When Friday afternoon comes, most of the students at the Horace Greeley High School summer session in Chappaqua bolt for area pools and tennis courts. But 15 students head for the 3:02 train that will carry them back to their homes in the South Bronx.

LEAD: It might be said that Skip Storch put his mouth where his money was. LEAD: In a culture whose critical mass has nourished rock and roll for 30 years, the fall of the big bands toward extinction has been inevitable. The old swing-era infrastructure of bands, ballrooms, broadcasts and booking agencies is gone. Most of the legendary figures are dead. And now, Johnny Carson's contract will be up in September.

LEAD: The snowbirds are returning home to roost, said Paul T. Liistro, the developer of an $11 million retirement community opening in October near Hartford. But as some abandon Florida for northern climes, many cannot find living space that caters to their needs. Retirement communities, which are thought to have originated in the Midwest and proliferated across the Sun Belt, are late in coming to New England.
LEAD: The other day my old friend Professor Harsch showed up at my front door. He had been away for two or three years, buried in the depths of the country; and now here he was back in town.

LEAD: Dave Righetti went to the mound with two out in the ninth inning and struck out Kent Hrbek for his 17th save as the Yankees defeated the Minnesota Twins, 5-3, before 40,814 last night at the Stadium.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Simon B. Ehrlich of Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Abigail Mary Ehrlich to Aaron Daniel Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Cohen of Roslyn Heights, L.I.

LEAD: A picture caption on July 10 about the Preston B. Bird and Mary Heinlein Tropical Fruit and Spice Park in Florida misidentified one fruit. The fruit, fuzzy and oval-shaped, is mountain soursop. Another picture caption with the same article characterized passion fruit incorrectly. It grows on a vine.

LEAD: On the corner of a once-busy road to the ancient cathedral town of Winchester and a byway to the village of Gosport, there is an unassuming late 17th-century brick cottage that was built as the home of a farm bailiff. It stands alongside a few smaller cottages across the street from what is now Cassandra's Cup Tea

LEAD: Film lends extra poignancy To the passing of time, allowing an instant overview of the arc of a career. The Film Society of Lincoln Center's forthcoming ''New Directors/Newer Films'' series will make it possible to see these trajectories clearly, to trace the path of a Hector Babenco as he progressed from the raw ''Pixote'' to the brilliantly realized ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' to the sodden ''Ironweed.

LEAD: Senate Democrats have stumbled onto a good policy on the vexatious matter of contra aid. Their approach is to provide further food, medicine and clothing to the Nicaraguan rebels but to keep military aid in the far background. This tack prevents collapse of the contras and maintains the basis for negotiations.

LEAD: THIS WAS THE UGLIEST HOUSE IN THE neighborhood: a dark-brown elephant with asbestos siding. But to interior designer Kevin Walz and his wife, Barbra, a photographer, this was also a house with hidden charms. Not only was the property inviting, there were also porches on four sides, a series of untouched and well-proportioned main rooms on the ground floor, eight bedrooms upstairs and quirky Victorian details.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Stephen Chamberlin of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Ann Chamberlin to Edward Frank Keyes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Keyes of Barrington, R.I., and West Palm Beach, Fla. The couple plan to marry on Oct. 22.

LEAD: To the Editor: Hooray for Roberto Suro! At last he lists, in ''What's Doing in Venice'' (Travel, June 12), some less expensive hotels instead of hotels charging $200 or more a night. I am sure other readers wish to know of second-class hotels not easily discoverable. LEE FIELDEN Collinsville,
LEAD: WHAT is wrong with this advertisement: Charming Colonial, 4 bdrm. 2 1/2 baths, modern eat-in kitchen, fireplace, enclosed porch, in-ground pool, Greenburgh vicinity, asking $550,000?

LEAD: THE recent Federal drug bill reintroducing capital punishment for certain drug-related murders in an election year is further evidence that politics never changes. You can fool some of the people, but, one hopes, not all of the time.

LEAD: SOMEDAY soon, utility shareholder and customers will find out which of them will pay for the last of the approximately 100 nuclear reactors that were ordered, but never completed, at a cost of about $30 billion.
LEAD: Armbro Goal captured the 63d edition of the Hambletonian, the middle leg of trotting's triple crown, in straight heats this afternoon in a festive atmosphere at the Meadowlands race track.

LEAD: It is a project that exudes international brotherhood and good will, but its primary purpose is music. On Friday evening, the American-Soviet Youth Orchestra, 110 musicians from the United States and the Soviet Union, began a three-week tour of nine cities in both countries with a debut concert at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

LEAD: CANADA'S opposition Liberal Party announced last month that its majority in the upper house of Parliament would block the legislation necessary to implement a free-trade agreement that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a Progressive Conservative, had negotiated with the United States.

LEAD: CRAVING FOR JAZZ The New Haven Jazz Collective, a new cooperative, will open its rehearsals to the public from 5 to 7 P.M. today and the next two Sundays. LEAD: James P. S. Devereux, a World War II hero and former Maryland Congressman, died Friday of pneumonia at Stella Maris Hospice in Baltimore. He was 85 years old and was a resident of Ruxton, Md.

LEAD: The Democratic nominee for President of the United States went for a brisk walk today, alone in the rarefied Rocky Mountain dawn - except for 13 cars, a dozen reporters, eight aides, assorted politicians and supporters, five motorcycle outriders, four golf carts, two tour buses and a stretch limousine.

LEAD: GOOD SKATES While it may be too early for most folks to think ''ice'' (except in tall, cool glasses) it's never soon enough for skaters. Today's the day the new competitive figure skating season begins, as hopefuls from the east show their stuff at ''Skate Long Island.'' One hundred and seventeen competitors, including the current National Novice Men's Silver Medalist and Eastern Sectional Novice Men's Champion and several Japanese skaters studying in the area, take to the ice at the Cantiague Park Rink in

LEAD: OHIO STATE University's recent decision to entrust $5 million of its endowment to a class of business students surprised many. Schools, already in financial straits, were hit hard by last October's stock collapse, and Wall Street's uncertain mood since has dampened interest in money-management careers.

Hawthorne, N.Y. $210,000 32 Weed Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; living room with fireplace, family room, full basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,828.

LEAD: ONCE again, the big steel companies - and their lobbyists - are beating the drums to renew the so-called ''voluntary'' restraint agreements. These agreements restrict the import of foreign steel into this country and are scheduled to expire in September 1989.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo told the Federal judge in the deadlocked Yonkers desegregation dispute again yesterday that he stood ready to help the judge enforce or modify his order for 800 new middle-income housing units.

LEAD: ONE of the richest men in America, M. Larry Lawrence, has sought to enrich the campaign of the Democratic nominee in the last 10 Presidential contests. He remembers well the days when candidates were bankrolled by a moneyed elite. He also recalls the change in direction after Watergate, when Congress wrote laws to drive big money out of Presidential politics through public financing of campaigns.

LEAD: President Reagan's veto of the $299 billion Pentagon budget bill last week puts politics above national security. Though Defense Secretary Frank Carlucci and national security adviser Colin Powell had problems with aspects of the bill, they recommended White House approval. So did leading Congressional
LEAD: An estimated 20,000 people marched silently through the streets today in a show of solidarity with the Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: In Bennington, where early American history dominates the landscape, residents are grappling with much more recent and less inspiring history: scandal and controversy in the Southwestern Vermont school system.

LEAD: IN a twisted way, the story of the Wedtech Corporation seemed a quintessential American tale, albeit one of bribery, theft, extortion and securities fraud that climaxed last week with the convictions of a Congressman and a former borough president.
LEAD: A passenger train slammed into a barrier at a railroad station here today, killing one person and injuring 57, the Paris fire department said.

LEAD: ''The dust clouds were so dark you could see them 10 miles away. But there wasn't a thing I could do to save the land.
LEAD: Responding to the rising demand for new AIDS treatments, the Reagan Administration is preparing a major regulatory proposal to permit faster evaluation of drugs for life-threatening illnesses.

LEAD: Today, the eve of her 32d birthday, as Sharon Kowalski lies in a nursing home in Hibbing, Minn., demonstrators across the country will be demanding that her family let her see Karen Thompson, who says they intended to spend their lives as a couple.

LEAD: NO one has been made ill, so far as is known, by the used hypodermic needles, vials of blood and other medical trash washing up on Northeast beaches. But the tides of medical waste still have ruined the summer for thousands of swimmers from Rhode Island to New Jersey, along with the shoreline businesses that depend on them.

LEAD: For nearly 50 years it was one of the most unusual buildings in midtown, with a seven-story-high modernistic facade, blank except for a strip of windows at the top. But earlier this year the ground-floor studio space in the CBS Studio Building at 49 East 52d Street was taken over by a Duane Reade drugstore, and a storefront has now replaced the ground floor's 50-foot expanse of gray and blue terra-cotta blocks.

LEAD: THE proposed settlement of the dispute over the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham nuclear power plant has created an extraordinary conjunction of interests among groups that seem to have little in common.

LEAD: The small valve that halted the firing of the space shuttle Discovery's main rocket engines was being removed today to prepare the craft for another attempt at the test, which could come as early as the middle of next week.

LEAD: To the Editor: In answer to L. R. of Toms River, N.J. (Q & A, May 15), Stanley Carr suggested that by sending $1 for postage to Convention and Visitors Bureau, Post Office Box 6977, San Francisco, Calif. 94101, one would receive a lodging guide containing information on small hotels. On May 17 I sent a $1 check, which was deposited promptly.

LEAD: A 26-minute videotape recorded by a Metro-North Railroad police officer in Grand Central Terminal five years ago has caused a major shakeup at the railroad and become the focus of news reports around the nation.
