LEAD: One of the few grand old hotels still left in Spring Lake, N.J. - the Hewitt Wellington - is now being divided into the seaside community's first condominium hotel. The town became known for its Victorian architecture when it was called the Irish Riviera - for the many wealthy Irish families who summered there.
LEAD: Residents here in the hometown of a leading figure in the Iran-contra affair have decided to cancel the second annual ''Oliver North Day.''

LEAD: Jim McAllister, who calls himself the unofficial historian of Salem, Mass., conducts guided tours of his adopted hometown. ''There are four reasons why people come to Salem,'' he said. ''Maritime history. Architectural history. Nathaniel Hawthorne. And witches.''
LEAD: The Democratic Party is recapturing much of the crucial middle ground of American politics as the fall campaign approaches, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

LEAD: What, if anything, distinguishes black painting or sculpture from any other kind of art? In exhibitions that encompass the period stretching back to the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920's, the First National Black Arts Festival has assembled a diversity of objects implicitly intended to address this elusive issue.

LEAD: The last filly to win her first 10 starts was Ruffian, and the last to win the Whitney Handicap was Lady's Secret. Now there is a filly who has done both of those things, and today she earned a place in history alongside those two.

LEAD: Although the collective shadows of past tragedies loom large (Mike Torrez, Bill Buckner and Calvin Schiraldi), the present squad consists of the exciting blend of veterans, trade acquisitions and youngsters developed from the farm system. Roger Clemens, the consummate power pitcher, may extricate the franchise from the curse of Babe Ruth once and for all.

LEAD: THE chance to see a seldomdone but once successful play by America's most honored playwright - in fact, his first produced full-length work, and a Pulitzer Prize-winning one at that - is surely an occasion to be bypassed only by churls and Philistines.
LEAD: CHARLOTTE MEW AND HER FRIENDS With a Selection of Her Poems. By Penelope Fitzgerald. Foreword by Brad Leithauser. Illustrated. 276 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. $17.95.

Travaglin of Colebrook, Conn., and the late Warren G. Bodey. The Rev. William B. Lane Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred.
LEAD: SPY vs. SPY Stalking Soviet Spies in America. By Ronald Kessler. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.
LEAD: Clothes Make the Art ''THE things people wear says a lot about them,'' said Hedy Klineman, an artist from East Hampton. ''The spirit of a person is in his clothes.''

LEAD: The Russian Choral Society was founded in 1973 to encourage the study, publication and performance of the literature it is named for. As anyone who has sung in a choir that has delved into Russian music knows, this is a rich body of music, with characteristics that set it apart from the choral traditions of the Western European mainstream.

LEAD: When it came time to dissect a frog in her high school biology class, Jenifer Graham wanted no part of it. Her grade in the class was reduced from an A to a B as a result, and the California teen-ager, a vegetarian who opposes the killing of animals for scientific purposes, took the matter to court.

LEAD: On a European trip early last fall I unexpectedly found myself with some extra days in Paris before my return to the United States. I was pleased. For once I would be able to enjoy my native city in a leisurely way, discover the Musee Picasso, explore in depth the Louvre, perhaps pay a call on ''La Dame a la Licorne'' in the Musee de Cluny.

LEAD: TIMOTHY F. BANNON, the Commissioner of Revenue Services, administers a staff of 860 employees collecting $3.9 billion in taxes a year. A 41-year-old Ohio native whose father was from Connecticut, Mr. Bannon is a 1977 graduate of the Yale University Law School who worked at private law firms and corporations before becoming an aide to Governor O'Neill in 1985.

LEAD: Nearly 10 months after the stock market took its plunge, the financial-services industry still remains wary of committing major amounts of capital to moving back-office facilities from downtown Manhattan to cheaper office districts.
LEAD: SHOULD smoking still be permitted in the community rooms, health clubs and public hallways of co-ops and condominiums? Or even alongside a condominium's open-air pool?

LEAD: The Atlanta Police Department was divided by racism and failed to follow standard operating procedures in 1987 when it investigated charges that former State Senator Julian Bond was a drug abuser, a civilian review panel has said.

LEAD: Leaky Windows in a Co-op Question: My building was converted into a co-op in June of 1985. In the year before the closing, the landlord, who was also the sponsor of the conversion plan, installed new windows. The job was botched and the windows leak, causing damage in many apartments. The board has been unsuccessful in getting the sponsor or the contractor to correct the problem.

LEAD: In a fortcoming autobiography, Brian Bosworth, the former all-America linebacker at Oklahoma, describes a Sooner football program in which players freebased cocaine, steroids were commonplace and National Collegiate Athletic Association violations occurred.

LEAD: A passenger ship carrying at least 300 Hindu pilgrims capsized today in the Ganges River in eastern India. At least 38 people were reported killed and hundreds were missing, the authorities said.
LEAD: Pentagon officials said last week that a Navy investigation had blamed crew error, arising from the stress of battle, for the downing of Iran Air Flight 655 by an American warship on July 3.

LEAD: Heidi Alice Eklund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Eklund of Hauppauge, L.I., was married yesterday to Bruno Gardien, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Gardien of Grenoble, France, and Rome. The Rev. Peter Colapietro prformed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

LEAD: The offense, the part of the team that was supposed to work, generated such scant yardage tonight that it was outscored until the final minutes by its kick-blocking unit.

LEAD: A caption accompanying a photo of the pianist Rudolf Firkusny in the Arts and Leisure section today gives the incorrect time for his performance at Caramoor this afternoon. It will begin at 5:30 P.M.

LEAD: I don't recall the exact moment during ''Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding'' when the lines between make-believe and reality began to crumble. Midway through the four-hour wedding and reception staged by the environmental comedy troupe Artificial Intelligence, I stopped feeling like a member of the audience and became part of the raucous celebration.

LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that he was ready to accept a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war if Iran agreed to begin direct peace talks immediately after the truce, the Iraqi press service reported.
LEAD: REAL-ESTATE agents welcomed the release of $100 million in low-interest mortgage money last week but said new rules would add to the difficulty in using it.

LEAD: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Washington, Ariantje DuBois, a daughter of Mrs. Eugene DuBois of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Mr. DuBois was married yesterday to Richard Neville Johnston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gregg Johnston of Connellsville, Pa. The Rev. James R. Adams performed the ceremony.

LEAD: WHEN THE FIRST TOMATO ripens on the vine, I resist all temptation to bite then and there into the tight skin. Instead, I carry it into the kitchen and make a sandwich. The ritual is always the same: a lather of store-bought mayonnaise on two slices of plain white bread, a couple of thick slices of tomato, a dose of salt and pepper.

LEAD: MICHAEL EDELMAN, a Yonkers lawyer who was the city's Corporation Counsel in 1982, recalled last week: ''We could have settled the discrimination suit then for 100 units of low-income housing and a school integration plan that would not have included busing.''

LEAD: Colin Higgins, a screenwriter and director whose works include ''Silver Streak,'' ''Foul Play'' and ''Harold and Maude,'' died Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 47 years old and had been suffering from AIDS, said a spokeswoman for his production company.

LEAD: THE key to Paris couture is luxury, but this does not always mean gleaming bead embroideries and sumptuous furs; elegant workmanship and rich materials are taken for granted. Exquisite details mark the difference between ready-to-wear and made-to-order clothes.

LEAD: The engagement of Dori Beth Goldsmith to Eric David Cook, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome L. Cook of Plainview, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin F. Goldsmith of Melville, L.I.

LEAD: THEIR NAMES leap off the pages of course catalogues. Registering for their classes inspires the competitive, camping-out-on-the-ticket-line spirit usually reserved for a Bruce Springsteen concert.

LEAD: Bologna's most famous pork product is mortadella, the original bologna. Dubbed la Bologna in Milan and outside the region of Emilia-Romagna where it is produced, it is an impressively large, pale pink sausage with a finely ground pork forcemeat. Sound familiar? This is the exalted relative of our humble bologna.
LEAD: THE LAST AMERICAN PURITAN The Life of Increase Mather 1639-1723. By Michael G. Hall. Illustrated. 438 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. $35.

LEAD: The story is not new, and some of the dramatic devices used in telling it are awkward, but Jesus Gonzalez Davila's play, ''De la Calle'' (''From the Street''), is possessed by a kind of grim fury that leaves you feeling shocked, even horrified.

LEAD: The engagement of Jocelyne Antoinette Giroux to David Ames DeNunzio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Dwight DeNunzio of Riverside, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Claude Andre Giroux of New York, parents of the bride-to-be.
LEAD: Things are looking brighter for digital audio tape, the first digital medium for home recording. A major legal obstacle to its launch has evaporated.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: One of the rare points of agreement between the prosecution and the defense in the Wedtech racketeering trial was that, without the firm hand of Judge Constance Baker Motley guiding it, the complicated five-month trial probably would have gone on for another six months, risking mutiny by wearied jurors and running up huge costs for both sides.
LEAD: What attracts young professionals to work for the Fresh Air Fund?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Midway through a prerelease screening of Francis Ford Coppola's new film, ''Tucker: The Man and His Dream,'' one member of the audience turned to a companion and whispered: ''I thought Martin Landau was supposed to be in this picture.''

LEAD: WITH its ocean dumping, sewer overflows and monster landfill, New York has given New Jersey legislators plenty of ammunition for the ''sludge wars'' over how the Federal Government should deal with marine pollution. But in regard to medical wastes, the legislators have an additional target: the Environmental Protection Agency.

LEAD: AN event scheduled for the first half of April, 1989 will have many unusual features, and may rate a mention in the ''Guinness Book of World Records.'' It is the Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes to be played in New York and Paris with celebrity, charity and sponsor involvement.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Israeli television reported today that the authorities had seized a draft of a ''declaration of independence'' drawn up by Palestinian leaders who planned to set up a state led by the Palestine Liberation Organization in the occupied territories and parts of Israel.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Being a true Red Sox fan is a strange and immutable condition. For better or for worse, it is what you are. And there is no going back. MICHAEL EDWARD O'CONNOR New York

LEAD: REMARKABLE new technology is introduced into the school system and experts predict education will be revolutionized. The technology will, as never before, allow the widespread dissemination of new concepts and ideas that will stimulate young minds and free the teacher for more creative pursuits. Yet the magic fails to materialize, and within a few years articles appear in the popular press asserting that the failure, obviously, arises from teachers not being skilled enough in the new technology.
LEAD: A NEW Government regulation on the handling of boaters seeking help has prompted an outcry from private tow-boat operators and the Coast Guard Auxiliary.
LEAD: TWO shooting incidents last month involving three Mountainside police officers have focused new attention on the rules governing the use of deadly force.

LEAD: TALK about the plays of Lanford Wilson and it is not likely that ''The Great Nebula in Orion'' will come up. Nor will ''Ikke Ikke Nye Nye Nye'' or ''The Family Continues,'' its companion pieces in a 1971 Off Off Broadway triple bill, that was called simply ''Three Plays by Lanford Wilson.''

LEAD: With a state-operated automobile insurance system running a deficit of $20 million a month, the New Jersey Senate will vote Monday on a bill intended to solve the system's financial problems, but the measure faces a difficult passage through the Legislature.

LEAD: Demonstrations by opponents of abortion led to the arrest of 69 more protesters today. Those arrested joined more than 120 other people in jail from anti-abortion demonstrations that began July 19 at the time of the Democratic National Convention.

LEAD: Twelve cars of a 113-car freight train derailed today and struck a tank of diesel fuel that exploded. The explosion and fire forced the evacuation of about 300 people, the authorities said, but no injuries were reported.

LEAD: Nina Kummel and Dr. Bertram M. Kummel, both of Convent Station, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Andrea Jane Kummel to Robert Wayne Burke, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jordan D. Burke of Short Hills, N.J.

LEAD: I was deeply moved by Barbara Crossette's article, ''After the Killing Fields'' (June 26). The story of displaced Cambodian families reminded me of my own Cherokee ancestors. Our people also were forcibly removed from our ancestral homeland. Many tribal groups were placed in the American version of a refugee camp - the reservation.

LEAD: What a cruel, heartless question! Anyway, regardless of where the Red Sox finish this fall, Joe Morgan has made watching (and, it seems, playing) baseball at Fenway fun again. And even if the Sox don't win it all this year, we Fenway Faithful have this compensation: neither will the Yankees. RICHARD L.

LEAD: A front-page article July 24 about the effect of air pollution on Appalachian forests misidentified a research group based in Washington that investigates stresses on trees and field crops. It is the World Resources Institute. MET

LEAD: Safad is a natural spot for an artists' colony. Atop Mount Canaan in Israel's northern region, it has a magnificent view of Upper Galilee's mountains and valleys. The 20th century has left few marks on the secluded town and its narrow stone-paved alleys, winding streets and ivy-draped houses built around courtyard gardens.

LEAD: DON'T tell the Opera Theater of Connecticut that August is not a fine time to produce opera. The company has booked the Andrews Memorial Theater in Clinton for four performances of ''Cosi fan tutte.'' Accompanied by a 30-piece orchestra, a chorus of 25 and, in proper Mozartian style, conducted from the harpsichord by Robert Ashens, the opera will be mounted in 18th-century period costumes and sung in

LEAD: Security officials in Punjab said today that they had found the bodies of 41 men, women and children who were tortured to death by Sikh militants in the months that the militants held control of the Golden Temple in Amritsar. The Indian police and military stormed the temple complex in May and ousted the

LEAD: The marriage of Tina Lisa Speiser and Joseph Charles Heinzmann Jr., both 1987 graduates of the Syracuse University College of Law, took place last evening at Holy Trinity Chapel in Manhattan. The Rev. Raymond Rafferty, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated.

LEAD: Sarah Nicklin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Nicklin of Garden City, L.I., and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to James H. Moreno, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Moreno of South Plainfield, N.J. The Quaker ceremony took place at the Westbury (L.I.) Friends Meeting House. The bride, a fourth-year student at the Dartmouth Medical School, graduated cum laude from Bryn Mawr College.

LEAD: ONCE upon a time, when my children were very small, and I, a working, commuting-to-New York mom, was very overwhelmed, I'd dream of having a few hours all to myself. Just a precious few - to read a magazine article all the way through, to stroll a shopping mall unencumbered, to speak on the phone without interruption.

LEAD: IN the unending quest for seafood, Darien offers a safe new harbor: Newport Grill. It is in a vast, rambling one-story building on the Post Road, vacated by Chi-Chi's, the unlamented pseudo-Mexican restaurant.

LEAD: The latest scandal to involve stock trading based on insider information centers on Business Week magazine and information obtained from employees of its printer, the R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company. Last week new legislation was introduced in the House of Representatives that would attach stiffer penalties to insider trading violations.

LEAD: Based on the braying by Pennsylvania Democrats, you'd have thought the Republicans were out to transform the Nittany Lions into the Nittany Elephants. Actually, to the state's Democrats, what the Republicans are up to is worse. They have recruited Joe Paterno to give a seconding speech for George Bush at the
LEAD: APPROACHING VIETNAM From World War II Through Dienbienphu 1941-1954. By Lloyd C. Gardner. 440 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: OVER the last several months, Hollywood has barraged us with a number of movies in which children suddenly become adults and, to borrow one film's title, vice versa. Film critics and columnists have said this suddenly popular genre, along with any number of nostalgia films and television programs, exposes a definitive characteristic of the baby boomer: an inexhaustible attachment to his own childhood.
LEAD: TWICE condemned to death, Bandit, described by his owner as a pit bull terrier, had his day in court in Stamford, Conn.

LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

LEAD: When Admiral Perry sailed into Kurihama harbor in 1853, reopening Japan to active trade with the West, he unleashed an esthetic fusillade that was heard round the Western art world, loudest of all in its capital, the city of Paris. As Japanese prints, albums and objects began to arrive in plenty from the East, a kind of mania set in among artists, critics, designers and collectors alike.
LEAD: Doyle Alexander showed again today there's nobody better when the money's on the table.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-19
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AND BABY WILL FALL. By Michael Z. Lewin. (Morrow, $16.95.) Quietly, women authors have been introducing to the amateur mystery female sleuths who do more between adventures than get their nails wrapped. Now comes another sleuth, created by a male author, who can stand tall in this gathering crowd.
LEAD: Doctors have treated the problem in Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd's right shoulder, but Boyd still doesn't know how long it will be before he can start pitching again for the Red Sox.
LEAD: I appreciate the interest, but feel that Robert Lindsey's article, ''Francis Ford Coppola: Promises to Keep'' (July 24) repeats some tired old ideas about me: maverick; mad at Hollywood, etc.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: LIKE Disneyland or Hollywood, smog has long been a symbol of Southern California. Now environmentalists, Government officials and the business community here are debating whether the cost of solving the intractable problem is the reining in of a local economy that has been as vibrant and unfettered as the air is dirty.
LEAD: NEVER before has Cape Cod had so many houses, condominiums and commercial spaces for sale as it has today. And at no time in recent years have there been so few prospective buyers.
LEAD: Jurors throughout New York will get $15 a day starting next April under a bill signed into law this week by Governor Cuomo.
LEAD: OUT ON THE MARSH By David Updike. 168 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $16.95.

LEAD: Starting this week, The New York Times is changing the notation system it uses to describe chess moves. The new system, known as algebraic notation, is widely preferred in the world chess community and has been officially recommended by the International Chess Federation.

LEAD: The Social Security Administration said it was inundated with telephone calls Friday after announcing it was offering free, individualized estimates of future benefits to workers of all ages. The agency's chief said she was adding 100 phone lines to handle the demand.

LEAD: As a competitive swimmer when I was a girl, I lived for those moments when, body poised, toes tingling, I would hear the official intone: ''Judges and timers ready? On your mark, get set. . . .'' (Hers: ''Playing to Win,'' by Margaret A. Whitney, July 3). I would crack-splash into the pool and go for it, to the piercing cries of my mother, at the pool's edge: ''C'mon, Mal!

LEAD: The marriage of Jeanne Appleton Voltz, a food writer and freelance editor, to Frank Barnett MacKnight, a co-owner of MVP, a video production company in Lincoln, Neb., took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Edward C. Horne performed the ceremony in the chapel at the United Methodist Church of St.

LEAD: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, Lisa Laverne Lang, a daughter of Cranford L. Lang of Sarasota, Fla., and Fern A. Lang of Little Rock, Ark., was married yesterday to James Edward Fleming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Fleming of Nevada, Mo. The Rev. Carl B. Nelson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Lori Ellen Schimmerling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Schimmerling of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married in New York last evening to Richard Scott Thal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Thal of New York. Rabbi Norman Kahan and Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Plaza. Mrs. Thal, a nursery school teacher at the Stephen Wise School in Manhattan, graduated from the American University.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of America's highest-ranking secret agent in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: ''ALL I need,'' I said last year as I began a legal separation toward an eventual amicable, uncontested divorce, ''is a room with a closet, space for a desk, a chair, and, er - what would you call them, odds and ends?''

LEAD: A WELL-FUNCTIONING gutter system is essential. Without one, rainwater and melting snow dripping from a roof can easily saturate ground around the foundation, causing basement leakage and settling. If a gutter system is so badly deteriorated that repair is neither practical nor economical, a new system should be promptly installed to replace it.

LEAD: Robin Marantz Henig's aricle, ''Less Can Be More'' (Body and Mind, June 26) demonstrates some of the strengths and weaknesses of short-term psychotherapy. As a practitioner of brief treatment, I do not doubt its value. However, I hesitate to use the word ''cure,'' because it smacks of expectations of instant gratification that are, to my mind, a bane of modern American life.

LEAD: NOT LONG AGO, a devoted grandfather laid out a total of $13,113 to cover four years' worth of tuition, room and board at the University of Wyoming for his two granddaughters. Quite a gift. The earliest that the older child, a 6-year-old, might become a freshman is 1999, when the school's four-year costs are expected to be $19,225, more than two and a half times the prepayment of $7,488; for the other grandchild, who is 3, the $5,625 prepayment will become the equivalent of nearly $23,000 starting in 2002.

LEAD: President Reagan has agreed to freeze emission levels of nitrogen oxide, an important air pollutant, for at least the next seven years. The action will allow the United States to join in a major international treaty to reduce acid rain.
LEAD: Many fans surely could have been knocked over by a feather when they heard the news Thursday that Sugar Ray Leonard had unretired yet again.
LEAD: Police officers across South Africa today seized newsstand copies of The Weekly Mail, a prominent anti-apartheid newspaper.

LEAD: SOME time ago, on a beautiful baseball day late in the season, I was watching my son's team play in a Little League contest. The parents attending were, of course, familiar to me. We had spent the pre-game warm-up speaking of pleasant things and preparing to root our charges onward.
LEAD: THE BEST CONGRESS MONEY CAN BUY By Philip M. Stern 321 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

LEAD: The engagement of Susan J. McClellan to G. Lindsay Valk, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Garry Valk of Cutchogue, L.I., and Sea Island, Ga., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. George W. McClellan of Greenwich, Conn. An Oct. 1 wedding is planned.

LEAD: Yes! And what a glorious fall it will be as the Sox sweep 50 of the remaining 59 games to win the A.L. East going away. Boston then routs Oakland in three and blows out the Mets in five with Mike Boddicker notching the clincher in Fenway Park. The world championship returns to Boston for the first time since 1918.

LEAD: The bronze plaque on the front of the big marble and tile office building solemnly declares that it is the headquarters of the New China News Agency, Hong Kong Branch. But everyone here - from the British Governor of the colony to the Chinese taxi driver - knows better.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo has signed a bill creating the Liberty Scholarship program, which he described as the nation's first state-run effort to cover all college costs for low-income students.

LEAD: Resurrection Roman Catholic Church in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Catherine Jane Natoli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Natoli of Plainsboro, N.J., to Francis Kirk Mahoney, a son of Judge and Mrs. J. Daniel Mahoney of Milford, Conn.

LEAD: CAN you teach an old DOS new tricks? Definitely. That is made clear by version 4.0 of the Disk Operating System from the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation. Upgrading to DOS 4.0 ($95 for those who want to upgrade from an earlier version, or $150 for new customers) is well worth the cost and effort for anyone who has been frustrated by cryptic symbols and commands like A< or COPY B:SUBDIR*.* C:JEEPERSIMLOST.

LEAD: IN April 1983, Yasir Arafat came to Jordan for a series of tense, and ultimately futile, talks with King Hussein on forming a Jordanian-Palestinian negotiating strategy for dealing with Israel. On the day of their first meeting, the P.L.O. leader's armor-plated silver Mercedes drove up to King Hussein's palace.

LEAD: It might have been one of the unfunny consequences of the Writers Guild of America strike: Johnny Carson and David Letterman would be denied their protective cordon of jokesmiths, leaving them writerless and vulnerable before the terrifying eye of the camera. Walking the video tightrope without a safety net, abandoned by their comedy support teams, there was every chance that
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Six mornings a week, at 9 A.M., the Rajdhani Express, queen of India's vast railroad network and its only fully air-conditioned train, eases into the New Delhi railroad station from Bombay. It is rarely late. But the plushness of this flagship -with tinted windows, uniformed room attendants, six-course meals, special linen for the wide and soft bunk beds and even showers in the bathrooms of the first-class coaches - is in vivid contrast to the overcrowded and dirty trains that are more common in India.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph-on-the-Brandywine in Greenville, Del., Regina Thompson Bahr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bahr of Greenville, was married yesterday to Patrick Matthew Finn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Finn of Towson, Md. The Rev. Roch Ciandella, the chaplain of the Canterbury School in New Milford, Conn., performed the ceremony.

LEAD: FOR two years I combed the antique print shops in Boston and New York searching for a wedding gift for a very special young couple. Then, to my surprise, I found two old prints I wanted at a local antique show held in a church near my home each year.

LEAD: The Giants opened their preseason schedule in impressive fashion this evening. In fact things couldn't have gone much smoother if the coaching staff had scripted the team's 34-3 shellacking of the Green Bay Packers.

LEAD: YOU know it's summer when there are blueberries with the cereal in the morning. The berries are also delicious, as any child knows, in pies and tarts - and are particularly good for homemade ice cream.

LEAD: Two Canadian businessmen made the first of what is expected to be a handful of competing proposals to acquire the bankrupt PTL ministry and its Heritage USA theme park, a trustee for the ministry said Friday.

LEAD: AN article of faith in shopping center design is that a large nationally known department store lures customers, who then also spend money at the small, local, less well-known stores. Even as department stores have lost ground to smaller specialty shops, shopping centers with national retailers as anchors continue to outperform those that have only local tenants.
LEAD: The Greek police have been put on alert around the Athens airport and at American military bases and airlines offices here amid fears of terrorist attacks, a senior police official said today.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having spent one night (all we could afford) in a ryokan (Japanese inn) during our three-week visit to Japan last summer, we sympathized with Kathy Jones and Clyde Haberman (Travel, June 12). However, they failed to alert potential visitors to a further hazard. Our guidebook informed us that it was customary to wear the yukata (cotton kimono) in the passages and public rooms of the ryokan.
LEAD: To the Editor: Norman Kotker's article on Revere Beach (Travel, May 15) brought back many boyhood memories.
LEAD: COMMUTING to New York and planning to park on the narrow streets here to beat public garage fees? Better think twice, say officials of the Hoboken Parking Authority. Getting caught will cost

LEAD: The Yankees have had to summon Dave Eiland and Lee Guetterman from the minor leagues to start games (they had no interest in Mike Boddicker), John Candelaria has a sore elbow, Ron Guidry and Charles Hudson are on the disabled list (they had no interest in Mike Boddicker) and they don't know if they can trust Tommy John and Richard Dotson as starters any longer (they had no interest in Mike

LEAD: AS Secretary of State George P. Shultz toured Latin America last week seeking support for the Nicaraguan rebels, he denounced Nicaragua's Sandinista Government at every opportunity, describing it as ''a cancer'' that must be removed. President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, an outspoken critic of the contras, was no less vehement.

LEAD: Bela Karolyi's expertise in developing female gymnasts was never more apparent than today as three of his athletes qualified for the six-member United States Olympic team and two others won spots as alternates.

LEAD: NIGHTS AS DAY, DAYS AS NIGHT. By Michel Leiris. Translated by Richard Sieburth. (Eridanos Press, P.O. Box 211, Hygiene, Colo., Cloth, $22; Paper, $13.) Born in 1901, Michel Leiris has shirked no adventure of the French intellectual left. Surrealist writer, then ethnographer, he has worked with the giants of modern art and social thought, but his most intrepid explorations have been autobiographical.

LEAD: At Congregation B'nai Jeshrun in Short Hills, N.J., Dr. Stefanie Sue Jacobs, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fred M. Jacobs of Short Hills, and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Hadley Evan Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger B. Feldman of Potomac, Md., and Grantham, N.H. Rabbi Barry Hewitt officiated.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wayne Harvey of New Martinsville, W. Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cyndra Lynn Harvey to Alan Sterling Van Clief, a son of Mrs. Daniel Good Van Clief of Nydrie Farms, Esmont, Va., and the late Mr. Van Clief. The couple plan to marry Oct. 1.

LEAD: To the Editor: On a recent visit to Rome, we made two interesting discoveries. One was the Pension Suisse (56 Via Gregoriana) where we stayed three weeks. It was immaculate, efficient, well located, and it cost us $51 a day for two with Continental breakfast.

LEAD: Edison $144,000 137 Winthrop Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, patio; taxes $1,414. Iselin $159,000 1051 Woodruff Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old expanded Cape Cod; den, formal dining room, patio; taxes $1,639.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''There will be some disappointment tonight in Germany and Japan.'' - Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas after passage of the trade bill.
LEAD: In his Brooklyn basement, Robert J. Randisi writes novels about the Old West that are partly inspired by racehorses he has watched at Belmont and Aqueduct.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor: The New York Times has long printed more news and articles about Canada than any other United States newspaper that I know of.

LEAD: MORE than 170 American companies have sold their holdings in South Africa in the last three years as a result of considerable political and economic pressure from within the United States and abroad. Disinvested companies include such familiar names as the Xerox Corporation, the International Business Machines Corporation, the Coca-Cola Company, the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation, Citicorp and the Eastman Kodak Company.

LEAD: Citing declining American political support for the deployment of forces abroad, a House Armed Services subcommittee warned today that Western Europe and Japan must rely less on the United States and more on their own forces and funds to defend themselves.
LEAD: BY ALL initial indications, 9-year-old Kendall Smith drowned in Dillon, S.C., on Jan. 12. Yet today he appears to be as active physically as any boy his age and mentally alert.

LEAD: Merry I. White, an associate professor of sociology at Boston University, and Edward J. Baumeister Jr., the managing editor of The Trenton Times, were married yesterday in Princeton, N.J. Mayor Barbara Boggs Sigmund of Princeton Borough officiated at the bridegroom's home.

LEAD: Anglican bishops from all over the world are ending a three-week Anglican Conference this weekend convinced that their union of independent churches has been strengthened rather than shipwrecked on issues like the consecration of female bishops and maintaining common church doctrine and authority.

LEAD: THEY MAY BE SWEET strawberry blondes or deep coppery redheads, blondes streaked with bits of rose or brunettes spun with auburn, but red is the captivating hair color of the moment. A year ago, blond was the color of choice. This summer, those who were born red are flaunting it, and those who were not are giving nature a nudge.
LEAD: AFTER John F. Cockerill, a Scarsdale landscaper, spends his usual 40 hours a week fighting Westchester's crabgrass and insects, he spends another 20 hours fighting the politics of pesticides.

LEAD: A well-known Wall Street figure may join the Cabinet as head of the Treasury Department. Nicholas F. Brady has been named to replace James A. Baker 3d, who resigned from the top Treasury post to run Vice President Bush's capaign for the presidency. Mr. Brady, 57 years old, is co-chairman of the Dillon, Read investment house and was the head of the Presidential commission that investigated last October's stock market collapse.
LEAD: A new Boston law on converting rental apartments to condominiums could become a model for other cities, according to advocates for affordable housing and real estate industry spokesmen.
LEAD: FIDDLERS ON STAGE

LEAD: A listing of harness entries in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the race in which the horses were entered. It was not the Hambletonian but the Hambletonian Oaks, which was run Friday night. An account of the Hambletonian appears today in Section 8.
LEAD: PRIVATE DEMONS The Life of Shirley Jackson. By Judy Oppenheimer. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

LEAD: Lynne Beth Cohen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael H. Cohen of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married in Rye Brook, N.Y., last night to Michael William Wolitzer, a son of Faith Wolitzer of North Woodmere, L.I., and the late D. Lawrence Wolitzer. Rabbi Paul Siegel, assisted by Cantor Jerome Holland, performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton.

LEAD: Seeing the sprawling new national Gallery here makes it hard not to wonder if there are not two Moshe Safdies. For there is a world of difference between this building, which is the architect's latest completed work, and the tower he recently designed for Columbus Circle in New York. The massive, angular New York tower, which was not built (it has now been replaced by a different design by another architect), looked as if it would have been a harsh and overpowering presence.

LEAD: Tennis McEnroe Advances: Fifth-seeded John McEnroe was on top of his game and temper in beating No. 15 Robert Seguso, 7-5, 6-3, to reach the finals of the $415,000 United States Hardcourts tournament in Indianapolis. Earlier, top-seeded Boris Becker ended the surprising run of a local hero by beating Todd Witsken, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, in the other semifinal.

LEAD: THE Senate will return in a special session tomorrow to consider a compromise automobile insurance proposal by Governor Kean that could be the Legislature's last chance to do something about rising insurance costs this year.

LEAD: This is an open weekend on the International Motor Sports Association's Camel GT sports car racing circuit, and with one exception all of the teams that contest the races are breathing a collective sigh of relief and using the spare time trying to figure out how to coax more speed out of their cars.

LEAD: JUST when it seemed that the marvelous rivalry between Gary Kasparov, the world champion, and his perpetual challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was about to degenerate into a lopsided thrashing by Kasparov, Karpov has sprung back with a vengeance.

LEAD: THE PASSION. By Jeanette Winterson. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) ''It was Napoleon who had such a passion for chicken that he kept his chefs working around the clock.'' So Jeanette Winterson begins her tale of Henri, who slaughters and serves those chickens, and Villanelle, the sophisticated Venetian whose fate ultimately overtakes the simple soldier's.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Soviet Union hopes to develop an atomic-powered rocket engine to provide the propulsion for a manned mission to Mars early in the 21th century, a Soviet scientist has said.

LEAD: Two brothers turned in their parents to the police Thursday after finding marijuana plants growing behind their house, the police said. The brothers, 11-year-old Timothy Gustafs and 9-year-old Christopher Gustafs, said they acted because they did not want their 15-month-old sister to be exposed to illegal drugs.

LEAD: THE Senate made a significant but paradoxical gesture last month when it unanimously passed a nonbinding resolution acknowledging that the United Nations has been making some important contributions to world peace.

LEAD: THE State Attorney General's office has been handling a growing number of consumer complaints concerning talent, modeling and casting agencies that have set up operations in the state as a result of the booming television and motion picture business.

LEAD: To the Editor: Although superhighways radiate out in all directions from Paris, traveling between them is apt to be on two-lane macadam roads, and if you find yourself behind a bicycle road race, as I did, it's best to forget American standards of highway speed and enjoy the scenery. Finally at Etampes the bike racers took a break and allowed traffic to pass.

LEAD: Q. The kitchen floor in our 1832 farmhouse is covered with layers of linoleum that we are taking off. The wood floor under this appears to be of four-inch-wide pine boards that we want to stain and seal. What is the best way to refinish this floor?

LEAD: At the First Presbyterian Church in New York, Cynthia Chesebrough Hall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Goran L. Hall of Demarest, N.J., and Robert Michael Domine, a son of Annie N. Domine of Durand, Mich., were married yesterday by the Rev. John B. Macnab. Nancy Reynolds Hall was her sister's maid of honor, and Gregory T.

LEAD: Cesar Chavez, head of the United Farm Workers, is suffering from bouts of nausea, dehydration, dizziness, and malnutrition, his doctor said today as Mr. Chavez entered the 21st day of a fast to call attention to his boycott of California table grapes.

LEAD: Dr. Hillary Allison Richardson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Lust of Merrick, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. W. Michael Canning, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Canning of Boynton Beach, Fla. Rabbi Robert Block performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz Hotel.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Red Sox have 32 remaining road games, 8 against the Yankees and Tigers (and 13 on the West Coast). Left-handed relief pitching could be crucial, and the Sox just haven't got it. I'm sure the Yankee left-handed hitters - Mattingly, Washingon, Phelps and Pagliarulo - and the Detroit lefties - Whitaker, Evans, Sheridan and Nokes - are looking forward to their coming games with the Red Sox.

LEAD: ''The Glamour, the Glory and the Glitz of Hollywood,'' an exhibition of 20 costumes worn by some of the movie world's legendary performers, is at the Market at Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 53d Street. The costumes are displayed on look-alike mannequins, and photographs show the artists in scenes from the films.
LEAD: RECOLLECTIONS OF A LIFE By Alger Hiss. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Seaver Books/Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: ''The Mafia Gives Thanks'' was the headline in more than one Italian newspaper this week as judicial and political leaders struggled to prevent a collapse of the nation's most important law enforcement effort, a campaign against the criminal organization.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article on the Vecht River in the Netherlands (Travel, July 10) recommends access to that appealing region merely ''by auto, by bike or by foot.'' But a better way to view that area of ''windmills, castles and dozens of mansions,'' since they ''display their grandest facades to the Vecht,'' is from the water by either barge or boat.

LEAD: STANDING in front of his seventh-grade class, his Hawaiian shirt a burst of color against the chalkboard, Willy straightened his aviator glasses, shifted his weight from foot to foot and held out a 12-ounce can marked ''beer.'' ''Want some?'' he asked the teacher, his voice part bravado, part nervousness.

LEAD: As the flap over Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's mental health indicates, we have created an impossible situation for our political leaders, a situation that undermines both them and the quality of our political life. Few ambitious politicians now dare seek out professional help for psychological, marital, alcohol or drug problems for fear they will be labeled ''mentally unbalanced.

LEAD: South Korean students demanding reunification talks with North Korean students attacked a United States diplomatic office and police stations today in the southern city of Kwangju, news reports said.

LEAD: Publicly, the United States has praised President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica for leading the quest for peace in Central America. But privately, Reagan Administration officials have taken steps to embarrass and undermine him, and have derisively referred to him as ''the laureate,'' according to political leaders here and in Washington.

LEAD: CHILDREN in Moscow may be reading translations of books about Ellis Island and American Indian myths when an exchange of books takes place next year between the United States and the Soviet Union in celebration of the Year of the Young Reader.

LEAD: THE first of a string of rainy days received mixed greetings from the campers and counselors of the Elmwood Day Camp, on Dobbs Ferry Road in White Plains. Boys and girls enthusiastically played ''ga-ga,'' a kickball game suitable for indoors, energetically danced to ''Ballin' the Jack,'' made tile trivots as well as beaded bracelets and played bingo.
LEAD: Jim Kelly moved a step closer to returning to full workouts for the Buffalo Bills yesterday, throwing more than he had since camp opened three weeks ago.
LEAD: IN the patois they so artfully advanced, Daily Variety and the Hollywood Reporter are prepping to boost competish.

LEAD: THE penitentiary at the Westchester County correctional complex here is attempting to help inmates break the cycle of drug dependency and crime through a new 28-day program of intensive alcohol and drug rehabilitation before their release.

LEAD: Billy Casper, who led the United States Senior Open after two rounds, took a bogey and a double-bogey to start today, so he opened the door for Walt Zembriski. LEAD: The world's armies include about 200,000 youths, some as young as 12 years of age, according to a report issued to a United Nations human rights meeting. Governments forcibly conscript many of the youths, the report said, and parents urge others to join to help the family gain food or money.

LEAD: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York, Lisa Susan Green, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Green of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married last night to Dr. Gary Richard Markoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Markoff of Merrick, L.I., and Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Stanley Bramnick officiated. Mrs. Markoff, a second-year student at the New York University School of Law, is a summer intern reporter for The National Law Journal in New York.

LEAD: I WANTED TO give low-income black children the same chance in life - through education - that I had had. I wanted to find out why the schools were not working for them and to help make them work. I was delighted to be assigned as head of an intervention team at two elementary schools, Simeon Baldwin and Martin Luther King Jr.

LEAD: ALL Presidents are part legislator, part statesman and part politician. Last week, it was Ronald Reagan the politician who moved to the center of the White House stage, making two decisions that reflected the urging and the interest of Vice President Bush and his Presidential campaign.

LEAD: Down Under Question: My wife and I are planning to ship our motorcycle to Australia and tour there and in New Zealand. Can you advise on making contact with local organizations that arrange home stays and with motorcycle clubs, and on how to arrange a stay at a sheep or cattle station? -M.
LEAD: Renovation work has begun to turn an Upper West Side hotel into an experimental residence in which homeless teen-age mothers and their children will be housed together with elderly people.

LEAD: ''THE one who survives is the one who connives.'' So goes a lyric from ''The Mandrake,'' which is being called a very loose or free adaptation from a story by Niccolo Machiavelli, ''La Mandragola.''

LEAD: The National Rifle Association promotes itself as an organization of wholesome sportsmen and gun collectors. A recent article in Newsday shows that its adherents also include another type: the inner-city gun runner.

LEAD: Q. The kitchen floor in our 1832 farmhouse is covered with layers of linoleum that we are taking off. The wood floor under this appears to be of four-inch-wide pine boards that we want to stain and seal. What is the best way to refinish this floor?
LEAD: Joseph A. Caruso, founder and chairman of the board of Bar Harbor Airways, died Friday. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: For Red Sox fans, this year is different. A lot of things are coming into place on the field, and the future, if anything, looks brighter than the present. Remember, it was Lou Gorman, the Boston general manager, who initiated all those long-ago plans for a continuously strong Mets team. PENELOPE PRUTSALIS Cambridge, Mass.

LEAD: The Republican Party struck first with a roundhouse pounding: a two-and-a-half-week, 50-state campaign on network, cable and local television costing $4 million.

LEAD: Two generations of reggae style, both full of life, shared a double bill Wednesday at S.O.B.'s, opening a two-night stand. The Meditations, a harmony group formed in 1974, and Ini Kamoze, a singer who made his first record in 1981, led crisply understated bands, putting secure grooves behind the singers' idiosyncratic mixtures of righteousness and playfulness.

LEAD: The Red Sox have given us real thrills. Take, for instance, Dave Henderson's incredible two-out ninth-inning home run in Game 6 of the 1986 playoffs to force a seventh game against the Angels. Moments like that are what being a fan is all about. It's not defeatism, impending doom or the ''Here we go again.

LEAD: With the Bosox hitting (tops in the majors), all they needed was one more solid pitcher to get to the playoffs. They acquired that and more with Boddicker. And when they reach the playoffs, a time where the three-man staff comes into play, Clemens, Hurst and Boddicker will lead the Sox to the championship.

LEAD: Friday's Mostly Mozart program at Avery Fisher Hall provided the first hint that anybody in the concert business here is aware of - or cares about - the 200th anniversary of Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach's death in December. He was an immense force in 18th-century music, though largely ignored today, and the concert by the festival's orchestra under Leopold Hager began with the E-flat Symphony, one of four powerful works in this format written in the mid-1770's.

LEAD: SAYING he believed that a hometown soft drink would help promote South Norwalk, where his parents own a deli, Ray Contone created SoNo Seaport Soda, which uses a common shortening for the area. But the move has angered the maker of a better-known drink, Soho Natural Soda.
LEAD: Amy Michele Savin and Thomas Vincent Ealy, who both received M.B.A. degrees in June from Harvard University, plan to marry Oct. 15.

The stepped-up foreign presence in several major fairs comes at a time when the antiques market is booming and collectors are traveling abroad to acquire the rarest objects.

LEAD: In summer Aspen's intellectual aspirations are as lofty as the surrounding Rockies. At this time of year the town's reputation as a glitzy ski resort is temporarily eclipsed by its image as a cultural center.

LEAD: Mrs. Theodore S. Sloane of Palm Beach, Fla., and Dr. Albert Levy of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Jane Levy, to Joseph Christopher Lewis, a son of Patti Lewis of Bel Air, Calif., and Jerry Lewis of Las Vegas, Nev. The couple plan to marry in December.

LEAD: OCEAN VU, JOG TO BEACH. By Clement Biddle Wood. (St. Martin's, $17.95) According to Clement Biddle Wood, yuppies never identify themselves as such - it is unyuppie-ish to even think the word. Mr. Wood's amusing novel about seven young urban professionals who share a summer home on Long Island's South Fork gently satirizes the mores of this tanned and limber race.

LEAD: SOON after toxic gas escaped from the Union Carbide pesticide plant in Bhopal in 1984, experts predicted that it could take years to untangle the lawsuits surrounding the worst industrial accident in history. Their fears have proven correct.

LEAD: AT a time when many individual investors have fled the stock market in fear, one pack of investors is feverishly raising cash to buy up stocks. Leveraged buyout investors, who buy companies with borrowed capital and then resell them for hefty profits, are furiously piling up billions of dollars.

LEAD: ''MASS APPEAL,'' by Bill C. Davis, seems at first like a routine examination of classic conflicts within the Roman Catholic Church. However, as beautifully detailed in the current production at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, ''Mass Appeal'' uses arguments between traditionalists and reformers as a container to hold complexities that transcend church dogma.

LEAD: An electrical blackout that began late Friday night left thousands of people in Harlem and on the Upper West Side of Manhattan without power yesterday. Power was restored to most customers by 8:06 P.M., but electric utility officials said they could not rule out the possibility of further disruptions.

LEAD: OUTSIDE, the temperature is below zero and the weather is grim. Inside, crowds are gathered in swimsuits on a sandy beach with palm trees. The scene is from the 5.2-million-square-foot West Edmonton Mall, the world's largest, which was developed by the Triple Five Corporation of Alberta, Canada.

LEAD: THE DEVELOPMENT OF BLACK THEATER IN AMERICA: From Shadows to Selves. By Leslie Catherine Sanders. (Louisiana State University, $25.) Leslie Catherine Sanders' new book has much to recommend it: thoughtful, trenchant analysis of black theater in America; informed discussions of certain black playwrights; and a deft exploration of the quest to achieve a ''black stage reality'' beyond the confines of European theatrical conventions.

LEAD: The selection of Jenny Holzer to represent the United States in the 1990 Venice Biennale illuminates a lot more than one admirable artist and the art she has helped to invent. It sheds light on curatorial thinking in the United States and on standards by which American artists are being evaluated.

LEAD: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Catherine M. Zilliox, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Zilliox of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Arthur Wellington Malley 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Hamilton Malley of Greenwich. The Rev. David Riley performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The dismay still clouded Mark Jahner's face as the young farmer looked out over a field he had hoped to see covered with wheat. Now there was nothing there except barren subsoil. The rich topsoil had dried up and blown away, leaving yet another scar from the drought of 1988.
LEAD: ''And on the seventh day the Lord rested, and came to beautiful Wrigley Field, to watch the Chicago Cubs, play His own game, on His own green grass, under His own lights.''

LEAD: Twenty years ago they were together at the Jets' training camp, blending the skills that would win Super Bowl III in one of pro football's historic games. More than 30 of those Jets will be together again tomorrow when the 20th anniversary of that Super Bowl team will be celebrated by the New York chapter of the National Football League Alumni at its annual golf outing at Quaker Ridge in Scarsdale.

LEAD: A NUMBER of years ago when I was newly married, my grandmother came to visit me. I had already learned to turn her off when she started to lecture me about my poor habits, especially when it came to money. After all, she had lived through the Great Depression, and everyone knew her ideas were a little warped.
LEAD: The Lebanese economy is showing signs of recovery despite an increase in factional fighting over the presidential election scheduled this summer.

A few months later, a group of investors led by Reginald F. Lewis, a Wall Street lawyer and financier, bought the Beatrice International Company, a food products company operating mainly in Europe, for nearly $1 billion.

LEAD: YOUNG KATE. By Christopher Andersen. (Hutter/ Holt, $18.95.) For years Katharine Hepburn -a reclusive, independent figure - kept even the Hollywood gossips at bay. Here, in this entertaining, if slight, book based on conversations with Christopher Andersen, a writer and editor, she lets us in on her patrician past.

LEAD: The question would be appropriate if the Yankees had just won 17 of 18 games to cut the Red Sox lead from 9 games to 1. However, because just the opposite has happened, I must respond with a question of my own: ''Where was George?'' STEPHEN J. ZEOLI Westport, Conn.

LEAD: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, accused Republicans today of ''poisoning defense policy with partisan politics.''

LEAD: The leader of the Gurkha separatist movement today formally announced the end of a violent, two-year-long insurgency, the United News of India reported.

LEAD: Wanted: Tenants with jobs for old factory in economically troubled Midwest area. 20,000 to 2 million sq. ft. available. Ideal distribution center. Will improve and subdivide. Very reasonable terms (also state and local incentives). Access to roads, RR, air transportation and markets for millions of Americans.

LEAD: Twenty thousand people live in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn, and on Sundays, after a quiet morning in church or a quick jog through the park, many head for the municipal Marine Park Golf Course. Others navigate their small boats through Mill Basin and out to Jamaica Bay.

LEAD: To the Editor: The piece on Revere Beach brought back happy memories of Sunday forays to that crowded beach with its 5-cent frankfurters and tonic, as we Bostonians called soda pop. Mr. Kotker talks of piles of Coke bottles but in my day Coke was unknown in Boston. Moxie, a strange bitter sweet mixture, was the reigning drink.

LEAD: IF the warm weather has brought out the wanderlust in you, consider the possibility of a pleasant country drive that can yield the further bonus of an attractive concert at your destination.

LEAD: FOR EIGHT YEARS, Greg Hall was ''on the juice.'' Like thousands of athletes and body-builders, he was using anabolic steroids to gain a competitive edge. Now 30 years old, Mr. Hall, a fitness director for a major health and racquet club in Detroit, says that ''the drug nearly killed me.''

LEAD: TRANSPLANT broccoli, cabbage, kale and Brussels sprout seedlings to the vegetable garden; water in well and mulch to keep the soil moist. Resow a half row of beans. Keep up with squash and cucumber harvest. Allow tomatoes to ripen on the plant for best flavor. Chrysanthemums

LEAD: THERE WAS A TIME NOT SO LONG AGO when my hometown of Wichita Falls was known as the worst town in Texas. The novelist Larry McMurtry, a Texan, once had a character call it ''the ugliest place on earth.''

LEAD: I WAS A small child when I heard the words from my neighbor's apartment: ''You shake my nerves and you rattle my brain . . .'' It was in Poland, in 1958, just five years after Stalin's death, and these were the first English words I had ever encountered. My redheaded neighbor, who was a singer, took advantage of the first rustle of freedom and bravely changed her repertoire from the Russian ''Dark Eyes'' to ''Great Balls of Fire.

LEAD: XYZ, a singer, steps out on stage in a music video. He starts a slow, graceful dance, surrounded by women. Dressed in a black hat, leather pants and silver studs, it's obvious that he's trying to build an image, however banal. The music, with a bass line that courses like a river, fits the image. He starts singing, and that too fits.

LEAD: Representative Bill Chappell Jr. lived temporarily at the home of a lobbyist for the General Electric Corporation in 1986, the same year the lawmaker wrote a letter to an Army official regarding a gun contract that the company was seeking, Defense Week magazine reported today.

LEAD: WHEN Americans go shopping these days, their destination is likely to be ashopping mall. They are everywhere. As of 1987, for the first time, the number of shopping centers exceeded the number of post offices or secondary schools - 30,600 nationwide, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, an industry group.

The author and his band of Lexicographic Irregulars (readers and letter writers whose correspondence is also included) are unabashed Nosy Parkers when it comes to language.

LEAD: FROM Greenwich to New London, the hottest topic of conversation this summer is the beaches. And the more people talk about the beaches, and the pollution and medical waste that has fouled them, the more popular pools get.

LEAD: Summer wears on, pollution discourages relief at the seashore and there's every reason to think next summer will be just as uncomfortable. The nonprofit Parks Council, which works on behalf of New York City's parks and waterfront, thus makes a constructive proposal: revive floating pools.

LEAD: Seagate Technology Inc., a Scotts Valley, Calif., manufacturer of hard disk drives, said Friday that two suits had been filed accusing it of securities law violations in connection with public statements the company made from Oct. 13, 1987, to July 20, 1988. The class-action complaints, brought on behalf of everyone who bought Seagate stock in that period, were filed July 29 in United States District Court in San Jose, Calif.

LEAD: The Mets dismantled the Pittsburgh Pirates today with all the old fury, scoring four runs in the ninth inning, beating them for the third straight time and the sixth time in seven games in two weekends, and knocking them into third place. And then even Davey Johnson conceded that the summer's ''slump'' had probably ended.
LEAD: Foreigners will be allowed to trade on China's planned commodities futures markets, the first in a communist country, a senior official said in a newspaper article.

LEAD: A backlash has developed in the investment community to the Mellon Bank Corporation's decision to spin off $1 billion of its bad loans into a separate entity and recapitalize the ''good'' bank that remains.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: More than 100 men, huffing and grunting, hoisted 5,000 pounds of shrine onto their shoulders yesterday and marched through a sweltering Bronx street to commemorate a feast that dates to fifth-century Italy. At the base of the 63-foot shrine, beneath figurines representing Saints Anthony and Joseph, the Blessed Mother, Christ and six cherubs, stood a tearful real-life figure: the grand marshal, Mario
LEAD: It is not, as Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire concedes, the sexiest of political issues. Nor is it, as Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia notes, the ordinary stuff of ''table talk.''

LEAD: Countries of the Soviet bloc are scrambling to negotiate preferential trade agreements with the European Community - agreements that they hope will help lower barriers to imports of badly needed Western technology and foster the creation of joint ventures between Western companies and East bloc enterprises.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Acht! It's the eighth day of the eighth month of the eighty-eighth year of this enervating century, but you're far too slow. The number 8888 sold out faster than any other in the history of the New York State Lottery's Win Four game, all 1,000 tickets gone by 11:37 A.M. on Aug. 1, the first day they were offered.

LEAD: A speeding Formula One racing boat veered out of control in a race on the Allegheny River today, hitting spectators on the bank of the river and injuring 24 people, eight critically. Eleven of the injured were children, the police said.
LEAD: Groups that battle drunken driving say that Larry W. Mahoney, who has been charged in the church bus crash that killed 27 passengers here, is a murderer no different from those who use a gun.

LEAD: Firefighters used crowbars and sledgehammers to free a man who became stuck while trying to crawl down a chimney after he was locked out of a relative's house in the middle of the night. Rodolpho Mohoro, stuck in the chimney about two hours, was treated for abrasions at a hospital and released. The chimney was nearly demolished.

LEAD: J. Skelly Wright, who played an important role in promoting racial desegregation in a long career as a Federal judge, died of prostate cancer Saturday at his home in Westmoreland Hills, Md. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: An article on Friday about gases in ancient amber misidentified a researcher who challenged a report that bubbles of air had been trapped in amber for 80 million years, and misstated his affiliation. He is Dr. Harold B. Hopfenberg of North Carolina State University in Raleigh.

LEAD: Repairs were completed yesterday on the last of five 13,000-volt cables that failed Friday night, knocking out electric power to thousands of customers in Harlem and the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan.
LEAD: Debt Duracell Holdings Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $750 million of debt securities. Duracell was taken private by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co. on June 24.

LEAD: In his first successful outdoor competition since last fall, Ben Johnson ran three 100-meter sprints in less than 24 hours at the Canadian track and field championships: a heat Friday night, then the semifinals and final Saturday afternoon. He won each race, as expected, and posted a winded-aided time of 9.90 seconds in the final.

LEAD: The president of France's state-run railroad resigned today after the second fatal train crash in Paris in six weeks. The Government attributed the crash in part to a failure by officials to move ahead with measures ordered after the earlier wreck.

LEAD: The Dutch Petroleum Company B.V. said last week that it was leading a $1 billion project to build a 177-mile pipeline into the North Sea to speed up exploration of gas reserves. The project is scheduled to come on line in several phases starting in 1991, according to Dutch Petroleum, a joint venture of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Corporation.

LEAD: The first versions of the pedal boat often appeared at amusement parks and hotel beachfronts. These pontoon-based craft, driven by paddle wheels, tended to skid sideways as easily as they moved forward. New technology has improved the idea, harnessing the power of the propeller and adapting it to foot pedals.

LEAD: With the Olympic Games starting less than six weeks from now in Seoul, South Korea, more than a quarter of the United States team is still to be chosen. Trials in the various sports will continue until Aug. 28.

LEAD: In this, the first full summer since Nassau County adopted rules to conserve its dwindling supply of drinking water, residents are taking shorter showers, washing clothes in less water and waking up earlier to water their lawns.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Medcom Partners, largely owned by Park Avenue Publishing, has acquired Illustrated Medicine, from Wynwood Publishing. The publication is Medcom's fourth acquisition since spring. No details of the deal were disclosed. Illustrated Medicine is a single-subject, single-sponsor magazine with a 10-a-year publishing frequency.
LEAD: The contentiousness and turmoil of their Presidential election largely behind them, Mexicans are once again focusing on the country's longest-running drama: the perils of the economy.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Joseph A. Caruso, founder and chairman of the board of Bar Harbor Airways, died Friday. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: Former Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., critical of the long delays that have prevented most death sentences from being carried out, suggested today that legislators reconsider whether capital punishment should be retained.
LEAD: The Soviet Union delivered a firm message today to its nervous ally, Afghanistan, that the removal of Soviet troops would continue on schedule.

LEAD: Nineteen months ago, Ansell-Americas, a maker of health-care products, ushered in a new era in condom marketing with an advertising campaign that was as scary as it was straightforward. ''I'll do a lot for love, but I'm not ready to die for it,'' a sober woman said in the ads for the company's Lifestyles condoms.
LEAD: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: The idea of an audition did not go over well. Richard Dotson considered the years he had spent as a starter - the games he had won and the innings he had pitched -and said openly that he believed it was unfair.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain being greeted with a welcoming song by refugee children as she visited the Site B refugee camp on the Thai border. LEAD: FOR weeks, executives of the entertainment divisions at ABC, CBS and NBC insisted that the fall television season announced in May would be a casualty of the strike against producers by the Writers Guild of America. They scrambled to put together an ''interim season'' that would include reruns, coverage of news and sports events, series that had been completed but shelved, and other programs that could be made outside union jurisdiction.
LEAD: Two people were critically injured and three others were wounded when four men walked up to a group of people in the Bronx and started firing early yesterday, the police said.

LEAD: Broadway producers look forward to the 11 o'clock news and morning newspapers to sample the reviews. John Thompson, the Olympic basketball coach, was eagerly anticipating a viewing of the game films before giving an assessment of his team's exhibition game against National Basketball Association players today at the Civic Center.

LEAD: A popular bumper sticker seen here and in other cities across the interior of Mexico demands, ''Chilangos go home.'' LEAD: Though the Germans are loath to admit it, the long arm of sea pollution has even reached Sylt, an island long famous for its pristine beaches and the summer resort of choice for West Germany's industrialists.

LEAD: The New York City Opera's production of ''Madama Butterfly'' has been in the company's repertory for 21 years, and has long been in need of complete directorial revamping. At the Saturday afternoon performance at the New York State Theater, the first in this season's run, it was clear that the needed face lift was not on the company's agenda: the aimless and inconsistent staging remains so distracting that the work's emotional drama nearly sails by unnoticed.

LEAD: Pressures on the Federal Reserve Board to once again push up short-term interest rates are intensifying, a number of private credit market analysts contend, and the central bank may be forced to act soon, perhaps this week.
LEAD: Bob Knepper allowed five hits in seven and one-third innings today and Houston scored two runs on balks as the Astros beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-2.

LEAD: Ordinarily, the annual commemoration of Herbert Hoover's birth is a distinctly subdued affair, drawing only a smattering of family members and others to the Hoover Presidential Library and Museum in West Branch, Iowa. The nation's 31st President was born in West Branch on Aug. 10, 1874.

LEAD: Official Burmese newspapers were quoted as reporting today that five people were killed and an undetermined number were wounded during anti-Government protests over the weekend. Students in Rangoon, the capital, reportedly called for a nationwide general strike Monday.

LEAD: GIVEN an unfavorable ruling, lawyers can always appeal until they reach the Supreme Court. In a number of recent cases, however, attorneys have tried another tactic: asking the judge to disqualify himself or herself on the basis of conflict of interest.

LEAD: South Korean companies paid $321 million in royalties for high-technology imports from the United States and other countries in the first half of the year, up from $226 million a year earlier, a Finance Ministry report showed today. Officials attributed the sharp increase to South Korea's growing demand for high technology in the electric, electronic and chemical industries.

LEAD: The third-hottest summer in the New York region since 1869, when Ulysses S. Grant was President, is taking its toll on the psychological makeup of an already feverish city, straining civility in offices, automobiles and parks.
LEAD: New York's senators have reversed themselves on the dumping of sludge at sea, saying today that they would co-sponsor a bill outlawing the practice by January 1992.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his delegation escaped unhurt today when a bomb exploded along their motorcade route. Four vehicles were damaged, including the car carrying Mr. Shultz's wife, as the group traveled toward La Paz from the airport. She was unhurt.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were mixed in slow trading yesterday, as dealers prepared for today's start of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.
LEAD: The Duchess of York gave birth today to a daughter, the first child for her and her husband, Prince Andrew, Buckingham Palace announced.

LEAD: The American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals ended here last night with a victory for one of the country's greatest partnerships in the Life Master Pairs. LEAD: Bruce David Kimball, the platform diver who won a silver medal in the 1984 Olympic Games, reportedly had a blood alcohol level of 0.20 percent -twice the legal limit - when his car smashed into a group of more than 30 people, most of them teen-agers, on a dead-end road in Brandon, Fla., last Monday night.

LEAD: About 14,500 Soviet and East German soldiers began joint manuevers today in central East Germany, the state-run East German press agency reported. The press agency did not say how long the war games would last. In Casteau, Belgium, meanwhile, NATO said about 250,000 soldiers, including 17,000 from the United States, will take part in the Western alliance's annual fall maneuvers in Europe.

LEAD: The first half of ''The Music of Tadd Dameron,'' the opening concert of Lincoln Center's ''Classical Jazz'' series on Friday night, was infused with gentleness. This was partly due to Mr. Dameron's compositions, which have an unhurried, calm melodic sense. But it was also due to the musicians - the pianist Tommy Flanagan, the bassist George Mraz, the drummer Kenny Washington and the tenor saxophonist Charlie Rouse.

LEAD: Fair-minded people can only endorse New York City's aim of enforcing a 1 A.M. curfew in Tompkins Square Park, on Manhattan's Lower East Side. Most of the players who will compete -also including Kenny Smith, Shelton Jones, Rodney McCray, Ed Pinckney and Walter Berry - learned the game while growing up in the New York City area.

At the start of ''Clean and Sober,'' Daryl Poynter (Michael Keaton) finds himself at rock bottom: he wakes up with a bad hangover, heavy debts and a comatose stranger in his bed. Daryl's alcohol and cocaine habits are the source of all this trouble, and they might have remained out of control indefinitely. But when Daryl's date fails to wake up at all and his irregular bookkeeping practices are in danger of being discovered, he thinks it wise to stage a temporary retreat. A chemical dependency center with a 21-day detoxification program sounds like just the place. Daryl enters this rehabilitation center with the firm conviction that he does not have a problem. The film, directed by Glenn Gordon Caron, works slowly, carefully and finally quite affectingly to trace the process whereby he discovers otherwise. Though it covers only a monthlong period, ''Clean and Sober'' is so slow and deliberate, approaching its subject in such an intent, realistic manner, that it seems to have spanned several lifetimes.

He said he expected the debt to fall to about $1.4 billion by the end of this year.

LEAD: MY favorite city mouse/country mouse story is the one about the flat tire in the parking lot of the small-town supermarket. Naturally, it happened when the car was carrying two children, nine bags of groceries and no spare, and when I was carrying $11 in cash. The service station across the street called the body shop around the corner, which sent a man to pump the tire up and lead me back to his lot.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday released Don Sutton, the active pitcher with the most victories in the major leagues. Sutton, 43 years old, failed to complete any of his 16 starts this season. He was 3-6 with a 3.92 earned run average. He was on the disabled list with a sprained elbow from June 29 until Tuesday, when he was activated and started against the Cincinnati Reds.

LEAD: Allegations linking Kurt Waldheim to the execution of a British Army officer in Greece in World War II were made today by a Member of Parliament who once worked for Mr. Waldheim and by a British historian who commanded Allied operations in support of the Greek resistance.

LEAD: Jazz musicians rarely get credit for keeping Tin Pan Alley standards current through the rock era. Yet they continue to honor that repertory, both by reclaiming pop melodies with eloquent phrasing and by evading them to reveal ingenious harmonic structures. ''Standards on Horn,'' part of the ''Classical Jazz'' series with Wynton Marsalis as artistic adviser, drew almost equally on pop standards (''Body and Soul,'' ''Embraceable You'') and be-bop tunes (''Confirmation,'' ''Blue Bossa'').

LEAD: At the end of a sun-washed Wall Street, as depicted in the newly issued New York statehood stamp, the spire of Trinity Church rises smartly over the city. The scene is labeled simply ''July 26, 1788.'' That's the problem. Anyone looking west on Wall Street on that date (when New York ratified the Constitution and joined the Union) would have seen - at most - the charred shell of the first Trinity Church, which burned in 1776 and remained in ruins during and after the Revolution.

LEAD: Puma A.G., the West German manufacturer of athletic shoes, has patented electronic running shoes. Each shoe contains a miniature transmitter, receiver and time-counter. As a shoe hits the ground it emits a signal that bounces off the second shoe and returns. A computer, located nearby, monitors these signals and translates them into stride length.

LEAD: Judge Learned Hand once said that if we are to keep our democracy, there must be one commandment: ''Thou shalt not ration justice.'' Yet current national trends, raising the cost of private legal counseling while diminishing the availability of public law services, seem to break this rule. As a consequence, economic constraints, rather than the judge or jury, have become the arbiters of justice.

LEAD: For the last five years, Tracy Austin has been on the outside of women's tennis looking in, waiting for the chance to answer the skeptics who said she would never play competitively again. If we are to believe John Martel, the trial lawyer who is the author of this first novel, it's no joke.
