LEAD: THE ADVENTURES OF TELEMACHUS. By Louis Aragon. Translated by Renee Riese Hubert and Judd D. Hubert. (University of Nebraska, $18.95.) Published in 1922, Louis Aragon's novel ''The Adventures of Telemachus'' occupies a pivotal position in which Dadaism and Surrealism overlap. A subversive Dadaist impulse certainly figured in Aragon's choice of Francois Fenelon's 17th-century prose epic ''Aventures de Telemaque'' for a parodic model, since Fenelon's earnestly moralistic retelling of Homer and Virgil provided a target rich in literary reference and high-mindedness.

LEAD: The organization which has funded the restoration of the Milliken-Bevin Trellis at the Nassau County Fine Arts Museum in Roslyn (more accurately Roslyn Harbor) is the Roslyn Landmark Society, not the Roslyn Historical Society. There is not, and so far as we know, never has been, a Roslyn Historical Society, but this by no means indicates a lack of interest in local history in Roslyn.

LEAD: Coverage by the press of events in Northern Ireland has produced an unintended, and unwelcome, consequence for British authorities - the awakening of conscience among Americans of Irish descent. Non-jury trials, detention without cause, mistreatment of prisoners, official cover-ups and sanctioning of police and military brutality are but some of the more recent examples of an atavistic Whitehall meanness toward the Irish people that are provoking anger among normally passive Irish-Americans.

LEAD: Otto E. Passman, an acid-tongued son of Louisiana sharecroppers who served in Congress for 30 years and pursued a relentless battle against spending for foreign aid, died yesterday at a hospital near his home in Monroe, La. He was 88 years old.

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor said today that he did not have to call for a boycott of the controversial movie ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' because sensible Christians would avoid it on their own. During a homily at a Mass at the Don Bosco Marian Shrine, the Cardinal said he had received many letters asking him to call for a boycott of the film, which portrays Christ as a man who questions his role on Earth.

LEAD: WE all have our demons, our fears of the decline and fall of culture. Mine sometimes takes the form of regretting that we don't read much poetry anymore. Where will our flair come from, I sometimes wonder, our hyperbole, our mots justes? Unless we read poetry, we'll never have our hearts broken by language, which is an indispensable preliminary to a civilized life.

LEAD: The leader of an eight-year-old insurgency in the northeastern state of Tripura who signed a peace accord with the Indian Government on Friday said today that he would press for the deportation of tens of thousands of illegal immigrants from Bangladesh.

LEAD: The engagement of Ellen R. Dickman and Steven Koch has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Irwin L. Dickman of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Koch of New York.

LEAD: For the Mets, the sins had been bunched into one unforgivable inning, the first. There were three stolen bases, three walks, a wild pitch, a balk and an error. For the Expos, there were four unexpected, unearned, but totally appreciated runs.

LEAD: I was pleasantly surprised by Peter Maas's article on Northern Ireland (''Generations of Torment,'' July 10). I applaud him for his honesty and dispassionate objectivity.

LEAD: The Central Park Summerstage festival got off to an uncharacteristically late start on Friday night at the Central Park Band Shell when a generator caught fire and delayed the show. But the show was worth the wait, for ''The Ringdove,'' a new piece by Ralph Lee and his Mettawee River Company, had all the charm and interest of a loose-structured bedtime story.

LEAD: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain which we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then tried rubbing with fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years).

The Rev. Peter Ohrt, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at Dragsholm Castle in Horve, Denmark.

LEAD: Elmo R. Zumwalt 3d, son of the admiral who ordered the spraying of Agent Orange in Vietnam, and who was exposed to the defoliant himself, died of cancer today at his home. He was 42 years old.
LEAD: THE last thing Vicki Stroby wanted in her city was a bar with nude dancing.

LEAD: THE scene is about the same wherever you go along the shoreline on Long Island - driftwood, healthy seaweed and roaming sea birds have become the exception. In their place in recent years is a sorrowfully changed environment.
LEAD: At the crest of Nigeria's oil boom, in the early 1980's, radio transmitters of the Voice of Nigeria broadcast the voice of Africa's giant to the four corners of the world.

LEAD: Last Thursday, Cray Research Inc. announced the first sale of its new supercomputer, the Cray 3, to the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, which gets much of its financing from the National Science Foundation. The new machine, which will perform 16 billion calculations a second, will not be delivered until 1990.

LEAD: IT has been 10 years since Dennis Kucinich, dubbed Cleveland's ''boy mayor'' when he was elected at age 31, won a recall election by 236 votes. Within months, Cleveland became the first American city to plunge into default since the Depression.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Ariane Wellin of Greenwich, Conn., and Adrian P. Reed of Centreville, Md., and Hobe Sound, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Elizabeth Reed to David Eliot Klein, the son of Mrs. David A. Klein of Stockbridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Klein. The couple plan to marry Nov.

LEAD: The marriage of Katherine Lattimore Bourne to Frank Bray Gibney Jr. took place yesterday at the home of the bride's father, Donald W. Bourne, in Waquoit, Mass. The Rev. Robert Thomas, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

LEAD: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who had been seeking a left-handed starting pitcher for several weeks, obtained Dave LaPoint from the Chicago White Sox today. The Pirates sent Barry Jones, a right-handed reliever, to Chicago.

LEAD: GLENN MILLER SOUND The Glenn Miller Orchestra - authorized by the Miller estate to carry on the big band sound and tradition of the bandleader who was on an aircraft when it disappeared in 1944 - will perform at the Ocean Grove Auditorium Saturday evening.

LEAD: AUTOMATIC focusing has become so much a part of the photography scene that it's easy to take for granted. Certainly no self-respecting camera buff would admit to ignorance of the subject. But for many people facing the prospect of buying a modern camera for the first time, the entire notion remains mysterious.

LEAD: THE world champion, Gary Kasparov, and his four-time opponent for the title, Anatoly Karpov, are poles apart on the question of defense: Whereas Karpov believes it is just something to get through without losing, Kasparov believes it presents another opportunity to win.

LEAD: Eleanore Hopkins Kuhn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Kuhn of Salisbury, Conn., was a married there yesterday to Matthew Gordon Boyse, a son of Mrs. W. E. Boyse of Grosse Pointe, Mich. and the late Mr. Boyse. The Rev. Charles Bevan performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: The fundamental flaw in your article ''Pushing Cigarettes Overseas'' (July 10) is Peter Schmeisser's inability to distinguish between health policy and trade policy. Our trade policy is simple and straightforward. We want the same market access and treatment for United States tobacco products that is afforded to the tobacco companies of the country in question.
LEAD: To the Editor: I read with keen interest ''Eating a Path Through the Pyrenees'' by G. Franco Romagnoli (Travel, June 26). However, there is a historical inaccuracy.

LEAD: The marriage of Suzette Lai Ung Fong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archie Fook Tse Fong of Honolulu, to Douglas Warren Elliott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Harrison Elliott of Brooklyn, took place yesterday in Los Angeles. The Rev. Norman Ishizaki performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church.
LEAD: It has been a year of last hurrahs for Ronald Reagan as his active political career edges ever closer to its end.

LEAD: AN $85 million waterfront condominium, with 21 apartments priced at more than $1 million, will open on the Charles River here next summer, capping the transformation of a onetime research and development district on this city's east side.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE END OF IDEOLOGY: On the Exhaustion of Political Ideas in the Fifties, by Daniel Bell. (Harvard University, $10.95.) In a new afterword, the sociologist Daniel Bell looks back on the decades since this collection of essays was published, finding still more signs of the dangers that come when ideas enslave minds.

LEAD: Two bills, one in the House of Representatives and one in the Senate, call for raising the minimum wage, now at $3.35 an hour. The House version would raise it by 40 cents a year until it reaches $4.55. Sar Levitan, professor of economics at George Washington University and director of the Center for Social Policy, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about America's declining wages and the need to increase the minimum wage.
LEAD: People thought to be Basque terrorists set off bombs at six French car dealerships and a dairy in northern Spain today, causing extensive damage but no injuries, Government officials said.
LEAD: Six weeks now.

LEAD: THE needles, syringes and other medical waste that have washed up on beaches this summer point to a larger problem confronting every medical institution: how to deal with infectious wastes that are increasingly barred from the hospitals' own incinerators.

LEAD: While most of the Jets and Giants players agreed during the week that tonight's meeting between the teams was just another preseason game, the Giants' 24-21 victory produced a few key revelations for both teams.

LEAD: ONE of the greatest battles in contract bridge history ended in Salt Lake City eight days ago near the end of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.
LEAD: Comdr. and Mrs. L. F. Rolen of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Gwen Rolen to Douglas Layton Furth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Furth of White Plains.

LEAD: ''Beach Waste Raises New Fears'' [ July 17 ] makes me feel an even stronger urgency about this problem. Ocean dumping of all refuse must end. Land dumping of all refuse must end.

LEAD: BEFORE an office tower goes up, it must go down - far enough for a rock-solid foundation. Far enough to expose a subterranean stew of manmade trouble - sewers, subway lines, highway tunnels, electrical substations, water mains, gas lines, diverted streams and assorted relics of the urban underground.

LEAD: Rangoon was reportedly returning to normal today after the resignation Friday of the new Burmese leader, U Sein Lwin. Mr. Sein Lwin's resignation was forced by five days of protests in which hundreds of people were shot to death by soldiers.

LEAD: At the top of the stretch at Saratoga Race Track today, Maplejinsky was clinging to a slim lead and three of her four rivals in the Alabama Stakes were drawing closer. But when the finish line came up, Maplejinsky, who had led from the start, was still in front.

LEAD: JUST how explicit should the new state-mandated AIDS curriculum be in teaching the use of condoms? The Three Village School District will address that issue Tuesday when the Board of Education meets to consider whether students at the Ward Melville High School in Setauket will be taught the ''Ten Recommendations for the Proper Use of Condoms.

LEAD: FOR years, the storage areas at Harvard's Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology were cluttered. ''Access to the collection was poor,'' recalls Una McDowell, the director of the museum's collections department. ''Things were cramped and difficult to get at.''

LEAD: Cordelia Frances Biddle, a freelance writer, and H. Stephen Zettler, an actor, were married yesterday in Fishers Island Sound off Connecticut aboard the M.V. Munnatawket, a ferryboat. William F. Henderson 3d, the purser and a Justice of the Peace in Waterford, Conn., performed the ceremony.
LEAD: FOR 23 seasons, Robin Sanders has endured heavy seas and hard times along the South Carolina coast, where he trawls the warm ocean shallows for shrimp.

LEAD: Written and photographed by Lou Stoumen, who has won two Academy Awards as a producer of documentaries, JOURNEY TO LAND'S END: A Paper Movie (Celestial Arts, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95) is a hip little fable for adults that takes a sad and humorous trip to the polluted End of the World, with time out for Love along the way.

LEAD: With the footwear industry reinstating the plain, classic pump, accessory designers are competing for a foothold in the shoe-ornament trade. Design Circle Ltd. of Dix Hills, N.Y., for example, carries 150 handmade styles in silk, lace and suede. The clips, which cost $15 to $30 a pair, are sold at shoe, jewelry and bridal boutiques, some pharmacies and even antique stores.

LEAD: When the sun rose over Tompkins Square Park last Sunday after a long, hot, angry night, broken glass and bloodied brows bore witness to the most violent conflict between the police and a crowd in New York City in years.

LEAD: ADULT day-care centers are cheaper than a nursing center, offer more than a senior citizens' center and are growing in popularity in Connecticut, their advocates say. While the centers allow many frail, elderly people who cannot care for themselves to live at home, they can also give the person who cares for an elderly person a welcome respite.
LEAD: Richard S. Mitchell has what some people call the best job of all the 210,000 employees of the New York State government.

LEAD: I'VE always anticipated the effortless, reassuring hug from my father, the kind that Gregory Peck as Atticus Finch delivers so easily to Scout in ''To Kill a Mockingbird.'' Twilight on the veranda, father to daughter, sitting shoulder to top of head.

LEAD: The United States Olympic swimming trials ended tonight with American records for Angel Myers and David Wharton and glory for Mary T. Meagher. They also ended with sadness for some fallen heroes of the past, notably Pablo Morales.

LEAD: While women have become commonplace in the work force - whether in coal mines or the executive suite - they continue to encounter obstacles. But as their numbers expand and their experience broadens, they are developing new ways of coping.
LEAD: Federal law-enforcement agents have seized more than $1 million in property belonging to convicted drug dealers who allegedly bought it with the profits from illegal drug sales.

LEAD: Sarah Allen Strickler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Strickler of Killingworth, Conn., and Jonathan Seth Cole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray L. LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

Rodgers, personnel director at the Rawlplug Company in New Rochelle. ''But when it came to filling out the forms, he couldn't do them. And he couldn't complete what was essentially a third-grade math problem, either.

LEAD: A retired costume-jewelry salesman, Michael M. Katz, 76 years old, is so inept with tools ''he can't knock a nail in the wall,'' his wife, Rose, says. Mrs. Katz, 74, is not much handier. So what is she to do when the bathroom faucet starts leaking and the fluorescent light in the kitchen will not go on?

LEAD: In the article ''Managing Electric Use: A Strain After Shoreham'' [ July 31 ] , a Lilco spokesman is quoted as saying that the company is operating its plants at up to 99 percent of their total capacity during peak periods. It is clear that the power supply for current customers is in a precarious state.

LEAD: Investors who try to predict the stock market's direction by studying such fundamentals as corporate earnings and interest rates are not alone in their current confusion. Technicians, analysts who instead scrutinize the market's inner workings, also have wildly different forecasts.

LEAD: Around the world, peace seens suddenly to be breaking out as several bloody conflicts simultaneously begin winding down. In Afghanistan, in Angola, in Southeast Asia, in the Persian Gulf, soldiers are laying down their arms, or talking about doing so. The reasons are varied, including national exhaustion, economic imperatives and a lessening of rivalry between the superpowers.

LEAD: EVENTUALLY, almost all mortar joints in brick masonry deteriorate. Prompt repair is required, because even small cracks and crumbled areas admit moisture, which in time can cause major damage, especially in regions where freezing occurs.

LEAD: Consideration of a disputed proposal to build an entertainment and amusement complex on Federal park land in Queens has been put off for at least a year while the Government conducts an environmental impact study.

LEAD: Between 6 and 10 track and field athletes who failed drug tests at the United States Olympic Trials in Indianapolis last month will not be barred from competing in the Summer Games because the drug use was either ''pre-declared'' or ''inadvertent,'' according to Mike Moran, a United States Olympic Committee spokesman.

LEAD: Two buses collided in northern Iran, killing 30 people and injuring 50, the Teheran radio reported today. The radio also said two strong earthquakes jolted the southern city of Bushehr, with no injuries or damage immediately reported. The two buses collided on the heavily traveled Teheran-Tabriz highway Friday, the report said.

LEAD: THE Senate passed a compromise automobile insurance bill last week that its designers say will curb rising insurance premiums and sent the measure, and the political problem it represents, to the Assembly.
LEAD: Little by little, I'm bringing my mother into my house.

LEAD: Diplomats in North Africa have welcomed a United Nations proposal for resolving a 13-year war between Morocco and the Polisario Front in the former Spanish colony of Western Sahara, but the officials were also cautious regarding any quick settlement.

LEAD: At the Seven Hills Country Inn in Lenox, Mass., Ronna Lynn Tulgan, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Tulgan of Pittsfield, Mass., was married last evening to Thomas Winslow Ostheimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Ostheimer of York, Me. Rabbi Alan Berg officiated. Mrs. Ostheimer, who will retain her name professionally, graduated from Miss Hall's School and William Smith College.

LEAD: For more than three years of rule by Mikhail Gorbachev, Soviet leaders have argued publicly about virtually everything - except foreign policy. Yegor Ligachev, the Kremlin's No. 2, recently shook that apparent consensus with a frontal assault.

LEAD: New Orleans in August? Why not? The climate indoors is cool. And outdoors the pace is leisurely. For some New Orleanians, August has certain advantages, allowing plenty of excuses to relax in a leafy patio, schedule fewer appointments, lengthen the lunch hour and savor fine cooking.

LEAD: Neil Young has a simple reason for not joining some fellow rock stars in singing for commercials: ''I don't sing for nobody/ Makes me look like a joke,'' he declares in ''This Note's for You.'' He didn't suggest that making commercials ruins songs and betrays fans, or insist that advertising should leave rock alone, or snarl at the commercial tie-ins that infest most American cultural events.

LEAD: COLONIAL FURNISHINGS A look behind the scenes at the Yale University Art Gallery furniture collection is offered to those with reservations for a free lecture and tour at 2 P.M. Tuesday and 1 P.M. Thursday.

LEAD: The final concert of the Tanglewood Festival of Contemporary Music tonight was a satisfyingly varied program, played by the student orchestra of the Tanglewood Music Center and led, in all but one work, by Oliver Knussen, the British composer who has overseen this new-music festival the last few summers.

LEAD: Tomorrow morning in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, worlds away from bedroom views of the Statue of Liberty, work will begin on the first city-owned shells to be renovated using surplus Battery Park City revenues.

LEAD: President Reagan plans to appoint Sherwin T. Chan to fill the vacancy on the Civil Rights Commission left by the death in June of Clarence M. Pendleton, the White House said today. The President appointed William Barclay Allen, a professor of government at Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, Calif., to succeed Mr.
LEAD: Balks are back. Not that they have ever gone away since they burst on the season like a tidal wave of beach pollution, but they had seemed to fade from the forefront of everyone's attention.

LEAD: While fishing this spring with a young Maine guide, the conversation turned to fall grouse hunting and shotgun shooting in general. The guide said he did not shoot skeet, trap or any of the shotgun games because, ''I can't seem to hit clay targets, but I do very well on live birds.''

LEAD: The facade of every house in Guarda, in the Lower Engadine, is boldly painted, sometimes with whimsical creatures, sometimes with elegant geometric designs. The big white-washed houses are set close together on cobbled streets that occasionally widen into little squares centered on a fountain. Green slopes rise on every side of the compact village: the main street ends abruptly in fields and meadows, and across the narrow valley stands a wall of rugged mountains.

LEAD: When Kitty Wells, country music's first woman superstar, started her career in the mid-40's, American culture was changing. Because of the war, families who had stayed near home for generations experienced life beyond their farms. Blacks and women were allowed into workplaces they'd never been before.

Finish garden plans and mail orders for fall-flowering bulbs.

LEAD: A ranking aide to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization is seriously considering proclaiming an independent Palestinian state and government, presumably in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: Ethnic Pathan transportation workers set fire to buses of a rival group today, setting off widespread rioting throughout the city in which 7 people died and at least 12 were injured, hospital reports and witnesses said.
LEAD: To the Editor: Excellent piece on going-away arrangements (Practical Traveler, June 12) except for advice about having the Post Office hold mail.

Some say they ''only'' pulled a woman's hair or shoved her - never intending to break the woman's arm. Others blame the women for their actions and continue to deny that their behavior is abusive.

LEAD: Tennis Lendl Beats Connors: Ivan Lendl defeated Jimmy Connors, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday to advance to the final of the Player's International tournament in Toronto. Lendl, the defending champion, overcame Connors in a 2-hour-10-minute match played in 104-degree heat at the National Tennis Centre at York University.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Phoenix Suns have signed their first-round draft pick, Dan Majerle, to a five-year contract.
LEAD: From her log home in this Champlain Valley town, Fay Honey Knopp, a 70-year-old Quaker minister, regularly corresponds with nearly four dozen prison inmates. Several are sex offenders.

LEAD: Fifteen years ago, the National Association for Female Executives was started to help women learn such business skills as writing resumes, asking for raises and surviving office politics. Its members are mostly white-collar workers who earn $32,000 on average. Now, the group has decided to bet its own money on its members and has set up a venture capital program for entrepreneurial women.

LEAD: To the Editor: Marcia Lieberman's article about climbing the Breithorn in Zermatt, Switzerland (Travel, July 3), was exciting, but there are a myriad of other walking opportunities in Zermatt. There are over 280 miles of marked trails and many more unmarked ones. With cable cars and even an underground lift, one can reach the higher altitudes in a matter of minutes.

LEAD: If George Steinbrenner feels unappreciated in New York, he can take comfort in the likelihood that he is still probably more popular than Walter O'Malley. For the younger set, O'Malley was the last owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers, a franchise beloved by its borough, more successful than any other in the National League after World War II, and richer than any other in baseball including the Yankees.

LEAD: A SIMPLE summer lunch or supper is easily accomplished. Fresh ingredients such as tomatoes, peppers, herbs and peaches are abundant in the markets now. Combined with fresh fish, the menu is appropriately light yet satisfying, low in fat and attractive.
LEAD: Barry Bonds hit two homers and drove in a career-high five runs tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 10-4.

LEAD: The woman who placed first two years ago in the final standing of the Mobil Grand Prix, Yordanka Donkova of Bulgaria, moved into a three-way tie for first place after winning the 100-meter hurdles in 12.45 seconds at the Budapest Grand Prix Friday evening. She is tied with Grace Jackson, a sprinter from Jamaica, and Petra Felke, an East German javelin thrower, both of whom did not compete in

LEAD: Stop for a moment and consider what a wonderful thing Governor Cuomo and the New York Legislature have now accomplished by enacting the Governor's Liberty Scholarship program. Forget all the passing urgencies of the moment; 10 and 20 years from now, this is one act that New Yorkers will remember, and with gratitude.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''NYACK is a place that's growing up and coming out of adolescence,'' said Bunny Crumpacker, the author of The Guide to the Nyacks.

LEAD: FOR a brief time, it appeared that racially motivated violence in New York City would forge a common purpose among blacks who usually disagreed over personalities, politics and tactics. That budding unity - which had obvious implications for next year's municipal elections - has been torn apart by the case of Tawana Brawley.

LEAD: Jeff Michels, a weight lifter who has always set goals for himself, figured he was about two years away from setting a few world records when he went to Caracas for the 1983 Pan American Games. Winning three gold medals gave him that much more assurance he was on schedule.

LEAD: CHRISTINE CRAFT, the television anchorwoman who went to court when her employer said she was too old and too unattractive to go on the air, wants to go back to court, this time for good. But only after she goes to law school.

LEAD: The line of heirs to the British throne got a little longer last week. The Duke and Duchess of York had their first child, a 6-pound, 12-ounce girl. Andrew, the 28-year-old Duke of York and second son of Queen Elizabeth II, was with his wife, Sarah, when the as yet unnamed Princess of York, fifth in line to the throne, was born Monday at 8:18 P.M.

LEAD: RUPERT MURDOCH has not lost his ability to astound. Mr. Murdoch, who has gobbled up publishing and entertainment properties in remarkably large bites, announced his biggest deal yet last week: an agreement to buy Triangle Publications, publisher of TV Guide, from Walter H. Annenberg for $3 billion.

LEAD: The delegates to the Republican National Convention are a very conservative group, separated by a vast ideological chasm from the Democrats who met in Atlanta, a poll conducted by The New York Times shows.

LEAD: With beaches closing along the Shore because of medical and other waste, New Jerseyans have been turning to backyard pools for relief, creating a boom in sales of in-ground and above-ground models.

LEAD: THE duck farmer sold his last duck some time ago and the truck farmer is losing enthusiasm for his lettuce and cabbages. Both of them now hunger for the profits to be made from that biggest cash crop of all: the housing development.

LEAD: AS investigators continue to search for sources of this summer's beach pollution and strategies to combat it, Long Island officials and business leaders fear that this year's drop in tourism could persist next year.
LEAD: If baseball were really this simple, half the athletes in North America would be waiting by the telephone for the mysterious Joe to call them, the way he called Gary Carter the other day.
LEAD: A year after the signing of a Central American peace plan, the confrontation that has torn Nicaragua for most of this decade seems little nearer to a permanent resolution.

LEAD: The Boston Red Sox won their 24th straight game at Fenway Park today, tying the second-longest home winning streak in major league history. Dwight Evans drove in a career-high seven runs with two homers and a bases-loaded triple in a 16-4 rout of the Detroit Tigers.

LEAD: West German protesters threw tomatoes and eggs at East German guards at the Berlin wall and Communist police hauled away protesting East German youths today as both sides marked the barrier's 27th anniversary.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: POLITICAL PASSAGES Journeys of Change Through Two Decades 1968-1988. Edited by John H. Bunzel. With an Introductory Essay by Edward Shils. 354 pp. New York: The Free Press. $21.95. $ TTHIS book will probably remind a lot of people of ''The God That Failed'' or ''Witness'' by Whittaker Chambers or Norman Podhoretz's ''Breaking Ranks'' or some other entry in the growing library of up-from-leftism confessionals.
LEAD: BEYOND MALICE The Media's Years of Reckoning. By Richard M. Clurman. 306 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Transaction Books. $24.95.

LEAD: HUGH L. McCOLL JR. learned a long time ago about the danger of confronting big challenges head-on. Some 30 years ago, on the lacrosse fields at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, he was bashed so hard by an opposing player that he was knocked unconscious.
LEAD: BIOLOGICAL FLUTES

LEAD: We appreciate Peter Schmeisser's article. The fact that so-called responsible leaders both in government and industry can ''push'' cigarettes when they know that smoking is ''as addictive as heroin'' and that it significantly increases the risk of illness and death suggests a serious flaw in the character of those leaders.

LEAD: More than 150 years after Americans in covered wagons began opening up the lands west of the Mississippi, a new brand of adventurers is out in force this summer on one of the continent's last frontiers.

LEAD: Paul Azinger made a hole-in-one at the 202-yard fourth hole of Oak Tree Golf Club today with a 6-iron, then barely hung on to maintain his one-shot lead in the third round of the PGA Championship.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration will begin applying new regulations that deny Federal money to family planning clinics that give women information about abortion unless the clinics are covered by court injunctions against the regulations.

LEAD: To the Editor: Readers who plan to do any driving in Italy and who speak little or no Italian can save themselves some grief by memorizing the phrases that appear at tunnel entrances along the Autostrade. Those with enough Italian will recognize immediately that the signs instruct drivers to turn on their headlights in the many tunnels through which the Autostrade run.
LEAD: Saint's Remains Stolen in Maine

LEAD: ''For people like us, in our early thirties, we've had to leverage ourselves to our eyeballs to get housing at all. After the down payment, who's got any extra cash to put into savings?'' -Diane Schmidt-Fellner, of Norwalk, Conn., on rising interest rates.

LEAD: Home on Montauk Range If Gardner (Rusty) Leaver has his way, Western movies may soon be a misnomer. One look at the Montauk-based Mr. Leaver, resplendent in cowboy hat and ankle-length ''duster'' coat, sitting astride his cutting horse, Slingshot Cody, and ''Easterns'' may seem more appropriate for cowboy films.

LEAD: The Jura, in the northwest corner of Switzerland, is all wide, rolling valleys, good-sized climbs and descents and primal surroundings of unending green in the summer and gaudy colors in the fall. The gypsy wagon, called the zigeunerwagen in German, is an old, accepted mode of transport in the Jura, which is horse country.
LEAD: When Sue Davis fires up her favorite touring car, it's more than a figure of speech.

LEAD: Elizabeth Beatty Sanford, a daughter of Mrs. Kenneth B. Beatty of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Machipongo, Va., and the late Mr. Beatty, was married yesterday to Cornelius Brett Boocock Jr., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Boocock of Mantoloking, N.J. The Rev. Edward S. Prevost performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St.
LEAD: Like most visitors to Paris, I'd always relied on the Metro to get around.

LEAD: Two men who died of heatstroke after running 3.5-mile races in Central Park this summer were not the first fatalities associated with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge races, Fred Lebow said yesterday.

LEAD: At the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church in Washington, Florence Carnet Branson, a daughter of James Taylor Branson Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Florence Crowley Branson, was married yesterday to Robert Kedar Bryan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cavenaugh Bryan of Dunn, N.C. LEAD: THE founders of the Furniture Training Institute in Queens thought they had a formula for certain success: free instruction, hundreds of jobs to be filled and a pool of thousands of unemployed New Yorkers from which to draw trainees.
LEAD: A CRIME OF SELF-DEFENSE Bernhard Goetz and the Law on Trial. By George P. Fletcher. 253 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

LEAD: Edward Bennett Williams, a celebrated trial lawyer and influential Washington insider whose clients included the teamsters leader James R. Hoffa to Senator Joseph McCarthy, died today after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: The marriage of Ann Katherine Hackeling, a daughter of Paula W. Hackeling and John C. Hackeling, both of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., to Geoffrey Scott Baker, a son of Ann M. Baker of Hilton Head Island, S.C., and Melvin C. Baker of Washington, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's mother. Justice Kenneth K.

LEAD: FOR a century and a half, United States Governments and citizens have argued about the country's role in Central America. How do they reconcile North American interests with Central American sovereignty? How deep and direct should United States involvement be? How much should Americans presume to direct these other lands in methods of governing themselves, even if the ostensible motive is to promote democracy?
LEAD: THE RAGMAN'S SON An Autobiography. By Kirk Douglas. 510 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.
LEAD: THERE are no pottery shops in Moveros. Yet this tiny village, about 150 miles northwest of Madrid, is renowned for its ceramics, sold in the homes of the women who make them.

LEAD: I am writing about James Feron's article on the State Senate campaign between Senator Nicholas A.Spano and County Legislator Paul J. Feiner [ ''Feiner Begins His Challenge for Spano's State Senate Seat,'' July 17 ] .
LEAD: THE war between Iran and Iraq, one of the bloodiest conflicts of this murderous century, was sputtering last week to a stalemated conclusion.
LEAD: IT is hail-and-farewell time for both the Westchester Chamber and the Caramoor Festivals, and interestingly, the strictly classical fare at both is about to be tempered with a little jazz.

LEAD: LAST MONTH, WHEN RIDERS IN the Tour de France, the famed annual bicycle marathon, swept onto Paris's grandest boulevard, the Champs-Elysees, television viewers saw the final moments of the race against an oddly gorgeous backdrop: the Arc de Triomphe, that stately symbol of the French Republic, cloaked in tricolored drapery.

LEAD: Peter Maas might have consulted the Provisional Irish Republican Army's own document ''Eire Nua'' to see that it is very much Marxist in nature, closer in political spirit to, say, Cuba or Nicaragua than to the present system of government that holds in the Irish Republic.

LEAD: Love is all-consuming in Bryan Ferry's songs; it's a raw need like drug addiction, a spiritual sacrament, a paradise and an eerie limbo. His concert Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall, starting a three-night stand, opened with a swirl and chatter of percussion and the sight of a censer wafting the smoke of frankincense - invoking a ritual - as Mr.

LEAD: Republicans made final preparations today for a national convention that is intended to establish Vice President Bush as the credible heir to President Reagan and to heighten public anxiety about Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, who has been running ahead of Mr. Bush for most of this year.

LEAD: JOHN K. CASTLE has grown up in the world of leveraged buyouts. He joined the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in 1965 and a few years later made his mark at age 28 as head of the firm's Sprout Group, then one of the largest venture capital operations in the United States.

LEAD: People think they know all about Henri Matisse, but most often they don't. None of the great painter/sculptor/printmakers of the 20th century has more surprises to spring when a major retrospective comes along. The most recent example of that is the unforgettable survey of his years in Nice that was put on at the National Gallery of Art in Washington by Jack Cowart and Dominique Fourcade in 1986.
LEAD: Marilyn Goodreau works from noon to midnight taking care of 9 horses, 6 ponies, 5 goats, 2 geese, a rabbit and a rooster on 200 acres of rolling farmland here in southern Maine.
LEAD: Anyone who has recently spent a Sunday prowling New Orleans will find it hard to believe, but once there were no jazz brunches.

LEAD: Mr. Williams, considered a brilliant ''superlawyer'' who stood as a pillar of the Washington establishment, had no particular political power bloc of his own, but Republicans and Democrats sought his friendship and counsel, and he seemed always to be in good standing with the occupant of the White House Oval Office.
LEAD: IN the 1920's, an outbreak of hoof-and-mouth disease wiped out nearly all the dairy cattle in Long Beach, Calif. Now that epidemic is coming back to haunt homeowners.

LEAD: The longing for peace and liberation after seven decades of South African rule - 17 years of it illegal in terms of international law - is shared by the overwhelming majority of the 1.2 million people of this sparsely populated mineral-producing territory.

LEAD: A visitor to this summer's Bayreuth Festival, the Wagnerian shrine inaugurated in 1876 by the composer himself and located in this eminently pleasant northern Bavarian town, would have been hard pressed to detect signs of endemic ill health.

LEAD: Adele Anderson, Dillie Keane and Denise Wharmby - the musical comedy trio who call themselves Fascinating Aida - represent a kind of wacky music-hall humor that seems very much a British home-grown style.
LEAD: Jerome Kidder, a retired judge of the New York City Criminal Court, died Thursday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

LEAD: The River Road, which follows the Mississippi to New Orleans, evokes the elegance and prosperity of this part of Louisiana before the Civil War. The road was once lined with grand homes and working plantations, live oaks and magnolias. LEAD: Chicken is to Kiev what baked beans are to Boston. Having survived a revolution, several purges and now perestroika, chicken Kiev is still the best-known dish in the capital city of the Ukraine. Ask any Intourist guide.
LEAD: It was shaping up to be the pool party of the summer until two uninvited guests - lightning and thunder -dropped in.

LEAD: Not only have I read your article [ ''Stealing the Stone Walls of Westchester,'' June 12 ] with quite a bit of interest, but I believe that you might want to send a professional photographer to our village here in Hastings. On Broadway, just two or three blocks south of the intersection with the Farragut Parkway, the stone walls that border on the (Billie) Burke

LEAD: A referendum today showed continued strong opposition to return gambling to this island where casinos once flourished. Supporters had hoped that a favorable vote would persuade the Texas Legislature to pass legislation enabling legalized gambling. Unofficial returns from all 14 precincts showed 7,368 votes, or 59.3 percent, against legalized casino gambling to 5,962 votes in favor.

LEAD: The red brick building crowned with a crystal dome, its shell gable characteristic of Dutch classic style, carries a single clue to its past as a house of worship. Two lines from the Psalms, inscribed in Hebrew letters, flank the Ionic columns of the main doorway on the Jonas Daniel Meijerplein.
LEAD: Yellowstone Visitors Face Road Closings

LEAD: When Cuauhtemoc Cardenas broke with Mexico's ruling party to run for President in last month's election, he quickly became a nonperson as far as the political establishment was concerned. Now his father, a revered former President, and a founder of that same party, appears to be getting the same treatment.
LEAD: All the beaches in this town on Long Island Sound have been open all summer, and the local health department says that the water is cleaner than it has been for years. But beachgoers are wary.

LEAD: Empire of the Sun Starring Christian Bale, John Malkovich, Miranda Richardson, Joe Pantoliano, Rupert Frazer, Emily Richard, Leslie Phillips. Directed by Steven Spielberg. 1987. Warner Home Video.

LEAD: The marriage of Janice Lynn Worth, a portfolio manager at Oesterreichische Laenderbank in New York, to Douglas Middleton Arthur, a vice president in equity research at Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York, took place yesterday in West Park, N.Y. The Rev. Lloyd Duren, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the West Park Winery.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The evolving nature of Presidential politics and the medium of television together have all but reduced party conventions to the level of the electoral college, which is to American politics what the vermiform appendix is to the human body. The trend has progressed to the point that the only question now is whether the national conventions will vanish entirely or be recognized for what they have largely become: unpaid advertising on as much prime-time television as can be grabbed off in the name of public service.
LEAD: Despite greater awareness of exercise and more healthy foods, many Americans remain ''significantly overweight,'' according to Federal researchers.

LEAD: GENERATION OF SWINE: Tales of Shame and Degradation in the '80s. By Hunter S. Thompson. (Summit, $18.95.) In the literary free-fire zone of American culture and political commentary, Hunter S. Thompson has always been on point. In his latest book, Mr. Thompson, author of ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas'' and ''Fear and Loathing: On the Campaign Trail '72,'' addresses new targets of opportunity - from Muammar el-Qaddafi and Ferdinand Marcos to a Soldier of Fortune trade show, from the George Bush campaign to handicapping the likelihood of a Democratic victory in November.

LEAD: My thanks to Peter Maas. His comparison of the indigenous Irish in the Six Counties to the American blacks in the Southern United States in the 1960's could jog the memory and conscience of Irish-Americans.

LEAD: WHETHER it is a desire for more space, or frustration with balky co-op boards, or simply a wish to own the roof above, the basement below and the garden behind, demand for one- and two-family Manhattan town houses in a city of apartment buildings is growing steadily, along with their prices.

LEAD: AUGUSTO GROB caught on to the idea at a public meeting near this commercial and agricultural center in Chile's southern lake region. At the meeting, a representative of Fundacion Chile - the Chile Foundation - offered to go into partnership with farmers and investors and provide the expertise to set up a berry farming and exporting business.

LEAD: In recent years, an increasing number of policyholders have taken aim at insurance companies in so-called bad faith lawsuits. The suits, which accuse the insurers of improperly rejecting claims brought under existing policies, have drawn a lot of attention. But another type of suit has been gaining ground with less fanfare.
LEAD: FOR the first time in American history, both the Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates of a major party, the Democrats, are fluent in Spanish.

LEAD: President Reagan has moved toward the political center. Michael Dukakis is sticking close to it. By all signs the voters like it. But George Bush is coming on making the noises of the far right.
LEAD: THE SIGNIFYING MONKEY A Theory of Afro-American Literary Criticism. By Henry Louis Gates Jr. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.
LEAD: BREAKING GENTLE By Beverly Lowry. 326 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

LEAD: The international advertising agency prides itself on being hip. Everything is stylish, modern and fast-paced; the executives spend 12 hours a day at their sleek desks, and everyone in the office has a powerful personal computer. Some have consoles on their desks that include a multiline telephone, a facsimile machine and a personal copier.

LEAD: At age 32, Sugar Ray Leonard still performs with all the spirit, vigor and gallantry of an Olympic athlete. In a sport full of human cash registers, whose sole incentive is money, Sugar Ray is a delightful aberration. When I watch him fight I feel privileged. ERIC H. MORRISON New York

LEAD: In this summer resort town, home of one of the nation's oldest art colonies, you can buy an original painting by Michael Stoffa for about $500. Or, for $29, a comparable-sized oil painting signed with the name Taylor.

LEAD: WORK AND PLAY. By Carlo Gebler. (St. Martin's, $12.95) This quirky and slight coming-of-age novel tells the story of Fergus Maguire, who is expelled from college after disappearing for a lost weekend of heroin snorting and carousing in London. He returns from this disgrace to the family home in Dublin, where his disappointed and disapproving father awaits.

LEAD: It isn't a question of Leonard boxing again that's at issue here. It's about money. Leonard is a box-office gold mine, the greatest entertainer the sport of boxing has seen. In the end, I will be surprised to see Donny Lalonde come away with a victory. Not because of Ray's efforts inside the ring, but because of his importance outside of the ring.

LEAD: I was hanging from a spikelike piton midway up the Mirroire d'Argentine on the third day of the Alpine climbing course. The Mirroire, a 1,000-foot face of the Argentine Mountain near Solalex in the Swiss Alps, is as smooth as glass from a distance and crack-ridden up close.

LEAD: IF your idea of dining out is serene surroundings, soft music, thick carpets and quiet conversation, forget Westbury's Caffe Baci. This casual cafe delivers crowds, excitement and razzle-dazzle. Caffe Baci is the latest in an unending stream of contemporary Italian cafes inundating Long Island. The Soho Grill had a short sojourn of six months at this location.

LEAD: THE work of the 17th-century playwright Aphra Behn (1640-1689) remains obscure to contemporary theatergoers. An Englishwoman, she wrote 18 plays, 15 of which were produced. LEAD: I TURNED THE HORSES OUT again tonight.

LEAD: ''The Portrayal of the Black Musician in American Art'' can make a difference. It is fresh. Its concern is the way the black musician has been represented in American art. What the show is really about is the response to black Americans during the last 200 years.
LEAD: THE fate of the Sharon Playhouse, built in 1955, could be in the hands of ''Godspell.''

LEAD: Susan Elliott Hentschel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Elliott Hentschel of Ogdensburg, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Francis Tully, the son of Hannah Moynihan Tully of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Thomas F. Tully. The Rev. John Yonkovig performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Ogdensburg.

LEAD: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LEAD: Bring on the tall ships. And the commemorative coins. And the corporate sponsors and merchandise tie-ins. It's four years to the quincentenary of Christopher Columbus's voyage to the New World, and the American way of celebrating historical anniversaries is gearing up again.

LEAD: Chatham Township $612,500 19 Hall Road 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 15-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, sun room, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $5,715. Edison $180,000 27 Holly Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; dining room, patio, full basement; taxes $1,866.
LEAD: How important to a team's success is one man in hockey, a sport in which a player rarely spends two minutes on the ice per shift? In the case of Wayne Gretzky, mighty important.

LEAD: NOT many travelers are aware that a large number of items made in developing countries may be brought home duty-free, beyond the provisions of the usual $400 exemption: baskets made of willow or rattan from Senegal, toys from Israel, unset jade for jewelry from Taiwan, records and tapes from Trinidad and Tobago, coral jewelry from

LEAD: Acknowledged by architectural historians as the jewel of Sir Christopher Wren's smaller churches in the City of London, St. Stephen Walbrook (1672-79), Wren's own parish church on the street where he lived, was designed as a laboratory of the neo-classical forms that became the model for St. Paul's Cathedral.

LEAD: Why don't composers of contemporary operas want me to know what the singers are singing about? Perhaps I am merely suspicious by nature, but I have begun to think there must be a secret they are trying to keep from me. Are the words a code of some sort? If not, why am I so seldom allowed to know what they are saying up there on that stage?

LEAD: TED KOPPEL HAS JUST surprised me - it's two hours to show time - by telling me he doesn't have a clue how he's going to start his program. It's 9:30 P.M. on Thursday, June 30, in the ABC ''Nightline'' conference room in Washington. Koppel and I, alone, are eating a typical ''Nightline'' dinner. Last night it was pizza, tonight it's Chinese delivery.

LEAD: Douglas Kiker, the NBC News correspondent, demonstrated a deft hand as a mystery writer in ''Murder on Clam Pond'' almost two years ago. He introduced a man named McFarland, an out-of-work, disillusioned journalist from Chicago who was holed up on Cape Cod. Mac, as he is called, was confronted with a murder and solved it.

LEAD: SUMMER is proverbially vacation time, but running into someone you know can pop up at any time, wherever you go. And on a recent trip to St. Croix our adventure was marked by several such instances.

LEAD: The Yankees and the Chicago White Sox, perennial trade partners through the seasons, are apparently discussing another deal that could take place before the end of the month. If it does, Mike Pagliarulo will go to Chicago for Steve Lyons in a swap of third basemen.
LEAD: PURPLE and green thumbers alike, those of us who garden outdoors passionately must soon come to grips with our acqusitive tendencies.

LEAD: Brookfield, Conn. $333,500 Secor Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; whirlpool bath; screened porch, 2.5 acres; taxes not yet available. Darien, Conn. $210,000 55 Old Kings Highway 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new condominium apartment; new construction, ceramic tile kitchen, fireplace; monthly common charges $75, taxes $2,400.

LEAD: Christians may disagree with some aspects of Martin Scorsese's challenging new film, ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' but if they understand their own tradition they will not argue with his presentation of Jesus as attracted to marriage. They will argue rather that such an attraction is not a temptation at all.

LEAD: The marriage of Ardith Campbell Dentzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Dentzer Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., to Andrew Borland McCormick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. McCormick Jr. of Lancaster, Pa., took place yesterday at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont. The Rev. Michael A.

LEAD: Men dressed in fancy military uniforms spin and dance on the stage to a raging drum tempo, their legs flying in all directions. As they whirl, they clash their swords together so sharply that sparks actually fly.
LEAD: LABRADOR By Kathryn Davis. 225 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.
LEAD: THE comparison to Anne Frank is obvious.

LEAD: I AWAKEN to the sound of your voice issuing commands from the front yard. My dreams are interrupted and I refocus on you; I welcome the diversion. In my mind's eye I see your confident presence as you stand at a makeshift home plate, see your bat make contact as I hear the smack and see your slight but sturdy figure start to run.

LEAD: A leading Armenian dissident who was recently expelled from the Soviet Union accused Soviet leaders on Friday of deliberately inflaming ethnic tensions to halt the growth of democracy in Armenia.
LEAD: ROGER STONE used to enjoy saying that no chief executive should stay longer than 10 years. Creativity would be replaced by rigidity, Mr. Stone would say, and that was just no good.
LEAD: Coast Shuttles

LEAD: TOUGH, new ethics rules that take effect Jan. 1 could hinder operations at the already overburdened Real Estate Finance Bureau of the New York State Attorney General's office. Attorneys critical of the new law believe this may lead to even further delays in approvals for condominiums and cooperatives.

LEAD: The clubhouse scene was boisterous one night, quiet the next day. The sense of accomplishment the Yankees felt on Friday was suddenly gone in the late afternoon today, even though they are hanging in a division race that refuses to leave them behind.

LEAD: It appears that Robert E. Chambers Jr. will spend the rest of his life literally paying for his crime against Jennifer Levin. Mr. Chambers, who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the strangling death of Miss Levin in Central Park two years ago, informed the court last week that he would not contest a $25 million civil damage suit filed against him by Miss Levin's parents.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, questioned about a World War II gunner's challenge to Vice President Bush's account of being shot down over the Pacific, said, ''I don't think that kind of thing has any place in the campaign.''

LEAD: Come next winter, Los Angeles may no longer be to hockey what Edmonton, Alberta, is to filmmaking. The owner of the Los Angeles Kings, which have had only five winning seasons in 21 years, last week made a deal for Wayne Gretzky, who helped make the Edmonton Oilers world champions four times in nine seasons and who is considered by many to be the best player ever to bounce a slap shot off a goalie's teeth.

LEAD: For the eighth year in a row, Barry Switzer of Oklahoma has the top winning percentage among major-college football coaches, according to the 31st annual Top Twenty Coaches list. The list was originated in 1958 by Elmore Hudgins, former public relations director for the Southeastern Conference.

LEAD: IF the warm weather has brought out any wanderlust, consider a pleasant country drive that can yield the bonus of a concert. In Cambridge, N.Y., for instance, nestled in the Green Mountains not far from Bennington, Vt., L'Ensemble has been presenting chamber concerts every summer since 1979 in its own reconverted Barn Theater.

LEAD: WHEN Greeks and others debate the American military presence here, the talk turns generally on a blend of high drama and deep passion, political theater and diplomatic machismo. The negotiations currently under way on the future of the United States' four main bases and a string of lesser military installations have mixed in another ingredient: a cynical belief that, whatever public figures may say in public, in private the deal is as good as done.
LEAD: Two men, two guns and a piece of lead are at center stage as testimony in the trial of Larry Davis enters its fourth week tomorrow in the Bronx County Courthouse.
LEAD: JUST how many ZIP codes can one remember? Or how many street addresses? Losing an address book can be disastrous.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH SHE ADMITS TO HAVING PERIODIC fantasies of living in rooms with gilt rococo mirrors and tufted bergeres, Barbara Jakobson, a New York art collector and design aficionado, says she is really ''firmly mired in the 20th century.'' At least a specific era from earlier in this century. The rooms pictured here, for example, ''were designed to look as though you have just been ushered into the stateroom on the A deck of an ocean liner.

LEAD: The relationship of Haydn and Mozart has been the subject of much comment, most of it (as far as 19th-century and 20th-century scholarship is concerned) of a slightly surprised nature, because Mozartians have always considered Haydn a second-rate composer. But contemporary and near-contemporary documents and Mozart's own compositions make it clear that Mozart treated the elder composer and his music with loving attention.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN the intense heat of late July, a group of dancers rehearsed a work they had performed publicly many times. ''More tension! Everybody can do more. There has to be drama in it!'' exhorted the petite dancer-choreographer watching them.
LEAD: FROM a diner's perspective, the Northwest Corner is slowly becoming livelier, perhaps partially due to the influx of new weekend residents and summer visitors.

LEAD: The desire to make a good impression on a potential sexual partner leads so many men to lie about their sexual past and drug use that it is virtually pointless for women who are dating them to ask, a new study shows.
LEAD: Pamela Hall Wilmot and Steven Edward Clinkenbeard were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Ridgefield, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. William Grant Nigh.

LEAD: 'I don't think it would be permissible for the independent prosecutor to tell only half the story.' - James C. McKay, independent prosecutor, defending the conclusion in his report that Edwin Meese 3d was ''probably'' guilty of a crime, though no prosecution was warranted.

LEAD: Politicians here say it is no concidence that the mayors of the cities playing host to the national party conventions this year come from the same clubby neighborhood in New Orleans. This city's Seventh Ward seems to be something of a nurturing ground for prominent black politicians.
LEAD: In an unusual display of offensive prowess, the World Cup soccer team of the United States defeated Jamaica, 5-1, today and advanced to the third qualifying round of the 1990 tournament.

LEAD: Jimmy Hamilton, the clarinetist who started a 26-year stint with the Duke Ellington Orchestra in 1942, has convened a small-scale Ellington revival at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas (near Ninth Street), where he is leading a sextet through next Sunday. With his fellow Ellington alumni Norris Turney on alto saxophone, Britt Woodman on trombone, Earl May on bass and Aaron Bell (who played bass with Ellington) on piano, along with Jackie Williams on drums, Mr.

LEAD: WHEN the first European settlers arrived in lower Westchester in the 17th century, they had to have been impressed with the opportunities they found. LEAD: The Pentagon report on the July 3 downing of an Iranian airliner by missiles fired from the Navy cruiser Vincennes recommends disciplinary action only against the ship's operations officer, according to a published report.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Olan of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dana Michelle Olan to Darryl Erik Lieberman, a son of Ruth Lieberman of New York and Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Dr. Harvey Lieberman.
LEAD: These are heady days at United Nations headquarters, with positive developments on Afghanistan and the Persian Gulf and the United Nations getting most of the credit.

LEAD: THOUGH medical waste washing up on Connecticut beaches has prompted calls for stiff penalties for ocean dumping and raised fears of infection, some of the reaction has gone too far, environmental and health officials say.

LEAD: Record floods in Khartoum have been so devastating that international help will be needed for at least three months to assist the 1.5 million people left homless, a Sudanese Government official said here today.

LEAD: AN $85 million waterfront condominium, with 21 apartments priced at more than $1 million, will open on the Charles River here next summer, capping the transformation of a onetime research and development district on this city's east side.

LEAD: Congress is considering an amendment to the Small Business Administration Act that would allow private organizations to receive financial assistance for projects to benefit small businesses owned and controlled by women. Enactment of this legislation would be a victory for groups that provide training programs for women entrepreneurs, among them the American Women's Economic Development Corporation.
LEAD: Rarely have I read such adolescent drivel as expressed in the article on the New Jersey Opinion page of July 10. It sounds like a response to the first surge of hormones in a 17-year-old.
LEAD: A boat capsized in the flooded Ganges River and at least 10 women died, it was reported Friday. The incident happened near where more than 400 people drowned in a ferry accident last week.

LEAD: What follows is a portrait of New Orleans from the collective palette - and palate - of those whose personal or professional histories give them more than a passing familiarity with the city. That the portrait has many features is not surprising, given the city's culture and history. While some of those who were asked for their favorite New Orleans attractions mentioned well-touristed places, a few gave more private spots.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: IN 1980, Jeffrey H. Shapiro, owner of the Cedar Island Marina in Clinton, paid $300,000 for 90 acres of intertidal flats adjacent to his eight-acre, 400-slip facility just in case he wanted to expand. Recently, he applied for permission to add 396 slips on 22 acres. After 16 days of hearings before the Coastal Management Division of the Connecticut Department of Environmental

LEAD: The message is hammered out almost daily over the airwaves, at political whistle stops and in the halls of Congress. Our labor force is crumbling, good jobs are rapidly disappearing, the middle class is collapsing. The culprits? Evil employers and underhanded foreign governments that are undermining the livelihood of working men and women.
LEAD: Clearing up a longstanding mystery, new genetic studies indicate that the microbe responsible for a kind of pneumonia that is a major killer of AIDS patients is a fungus.

LEAD: Mollie Davis Rimmer and Frederick Thomas Bedford Cunningham Hoopes, graduates of the Groton School and the University of Vermont, were married yesterday at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Bertrand N. Honea Jr., assisted by the Rev. Laman Bruner, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: The Brazilian federal police have brought charges against an American anthropologist who accompanied two Amazon Indian leaders on a visit to Washington earlier this year.

LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, observing his fifth anniversary as Panama's military leader, accused the Reagan Administration last night of creating a false crisis in Panama in an attempt to oust him.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I say no - a thousand times no. He should not gamble and push his luck. I say this from my experience as a retired fighter. I have had three retina operations - back in 1933 - all unsuccessful and I have been blind in one eye all these years. We didn't have laser in those days, but percentages are the same.

LEAD: William Shakespeare has never been at a loss for words about the weather, but there are some words the Bard never penned on the subject that are being bandied about these days at Central Park's Delacorte Theater, the outdoor summer forum for the free theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival. One gropes for the apt Shakespearean quote on the dripping whimsy of heaven but, without raiding
LEAD: The Army has decided that a black woman who was dismissed from her civilian job had been discriminated against by an Asian-American male supervisor and two white male officers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Carolyn Proga, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert J. Proga of Eastlake, Ohio, was married there yesterday to George Graham Vest Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vest of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Louis Pizmoht performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Justin Martyr. He was assisted by the Rev.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Sugar Ray Leonard has proven himself to be a great boxer, and by all accounts a smart boxer. But the decision to box again is not smart. Whether Leonard wins or not, he is telling young athletes by his example to set aside health, conditioning, and age considerations for one more grab at the brass ring.
LEAD: Tuesday marks the 40th anniversary of Babe Ruth's death. Larger than life, larger than death, larger with every passing year, he is the sports hero of our century.

LEAD: AMONG THE STILL LIFES, NUDES AND wildly abstract paintings at a recent official art exhibit in Tallinn, capital of the Soviet Republic of Estonia, hung two portraits of Josef Stalin that, even a few years ago, might have earned their artists a one-way ticket to Siberia. But on a Saturday afternoon last May, they prompted little surprise from the viewers who flowed around me in the gallery.

LEAD: MARKETS: Who Plays . . . Who Risks . . . Who Gains . . . Who Loses . . . By Martin Mayer. (Norton, $18.95.) The tremors that shook world financial markets last October have been closely scrutinized, yet thus far the reams of reports have done little to reassure anxious investors. Nor have they so altered the rules of the game that professionals on Wall Street would be willing to wager against the possibility of another blowout.

LEAD: DISSATISFIED with the service they have received from managing agents over the years, a sizable number of condominiums and cooperatives are changing to self-management. Others report doing so because their management companies went out of business or no longer serviced buildings of a certain size.

LEAD: At Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J., Cathryn Lou Heine, a daughter of Lowelle T. Heine of Newton, Ill., and David L. Heine of Longwood, Fla., was married yesterday to Mark Walker Kellstrom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arne Kellstrom of Singapore. The Rev. Robert W. Ihloff performed the ceremony. The bride is the Northeast region administrator at Equicor Inc., an employee benefits company in New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The New York, New Jersey and Connecticut delegations to the Republican National Convention this week in New Orleans will include a greater proportion of public and party officials and be considerably more white and more male than their Democratic counterparts in Atlanta last month.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Virginia Pope, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leavitt J. Pope of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Gerard Boehling 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boehling Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. John McCaffrey performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: AFTER decades of hovering between Communism and capitalism, Yugoslavia's leaders are approaching economic policy as if they believe that, over the long term, almost nothing is more important than the marketplace. Still, the Communist leadership's continued reluctance to loosen the political reins raises doubts about their ability to follow their newfound economic faith.
LEAD: THOSE sounds you're hearing at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival during performances of ''The Two Gentlemen of Verona'' are of laughter, a sign of life.

LEAD: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain which we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then tried rubbing with fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years).

LEAD: Deborah Parnelle Burks, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Parnelle Burks of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael John Southwick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Southwick Jr., also of Princeton. The Rev. Bruce M. Webber performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

LEAD: Sugar Ray is still physically able to fight in the professional ranks - albeit a weight class higher than he's used to. He still has hand speed, though some may contend his legs are suspect. He still loves to box. So let him box. Pay him whatever the market will bear. BOB WATERS Whiting, N.J.
LEAD: AFTER LOSING TO Jimmy Connors in the quarterfinals of last year's Wimbledon tournament, Slobodan Zivojinovic had this to say to a reporter: ''If I'm in the crowd, I'd be on Jimmy's side.''

LEAD: I HAVE JUST RETURNED FROM THE GARDEN WITH A basketful of blossom-tipped squash to cook for dinner. This squash will need no butter, not only because it is so fresh, but because it is an old-fashioned crookneck. It is funny looking, small and so frail that no commercial growers bother to ship them.
LEAD: A HISTORY OF THEIR OWN Volume One. Women in Europe From Prehistory to the Present. By Bonnie S. Anderson and Judith P. Zinsser. Illustrated. 591 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.50.

LEAD: A committee of influential businessmen, arts administrators and educators has been formed to rescue the New-York Historical Society from a financial and management crisis that threatens the survival of the 184-year-old institution.

LEAD: Forget the costumes. The garish new costumes that Christian Lacroix designed this season for American Ballet Theater's revival of ''Gaite Parisienne'' may have caused gasps. Nevertheless, the more amazing thing about that revival was the enduring vitality of Leonide Massine's choreography.

LEAD: Making Schubert's chamber music understood in a space like Avery Fisher Hall is by necessity an inexact translation. Vienna 160 years ago had opened its houses to music. The age of the palace concert was over; that of the big concert hall was yet to begin. LEAD: The marriage of Lisa Anne Niemiera, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander K. Niemiera of Perth Amboy, N.J., and James Raymond Collins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Collins of Louisville, Ky., took place yesterday at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Perth Amboy. The Rev. Robert J. Zamorski officiated.

LEAD: I was offended by Edson Atwood's article, ''Ban the Miniskirt, Please'' (Opinion page, July 10) because of his blatant sexism and presumptuous attitude. Mr. Atwood is mistaken in thinking that this reader is interested in his uncontrollable voyeurism and his dictatorial tendencies.

LEAD: sunday, Aug. 14 President and Mrs. Reagan arrive at Belle Chasse Naval Air Station. Welcoming ceremony at New Orleans Convention Center. Monday, Aug. 15 Convention opens. Address by President Reagan. Tuesday, Aug. 16 Platform presentation and vote.

LEAD: The thought arose that Dennis Dale McLain was either the dumbest person in the world, the most naive person in the world, the craziest person in the world, the biggest jerk in the world, or the most hardheaded person in the world.

LEAD: What started as morning in America reaches a climax tomorrow night in New Orleans. Ronald Reagan's address to the Republican National Convention will be more than a final appearance before the faithful. It will also be a trouper's dream, a chance to celebrate the accomplishments of eight years and confer what he can of that legacy on Vice President

LEAD: OEDIPUS REX With Alan Howard, Neil Rosenshein, Felicity Palmer, Claudio Desderi; Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra and NOS TV Men's Choir, Bernard Haitink, conductor. Produced by Harry Wich. Directed by Hans Hulscher. 1984. THE FLOOD With Pauline Daniels, Rudi van Vlaanderen, Kitty Courbois, with the voices of Sebastian Cabot, Elsa Lancaster, Paul Tripp and Laurence Harvey; Columbia Symphony, Robert Craft, conductor.
LEAD: In the article ''Day Camp Is Not Day Care'' Connecticut Q&A, July 24) Allen Beavers is emphatic in his assertion that camp is not day care, which he equates with baby-sitting.

LEAD: Peter Schmeisser's article pointed out how willing our Government is to export death and disease for profit. Your cigarette ads appearing in the same issue show how shamelessly you want a cut of the action.
LEAD: Maybe baseball should blame the mothers of America. ''I don't know if mothers want to raise their sons to be catchers,'' said Joe McIlvaine, a Mets' vice president.

LEAD: My husband, a gregarious Texan with a long stride and an easy smile, seems always to be chance-meeting aging reincarnations of people who still live and breathe within the landscape of his memory.
LEAD: THE BEGINNER'S BOOK OF DREAMS By Elizabeth Benedict. 325 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.
LEAD: Raj Sinha graduated last year from the University of Chicago School of Medicine. He now works as an investment banker for Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York.

LEAD: FOR the latest in munchkin summer fashion, it's all happening at the zoo. That's the newly renovated and resplendent Central Park Zoo, of course, where the sights include polar bears performing their famous synchronized aquatic routine, at left, and members of the cotton-candy set all spiffed up in their warm-weather dudlets.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Randolph Hornady 3d of Garrison, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Carr Hornady to William Edwards Magee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Magee 4th of Baltimore. Miss Hornady is an assistant account executive at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, an advertising agency in New York.

LEAD: Getting into medical school is much easier today than it was a decade ago, a result of a steep drop in applications. With a decline in the average grade of entering students, some schools are reducing class size to hold the line on admission standards.

LEAD: Rosemarie B. Greco started as a secretary at the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia. Nineteen years later, she's its president. At Pepsico Inc., Pam McGuire, a food law attorney, schedules her own hours so that she can spend time with her two young children.

LEAD: Interior Minister Tomas Borge has warned that no political settlement is possible in Nicaragua as long as contra guerrillas and opposition parties continue to press what he called ''unacceptable proposals.''

LEAD: The pessimists who have found so many things wrong with American swimming have been routed, as least for now. The Olympic team that qualified here in the United States trials, which ended Saturday night, appears strong enough to win five or six of the 16 gold medals for men and five of the 15 for women.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration, bowing to pressure from AIDS patients and members of Congress, has relaxed its normal rules and agreed to make an experimental drug more widely available to patients suffering from a severe form of pneumonia.

LEAD: Competition for big books and well-known authors is intense. But houses that are at each other's throats for acquisitions sometimes team up to publish, usually one in hardcover and the other in paperback.

LEAD: A police horse, frightened by exploding firecrackers at Coney Island early yesterday, stumbled and fell, losing his rider, and then fell again galloping back to his stable, injuring himself so badly he had to be killed, the police said.

LEAD: The Yankees, still burdened by pitching problems, attempted to improve their bullpen today when they released Tim Stoddard, a 10-year veteran, and called up Scott Nielsen from Columbus. It is probably not the only move the team will make this week.

LEAD: Anthony Cancellaro, the son of Italian immigrants, grew up at 154 Waverly Street. When he got married, he moved six houses up the block into his wife's family's house, at 128 Waverly Street. In his lifetime he has seen the Vivianos's house, two doors away, turned into a black Baptist church, the Italian grocery turned into a bodega, the apartments above the grocery become housing for single mothers on welfare.

LEAD: Eighteen years after passage of the Clean Air Act, 100 million Americans still breathe unhealthy, ozone-laden air, and acid rain continues to kill lakes and burn forests throughout the United States and Canada. Air pollution has been reduced, but not by enough. The White House, Congress and polluters resist the hard choices necessary for further protection of public health and the environment.

LEAD: IN my paperback copy of the Bible, the Gospels occupy only 140 pages, a small percentage of the whole. LEAD: The programs at most American race tracks outside New York's have become cluttered with little B's and L's over the last decade. LEAD: The catch phrases about Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, were largely correct. He was a strong man, a devout Moslem certain it was his mission to impose unity on a fractious country. LEAD: THE ways children tease each other and the ways they respond to being teased can tell us much about their mental and emotional development. Beneath the taunting are clues to how well children can think in abstractions, and how well they understand the feelings and situations of others. Most important, child development experts say, teasing and being teased are ways for children to practice some of the social skills they will need as adults.

LEAD: Geo. A. Hormel & Company announced it had bought Chicken by George Inc., the company founded by a former Miss America, Phyllis George. The price was not disclosed. Under the agreement, Hormel will buy all the assets of Chicken by George, based in Louisville, Ky., and operate the company as a division.

LEAD: The carefully drawn plans of the Bush campaign to use the Republican National Convention as a four-day television commercial have been overwhelmed by the attention the campaign itself has stirred up in the selection of a running mate.

LEAD: Sherri Turner was a nonwinner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour entering this year. She had been close a couple of times, but victory always eluded her. That changed in May when she won the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship for her first victory, then came back a week later to capture the L.P.G.A.
LEAD: Cesar Chavez, the leader of the United Farm Workers, plans to end his fast Sunday at an outdoor mass at the union's compound here, a spokeswoman announced today.

LEAD: Dr. Ellen C. Cooper has emerged as the most important gatekeeper for AIDS drugs in the nation, a role that has caught her in a spotlight of conflict that is rare for someone who is a mid-level manager at the Food and Drug Administration.
