LEAD: How serious is New York's Legislature about improving New York City schools? For months, Albany has procrastinated over a sensible reform agenda. At least three measures ought to remain high on the list of essential business as the Legislature reconvenes to finish its drawn-out session.

LEAD: About 100 residents in Perth Amboy and Woodbridge Township were evacuated from their homes today after utility crews accidentally pierced a gas line, city officials said.

LEAD: On Sept. 7, Guy Lafleur will be inducted into the National Hockey League Hall of Fame in Toronto. The team announced yesterday that it would grant Lafleur a tryout next month when its training camp opens.

LEAD: For well over a decade, Emmylou Harris has stood as a proudly independent figure in the world of country music. A close friend and collaborator of Gram Parsons, who helped invent the sound of modern country-rock, Ms. Harris has consistently eschewed country music formulas to explore some of the more obscure corners of the country and folk tradition.

LEAD: At noon on an August day, the sweet smell of marijuana drifts through Tompkins Square Park. Give us a break!'' a third yells to a woman with a notebook.

LEAD: Two days ago, Greg Louganis offered the startling opinion that it wouldn't shock him if he failed to make the United States Olympic diving team this year. Who was he kidding? With a typically splendid performance on the 3-meter springboard tonight, he breezed his way onto the team with 1,440.52 points, the most among the 11 finalists, to make the Olympic team for the fourth time.

LEAD: A series of about 10 underground explosions, apparently caused by gasoline in the sewer system, ripped through this seacoast city today. The explosions blew off 20 to 40 manhole covers, damaged two houses and caused the evacuation of about 200 people from homes and businesses, but no one was injured.
LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that his running mate, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, was a victim of a ''feeding flurry'' of rumors that will turn out to be a ''tempest in a teapot.''

LEAD: THE Adamses, the Kennedys, the Rockefellers, the Fords: these are among the family dynasties that have provided America with generations of leaders in politics, industry and philanthropy. There is one family dynasty, however, that comes from the bottom of the pile.

LEAD: After staying out of the political spotlight at his California ranch this week, President Reagan today praised the ''energy and enthusiasm'' of Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, the Republican nominee for Vice President.

LEAD: An Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 jet blew two tires today as it landed and skidded to a stop at National Airport, but none of the 156 people aboard was injured, officials said. The plane, Flight 158 from Miami, came to a halt at the intersection of the airport's two longest runways, forcing their closure for more than three hours.

LEAD: TO AN INDIAN FAMILY, THE tandoori meal is not just food. Like Sunday supper for some Americans, this meal is the high point of the week. I remember gathering with my family and friends in cool breezes at an outdoor concert in New Delhi under tamarind and mango trees. There, we would dig a pit to smoke, grill and roast chicken and meat.

LEAD: Talk of success in America and what do you mean? Take Reizl Bozyk, who never performed a word in English - well, maybe a few here and there - during 60 years in Yiddish theater, suddenly catapulted to a top role in the new movie ''Crossing Delancey,'' opening Wednesday at the Plaza. Don't 60 years of top billing in Yiddish, which some heartless ones believe is headed the way of silent films, also represent success, particularly when they were spent in entertaining
LEAD: A year of mental and physical problems came to a joyful end tonight for Michelle Mitchell. In Wendy Lian Williams's case, the joy came after a four-year wait.

LEAD: At the conversion of 301 East 66th Street, the sponsor is offering outside buyers 22,000 possibilities. Only 22 apartments in the 202-unit building are for sale right now, but each is being offered with enough options to allow 1,000 combinations for the mathematically inclined and the choosy. While an option package is as common in new construction as in new cars, it is unusual in the conversion of older buildings.

LEAD: COMPUTERS you can take with you - variously called notebooks, laptops and portables, depending on size, features and marketing strategies - are enjoying a boom in sales. Although they can serve just as space savers on a cramped office or home desk, since they usually take up less room than conventional desktop machines and can easily be packed away when they're not needed, presumably most portables are bought to be taken along on business or vacation trips.

LEAD: IN OUR AREA, Michael Ross is a household name. It rides past you on people's bumpers (''Electric Fry Michael Ross''). It calls to you from headlines and editorials about capital punishment. Recently I heard it used as a grim verb by one of my high school students. He was describing to a friend the plot of a movie he had rented: ''Then this guy took this girl out to a pond and he Michael Rossed her.

LEAD: One of two prosecutors shot in a robbery died Friday after he was taken off a life-support system. A man found sleeping on a beach in Naples was charged in the shooting, which the police said was a random crime.

LEAD: PORT JEFFERSON is a town in love with summer and the sea. Ferry crowds jam the streets and restaurants dot the harbor. At least half of those restaurants fly nautical colors. Costa de Espana, a Spanish entry tucked into a parking lot behind Main Street, is no exception. Its name and menu say seafood.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Florence Caplan of White Plains of the engagement of her daughter Dina Eve Caplan to John Peter Spyros Sarbanes, a son of Senator and Mrs. Paul Sarbanes of Baltimore.

LEAD: ''WE have no leader, we have no arms,'' said a Burmese student, lifting the bandanna that masked his face as he marched through Rangoon on a recent day of anti-Government protests. ''But one day we will remove this Government,'' he went on. ''They are shooting at us and we will die. But we will not die in vain.

LEAD: IT WAS THE ABANDONED GARDEN THAT most intrigued interior designer David Anthony Easton and artist James Steinmeyer. LEAD: JUST after she took the job last summer, Carri Lee Miller knew it was a mistake. Her hands would ache after every day at Morrell's meatpacking house here, where she sometimes had to make 1,900 cuts an hour on the hogs' heads that passed by her station. At night, she would wake up in pain with her fingers clenched in a fist that she could not open alone.

LEAD: Vice President Bush and his Republican backers around the country struggled this weekend to break free from questions about his running mate, Senator Dan Quayle, and to focus public attention instead on what they saw as Mr. Bush's substantial accomplishments at this week's Republican National Convention.

LEAD: For generations, the lure of the cool deep water and craggy terrain of this city's granite quarries has proved too strong. Drawn as if by the Lorelei, youthful trespassers have come to the quarries to deepen their tans, drink stronger waters and tempt fate by diving into the dark, dangerous deeps.

LEAD: The Stillwater National Wildlife Refuge became the second Western Hemisphere Shorebird Reserve in the country today, but the honor may be a hollow one for a once lush sanctuary that is now a dying swamp.

LEAD: AT companies around the country, television screens are lighting up the workplace. More than ever, employees are receiving their job training from videotape along with information about company services, benefits and programs. At a many companies, live broadcasts about late-breaking company news are being transmitted by satellite to television screens in employee gathering areas and coffee rooms.

LEAD: A large cache of homemade weapons has been uncovered on Rikers Island by New York City correction officers conducting a search, a spokeswoman for the correction department said.

LEAD: ''Love reciprocated is always rejuvenating,'' T. S. Eliot said in 1958. ''Before my marriage I was getting older. Now I feel younger at seventy than I did at sixty. . . . An experience like mine makes all the more difference because of its contrast with the past.''

LEAD: DRIVEN by strong demand for showroom space, Chicago's 24-story, 4.2-million-square-foot Merchandise Mart - the world's largest wholesale buying center under one roof - is undergoing a $100 million, 10-year renovation. It is the first major renovation of the building, which was put up in 1929.

LEAD: WHEREAS the 20-year-old Jacques Brel musical with the unwieldy title hammered away at its themes through songs, dispensing with a standard ''book,'' the new Brel musical at the John Drew Theater in East Hampton through Saturday - ''Jacques Brel Blues,'' it is called - talks itself into oblivion.

LEAD: A FULL coffee pot, crusted with pitch-black soot, was brewing over red-hot coals. Nearby the Taylor River gushed past boulders midstream in its steep path down the mountain. A group of campers, meeting for the first time and trying to remember each others' first names, huddled near the fire as the temperature started its dizzy descent from a daytime high in the 70's to near freezing at night.

LEAD: NUCLEAR power plants have generally performed safely during the last 34 years, with only one major accident, at Chernobyl in the Soviet Union, and one minor accident, at Three Mile Island in the United States. Since 1954, 408 nuclear power plants worldwide have had more than 4,500 reactor-years of safe operation.

LEAD: IN the last few years, it has become conventional wisdom that the best way to overhaul the American welfare system is to move able-bodied people off the dole by requiring and helping them to get jobs. Legislation now approaching a decision point in Congress embodies that very principle.

LEAD: Golf Nicklaus Hits $5 Million Mark: Jack Nicklaus passed $5 million in career earnings yesterday, but a three-putt bogey on the 17th hole cost him a place in the final round of the International Golf Tournament at Castle Rock, Colo. Nicklaus appeared to have a berth in the final sewed up until he hit the par-5 17th, probably the easiest hole he designed on the Castle Pines Golf Club course.

LEAD: DESPITE new speed limits on some waterways in the state, 13 people have died this summer in boating accidents in Connecticut, only three short of the record set in 1980, as boat traffic continues to increase.

LEAD: A judge killed himself in a deserted hallway of the county courthouse Thursday after he learned that allegations of sexual misconduct were being published. A friend said the judge felt hounded by the press and unable to bear it anymore.

LEAD: THE smoking room at Highclere Castle, about 60 miles west of London, looks pretty much as it has for years, with its large brown leather sofa and chairs. The carved wooden fireplace, terra-cotta-colored walls and inlaid marble table under Canaletto paintings make a male retreat that must have seen many a bridge or gin rummy game.

LEAD: Across the country, small community hospitals in poor inner cities appear on the brink of failure, squeezed by fluctuations in state and Federal Medicaid reimbursements and a rise in indigent patients depending on them, health policy experts say.

LEAD: Olympics on My Mind On a sunbaked, breezeless field in East Hampton, on a 95-degree day so muggy even the thermometer seems to sweat, Bianca Jagger is crouched in a three-point stance, ready to run the 100-yard dash.

LEAD: THE world has about 12 million refugees, people who fear persecution in their homeland, including many who have been uprooted by war. The war in Afghanistan created the world's largest refugee population, some five million people who have lived in Pakistan and Iran. Though civil war may continue in Afghanistan, the Soviet withdrawal is raising hopes for repatriation.

LEAD: Right about 2 o'clock in the morning on those special Saturdays, when the automobile turns southeast onto State Highway 92, Harold and Polly Gentry and Darrel and De Willet, two retired couples who live in nearby Gering, begin another autumn adventure.

LEAD: Aware that captive populations of the black rhinoceros were suffering anemia and were failing to reproduce, Dr. Ellen Dierenfeld, nutritionist at the Bronx Zoo, suspected that they were suffering deficiencies of vitamin E.

LEAD: AMONG the American political leaders who will march along Fifth Avenue in Manhattan today, in a parade celebrating the 41st anniversary of India's independence, few can claim Indian descent. LEAD: A modified version of a bill that would establish the first Government film commission has been approved by a House-Senate conference committee. The 13-member commission would have the power to require labeling of some classic films that have been altered by coloring or other technology.

LEAD: IN April, the end seemed near for We Can, a nonprofit can and bottle redemption center for homeless and poor people. It was about to be forced out of a vacant lot on West 43d Street to make room for high-rise condominiums, and it had nowhere to go.

LEAD: Leon McAuliffe, one of the early members of Bob Wills's popular swing band the Texas Playboys, died today at a local hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old.
LEAD: Voters polled after the Republican National Convention favored Vice President Bush over Michael S. Dukakis by 51 percent to 42 percent, Newsweek magazine said today.

LEAD: SINCE 1938, when the Government required employers to pay their workers at least 25 cents an hour, periodic challenges to the New Deal idea of a statutory minimum wage - which now stands at $3.35 an hour - have rarely amounted to more than academic exercises. This year, things could be different. Committees in the House and Senate have cleared legislation that would raise the minimum for the first time since 1981.

LEAD: With Phil Simms starting for the first time in the preseason and Zeke Mowatt starting for the first time at tight end, the Giants made short work of the Pittsburgh Steelers this evening. Simms threw a pair of touchdown passes to Mowatt as the Giants defeated the Steelers, 28-17, and boosted their preseason record to 3-0.

LEAD: The Kennedys played touch football, the Bushes pitch horseshoes. And the Bushes do it with as much passion, vigor, and spirited competitiveness as that relatively mild sport allows. Not that it's easy. Any novice who has tried to hang an iron shoe around the stake from the required distance - 30 feet for women, 40 feet for men - knows that.

LEAD: FARAWAY PLACES. By Tom Spanbauer. (Putnam, $16.95.) In ''Faraway Places,'' Tom Spanbauer's promising fiction debut, images of innocence are woven into a taut, brutal narrative of three murders as witnessed by a 13-year-old named Jake Weber. The setting is Wind River, Idaho, a rural landscape where power lines hinge the alfalfa fields to the sky.

LEAD: At lunch the other day at China Grill, an exclusive French-Chinese restaurant in Manhattan, a disturbing incident occurred. Coffee was served. The cream came in a geometric, sharply angular polka-dotted designer creamer; I watched in fascination as the cream dribbled, not into my coffee cup but langorously down the jutting lip of the chic pyramidal spout.

LEAD: My parents live life by the good book. Not the Bible, mind you, but the Entertainment Book. This is the book to end all books, they say. It's a short stubby volume, about four inches thick, and it's filled with coupons for tickets, free dinners and other special discounts for hundreds of places.
LEAD: THE WORLD ELSEWHERE And Other Stories. By Nirmal Verma. 238 pp. St. Paul: Readers International/ Consortium Book Sales. $16.95.

LEAD: I AM up at daybreak, filling the old metal thermos with fresh coffee, the red and yellow jugs with juice. Efficiently I pack the cooler: ham and cheese for the men, tuna salad for the girls, chips and Oreos for the kids. I remember the light beer for my Dad, the Coors for my Coloradan husband and the diet soda for myself.

LEAD: In southern Westchester County, where homes offered for $200,000 are considered moderate-cost housing, four new town houses will be priced at just under $150,000. The condominiums are part of a 30-unit development in White Plains whose prices peak, in fact, at $185,000. Ranging from 710 to 1,030 square feet, the one-bedroom town houses have one or two levels or one level and a loft, and all have one-car garages.
LEAD: EVERY SUMMER, it's the same question. Will I get up the courage and ambition to swim in the Atlantic Ocean or won't I?

LEAD: Leslie Jane Roberts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Leslie Roberts Jr. of Philadelphia, and Robert Miller Guillot Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Guillot of Florence, Ala., were married yesterday. The Rev. Russell Claussen performed the Protestant ceremony at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in

LEAD: Malcolm W. Browne's revealing report ''Will the Stealth Bomber Work?'' (July 17), about the Pentagon's latest boondoggle, is another example of how the pockets of tired United States taxpayers are bring picked clean by fast-talking military contractors.

LEAD: IN the early 1940's, Harry Hleva drove his 1937 Studebaker to an aircraft plant in Stratford, where his job was to help build an aircraft called a ''flying boat.'' Today, in his 1988 Dodge, Mr. Hleva heads for almost the same spot, to work on the very same craft.

LEAD: A letter that John W. Hinckley Jr. wrote to obtain a sketch of the actress Jodie Foster nude prompted a mental hospital to cancel its plan to take the Presidential assailant on a field trip, according to people familiar with the case.

LEAD: IT began 75 years ago with a modest state appropriation, and a year later five acres of Westport salt marsh was bought as the first piece of a statewide mosaic of greenery and open space. The state's parks system is now three-quarters of a century old, and some of the parks' best friends are celebrating.
LEAD: LONG ISLAND, you had your second chance and you blew it.
LEAD: A NEW HAMPSHIRE builder is re-creating the century-old Union Bluff Hotel, which burned down last year, by building a wooden Victorian-style hotel on the original foundation.

LEAD: A NUMBER of treaties and international agreements say that refugees should not be sent back to countries where their lives or freedom would be threatened. But they do not require countries to admit people who fear such dangers. More and more, countries are adopting new rules, laws and policies to restrict admissions of refugees.
LEAD: A traffic patrolman who wrote more than 1,000 bogus tickets and gave some motorists a break will remain with the Police Department, his superiors have decided.
LEAD: Buying Time in Burma

LEAD: By day, this narrow valley carved into the steep mountains seems nearly deserted, the only movement herds of goats scrambling among the rocks. But as dusk falls and the danger of Ethiopian MIG bombers fades with the light, the valley springs to life.

LEAD: A Congressional committee has charged that the Veterans Administration, which provides $14 billion a year in disability and pension benefits to about 4 million Americans, has been unfair to thousands of veterans and has concealed its own findings of ''error and bias.''

LEAD: The last balloon has been swept from the Superdome, the last hangover attended to, the last rhetorical cannon spiked. With a gavel's bang Thursday night, the long and largely unedifying process by which America selects its Presidential candidates came to a merciful end. Two candidates survive, one to be chosen.

LEAD: NORTHERN LIGHT Nordic Art at the Turn of the Century. By Kirk Varnedoe. Illustrated. 286 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $50.

LEAD: SMOG has one component, ozone, that comes out mostly in the summer, and this summer, both ozone pollution and public concern about it have been at a high point. This year, hot weather appears to be the main culprit. Readings compiled last week by the Environmental Protection Agency confirmed that ozone in urban areas has been at its highest levels of the decade.

LEAD: Comforting as it was to be told that this color or that silhouette was the right one - those days are gone. Today, fashion is about making choices. Most women have already settled on the hem lengths they like best. Now they can concentrate on experimenting with the other elements that add up to individual style and flair.

LEAD: A NEW law requiring youths 16 years old or younger to pass a state-approved boating safety course before they operate motorboats in New Jersey is drawing praise from many parents and groans from junior yachtsmen.

LEAD: TO summer theatergoers looking for a real - indeed, a surreal and radical - change of pace, ''Princess Ivona,'' a 1935 play about a girl who has been variously described as charmless, awkward, apathetic and ugly, may be just the thing.

LEAD: Sara Morgan Judge, the director of South and East Asian programs for AFS Intercultural Programs in New York, and William Francis McCalpin, a program associate at the Rockefeller Brothers Fund in New York, were married yesterday.

LEAD: Wayne Gretzky's domination of his sport is unparalleled in any other professional league. No other athlete singularly gains as much respect as the Great One does in hockey. Whether his dealing to the Kings will stimulate hockey in Los Angeles remains to be seen, but this was definitely a blockbuster deal for Canadians and Americans alike.

More accurately, it's one of a trio of new and shapely cameras designed to bridge the gap between simple ''point-and-shoot'' models and single lens reflexes.

LEAD: IT'S NO SECRET TO THE SARTORIALLY hip that a suit can be more than the sum of its parts - the jacket serving as a sport coat now and then, the pants doubling as odd trousers. Mixing it up, some peole believe, can lend a wardrobe variety and punch.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Henry U. Harder of Greenwich, Conn., and Saranac Inn, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Holly Harder to Bruce Catlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Catlin of Woodstock, Vt., and Sabael, N.Y. The couple plan to marry Oct. 8.

LEAD: ''When you were little. . . ,'' parents would say to their children; and then they would relate what the children had been too young to remember. Most of us learned about our early lives that way, and our self-images derive at least partly from these parallel accounts.

LEAD: THE lone survivor of a Northwest Airlines crash in Detroit a year ago is doing ''amazingly well'' and may need no further surgery.

LEAD: The Olympic Games begin in less than a month. Athletes have finished their physical conditioning. Now the hardest part begins: the mental preparation. The position and posturing that athletes do to gain a psychological edge on their opponents is as interesting as the events themselves.

LEAD: Some people drove from Florida to Indiana last week to watch Bruce Kimball try out for the Olympic diving team. They were not rooting for him. Earlier this month, Mr. Kimball's car plowed into a crowd of Florida teen- agers, killing two of them and injuring six others. The police said Mr. Kimball, who won a silver medal in the 1984 Olympics, was drunk.

It is thus an almost delicious irony that we seem to be seeing a budding nostalgia boomlet for just that mid-70's New
LEAD: It is a typical case. The cat lives in a six-story apartment building in Mamaroneck. It's a hot summer night, and the family feline leaps daintily out the open window to enjoy the fresh air.
LEAD: In his autobiography, ''Looking Forward,'' George Bush recalls one of the frustrations of his first statewide political race in Texas.
LEAD: Shorter seasons and shooting hours, lower bag limits and other restrictions for the 1988-89 duck season have been proposed by the Fish and Wildlife Service.
LEAD: Regional disparities in personal incomes widened in 1987, as residents of coastal states continued to earn more than residents in most other areas, the Government reports.

LEAD: At 1 P.M. on Sunday, quiet groups will gather and attempt to lay flowers at several sites here to mark the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia 20 years ago, an event that crushed the brief blossoming of what was called Communism with a human face.

LEAD: THE Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury is promising an ''afternoon of fun'' today from 1 to 6 P.M. ''with the sights and sounds of America,'' namely blues, jazz, folk and country.

Jordahl, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel of Manhattanville

LEAD: I HAVE used various modes of travel: a 747 jet, a drafty troop train in Korea, an ocean liner, a Harley-Davidson cross-country and even, I must confess, a horse and buggy in Tennessee. But I had never ridden in a recreational vehicle. I had seen a number on highways, been intrigued with their swaying bulk and stolid-looking drivers, but I had trouble picturing myself behind the wheel.
LEAD: Twenty-two members and supporters of American Indian tribes walked up a seven-mile mountain road to President Reagan's ranch today, seeking a dialogue on Indian rights.

LEAD: Linda Ishkanian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vahe Ishkanian of Teaneck, N.J., and Edward Joseph Munshower 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Munshower of Ormond Beach, Fla., were married yesterday at St. Illuminator's Armenian Apostolic Cathedral in New York. The Rev. William Yurko, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Gothic Cathedral of Chartres, 40 miles southwest of Paris, stretches nearly an eighth of a mile from western doors to eastern apse. Built to offer medieval visitors a glittering foretaste of Paradise, in its 762d year it still looks every inch the part.

LEAD: A group of Christian fundamentalists are challenging a Government requirement that children 5 years old and up must have Social Security numbers for their parents to claim them as exemptions on tax returns.

LEAD: STEPHEN DWECK is a sculptor who went into the jewelry business seven years ago and achieved success with dramatic necklaces and bold earrings combining silver with semiprecious stones, cameos or pearls. He is now entering a field where his sculptural abilities are more evident: silver accessories for the home.

LEAD: 'I didn't want to have greedy little eyes and greedy little fingers going over them. My aunt may have been many things, but to my knowledge she was not a writer.' - Stephen Joyce, James Joyce's grandson, defending his decision to destroy letters from his Aunt Lucia, the writer's schizophrenic daughter.

LEAD: The Israeli Army said today that its soldiers shot and killed three Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon early this morning as they were trying to cross the border into Israel, apparently to carry out a terrorist attack.

LEAD: Once upon a time, the picture on the nation's front pages the morning after a convention ended was always the armpit shot, the picture of the two candidates raising their arms, hands linked and looking jubilantly juvenile.

LEAD: IN ONLY TWO BRIEF YEARS -1964 and 1965 - Lyndon B. Johnson did more to advance the cause of black Americans than any American President since Abraham Lincoln, and initiated a program for the enrichment of American life as revolutionary and far-reaching as the New Deal. ''We are entering a new era of good feeling,'' pontificated The Washington Post in 1964, ''and Lyndon Johnson is the gargantuan figure making it all possible.

LEAD: Walking along the stately broad streets - shut-faced, but serving here and there as a lofty municipal belvedere - that lead to the Musee d'Art et d'Histoire in Geneva, Switzerland, visitors will find on every hand a poster that says ''Berggruen Collection.'' If they know something of the international art world as it has existed since World War II, they will head straight for the museum.
LEAD: ADELE AT THE END OF THE DAY By Tom Marshall. 248 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: Jose Lind's two-run single in the sixth chased Nolan Ryan, who had pitched five and two-thirds perfect innings, and John Smiley allowed five hits in seven innings for his first victory in six weeks as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Houston Astros, 2-1, today.

LEAD: REPUBLICANS considering a run for the governorship of New Jersey went on a crusade at the party's national convention: a crusade to make sure that none of the county Republican chairmen went hungry.

LEAD: When Juan Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, learned that Sebastian Coe, the 31-year-old British middle-distance champion, had failed to qualify for the 1988 Games, he was dismayed. After all, as Samaranch told The Guardian of London, ''Sebastian Coe is a great Olympic champion, having won the 1,500-meters title twice and made many other contributions to the sport.

LEAD: The marriage of Elizabeth Bromley Jewett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. and Freeborn G. Jewett Jr. of McLean, Va., to Dr. Stephen John Teach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Teach of Buffalo, took place yesterday at the Warwick Reformed Church in Warwick, N.Y. The Rev. James E. Vincent performed the ceremony.

LEAD: To the Editor: Dean Alan Webster's article ''St. Paul's Is for Yanks, Too'' (Travel, July 10) brought back many pleasant memories. When I am in London, I always enter St. Paul's Cathedral as its architecture, grandeur and beauty appeal greatly to me. A visit to the American Memorial Chapel, behind the main altar, is always included.
LEAD: It will prove to be the biggest ever if the talent-filled Oilers do not win the Stanley Cup in 1989 or if the talent-lacking Kings do. DAVID BERNKLAU Brooklyn

LEAD: THE new Apple Scanner and a software package called Omnipage, taken together, have achieved a radical breakthrough in the world of scanning, the process of converting drawings and photographs into electronic computer files. The products, introduced earlier this month at the Macworld exposition in Boston, have the potential to do for scanner sales what the Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet did for personal computers.

LEAD: The regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama has widened its harassment of American officials in recent weeks as a way of forcing the United States to lift punitive financial measures against the country, senior Administration officials said.

''For these final two concerts in our August 'Listen 'n' Lunch' series,'' said Connie Cullen, the administrator of St.

LEAD: The President of this American trust territory in the Pacific, Lazarus Salii, was found shot to death in his home today, the authorities said. The police a gunman entered the home and killed him; a Presidential spokesman said suicide had not been ruled out.

Sexton Jr. of Ormond Beach, Fla. The Friends Stony Brook Meeting House in Princeton, N.J., was the setting for the Quaker ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BEING INVISIBLE, by Thomas Berger. (Penguin, $6.95.) An advertising copywriter with the power to disappear exacts retribution for the assorted indignities of modern life. ''Here, as in previous books, [ Thomas ] Berger evinces an almost Jacobean feeling for revenge, an ear turned to that howl of vengeance that drowns out the small voice urging us to turn the other cheek,'' Francine Prose said here last year.

LEAD: THE RADIO TELESCOPE, WHICH makes pictures from the radio waves emitted by distant objects (as opposed to the optical telescope, which focuses on light waves) has been with us since World War II. It has revealed previously undetected entities in the universe and, because radio waves are not distorted by the earth's atmosphere to the degree that light waves are, it has the potential to unveil the clearest possible images of astronomical phenomena.

LEAD: When Ralph Nader was growing up in Winsted, he would go to City Hall to watch his neighbors debate local issues. These town meetings gave the young Mr. Nader a look at democracy in action, and he was fascinated.

LEAD: DANBURY BICYCLE RACES Last year 500 bicyclers participated in the Downtown Danbury Criterium. This year, with nine races scheduled from 8 A.M. and 3 P.M. today, up to 900 participants are expected. No more than 100 cyclers are permitted to race at any one time.
LEAD: Poland's leaders struggled today to contain labor unrest, as the number of coal mines struck by workers rose to 10 and labor organizers at the country's biggest steel mill threatened a strike.
LEAD: Mack Lobell again justified his claim as the top horse in harness racing by winning the 30th edition of the International Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

LEAD: LIKE the restaurateurs cashing in on a surge of tourists from across the globe this year, Manhattan landlords are renting space to foreign companies with prodigious appetites for office expansion.

LEAD: Joseph A. Tomeo is at 3,400 and counting. His goal is to obtain 500,000 signatures on petitions calling for the recall of the New Jersey Senate for what he says is its failure to deal with the state's rising automobile insurance costs.

LEAD: If the string quartet and the orchestra had largely aristocratic ties in Mozart's day, the wind band was a more populist and adaptable ensemble, as much at home in a parade or a concert in the town square as in a more intimate salon performance. The Chicago Symphony Winds have been specializing in this literature for a decade, and at a Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening the group and a half-dozen guest singers and players presented an ample selection of Mozart's music for variously configured wind ensembles.

LEAD: WHEN Walter Dean Myers was a poor teen-ager living in Harlem, he often dreamed of what it would be like to become a lawyer.

He was in Managua in 1972-73, running the relief program after the earthquake, and then back in Nicaragua many times - in 1987, he made clinical rounds in a tiny hospital at Puerto Cabezas that had been crippled by the United States economic embargo.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation kept a confidential file on the United States Supreme Court from 1932 until at least 1985, according to recently obtained F.B.I. documents.

LEAD: IT takes a special something to face the world upside down while hurtling unsupported through the air. David Iversen, a gymnastics teacher, calls it ''guts.''

LEAD: A design error will force workers to take down and rebuild the center section of a partly completed $16 million bridge near downtown Minneapolis. The mistake will cost up to $200,000, take three to four weeks to correct and force an overnight shutting of Interstate highway ramps. Al Pint of the Minnesota Department of Transportation said the state's design consultant inadvertently included a rise in camber in a 30-foot section of the bridge, which is more than a half-mile long.
LEAD: To the Editor: ''Inflation Redux'' (Prospects, July 31) evidently could not quote an economist of the disinflationary bent. I offer my forecast.

LEAD: WHEN he seized power in 1977, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was a relatively unknown general who was not given much chance of surviving long in the turmoil of Pakistan. He not only succeeded but proved himself a master at manipulating the country's divisive political forces and advancing American interests in one of the world's most unsettled regions.

We tried scouring powder, then fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years).

LEAD: Paul J. Cupp, former chairman of Acme Markets Inc., died of heart failure Monday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr.

It is the first major renovation of the building, which was put up in 1929.

LEAD: A review of ''Jefferson and Monticello: The Biography of a Builder'' on July 31 misstated the elevation of Monticello's site in Virginia. It is 857 feet above sea level.

LEAD: THEY are called naive, primitives, folk artists or outsiders, but ''para-artists'' might be a more accurate term. After all, these untutored painters and sculptors work without conscious reference to conventional art yet somehow parallel to it and, anonymously, they have exerted an enormous influence on it.

LEAD: Two remarkable programs offered this past season at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater forced audiences to think about the kinds of movement that may serve as dance movement and the kinds of people who may legitimately call themselves dancers.

Witnesses said one of the terrorists was a ''gringa.

LEAD: THE LIMITS OF SISTERHOOD The Beecher Sisters on Women's Rights and Woman's Sphere. By Jeanne Boydston, Mary Kelley, and Anne Margolis. Illustrated. 369 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $32. Paper, $12.95.

LEAD: Surrounded by yellowing volumes of history in the library of his Staten Island home, 82-year-old Loring McMillen sits at his oversized desk, remembering with precision obscure facts about the borough. He has been Staten Island's official historian since 1934, and his research has helped to preserve its heritage.
LEAD: Listening to George Bush on Thursday night, I heard echoes of two clashing themes in American life, two strains that have been in conflict through almost all this country's history.

LEAD: THOSE who think that corporate videos are as dry, dull affairs, have not seen some of the latest ones. ''Video programs can no longer afford to be dull or amateurish,'' said James Kaminsky, editor of Corporate Video Decisions, a monthly trade magazine. ''Productions now tend toward glamour and sophistication.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: So what is the No. 4-ranked tennis player doing in a place like this? Many of the big names on the men's tour were in Cincinnati this week or practicing for the United States Open, which begins in nine days.

LEAD: DOCTORS and psychiatrists have recently identified a new field in medicine. ''Eating Disorders'' is the generic term and anorexics, looking into mirrors and seeing fatty pads where there is in reality only skin and bone, have become a familiar subject to any reader of the popular press.
LEAD: Rags make paper, Paper makes money, Money makes banks, Banks make loans, Loans make beggars, Beggars make rags. (Anonymous 18th-century ditty)

LEAD: Constance Elizabeth Kheel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Kheel of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home in East Hampton to Timothy Don Smith, a son of Eugenia R. Smith of Lakeland, Fla., and Don C. Smith of Largo, Fla. Town Justice James R. Ketcham officiated.
LEAD: An article on Aug. 7 about Lyons characterized the city incorrectly; it is not walled. A map with the article misidentified the hill district; it is La Croix Rousse.
LEAD: While much of North America has been sweltering through a summer of record heat, a group of Canadian scientists have been rafting across the Arctic Ocean on a leviathan of floating ice.

LEAD: When compact disks made their first appearance, everyone marveled at their dynamic range. For the first time in the history of recorded sound, it was possible to hear the entire span from pianissimo to triple forte. The merest whispers could be captured in all their delicacy, and at the other end of the scale, orchestral thunder would burst forth undiminished.

LEAD: TOY SOLDIERS. By William P. Kennedy. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) When it comes to selecting innocent victims, the fertile imaginations of terrorists seem to be exceeded only by those of thriller writers. Airplanes full of tourists held for political ransom are, of course, now overly familiar. The same is true for cruise ships, hotels and conventions of business leaders.
LEAD: A caption on page 19 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies one of the two Marx Brothers. The one on the right is Groucho, not Harpo.
LEAD: Choice. The word itself rings with promise, with giddy freedom.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: AFRICA, the only continent unable to feed itself, may soon experience a green reform, but not a green revolution, agricultural experts say.

LEAD: By the time Gov. Michael S. Dukakis got to the Texas hill country for a courtly stroll with Lady Bird Johnson by her husband's grave, the Democratic Presidential candidate had settled into a carefully designed pattern. The order of the day was simple: Avoid controversy.

LEAD: Those who seek meaning and justice in history have to reckon with Czechoslovakia. Twenty years ago today, its 14 million people awoke to discover their country swarming with a half-million Warsaw Pact troops under orders to suppress a phantom counterrevolution.
LEAD: To the Editor: The answer to a question about a purported American Stonehenge in New Hampshire (Q & A, June 26) asserted the following:
LEAD: Two Conservative Party legislators have charged that kickbacks are routine in Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservative Government.

LEAD: Yes, Wayne Gretzky has dominated hockey more than anyone has dominated a major sport in history. That alone makes the Gretzky trade the biggest ever. The trade has also made at least 10 more teams Stanley Cup contenders. The Oilers traded away their favorite son and their competitive edge. ANTHONY C.

LEAD: ''Folkways: A Vision Shared'' (Columbia 44034, LP, cassette and CD) was recorded to accomplish a good deed - buying the catalogue of Folkways Records for the Smithsonian Institution. The album also gives a few good reasons why Folkways deserves the attention. With Bruce Springsteen, U2, Bob Dylan, John Cougar Mellencamp, Willie Nelson, Little Richard, Brian Wilson and five others performing 14 songs by Woody Guthrie and Huddie (Leadbelly)

LEAD: Leaders of the African National Congress have for the first time accepted responsibility for some recent bombing attacks on civilians and said they have taken the first steps to prevent a recurrence.

Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. $413,000 5 Brace Terrace 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fireplace, unfinished basement, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $6,354.

LEAD: This season women are being offered a wide range of choice in all aspects of fashion - and fur coats are no exception. They come in many different shapes, lengths, patterns and even colors. As ''name'' clothes designers become more and more active in fur collections, they too are adding to the already notable diversity.

LEAD: THE fate of a proposed 98-unit condominium complex in North Hills is enmeshed in a protracted legal battle that has pitted three residents against the village's planning board in a dispute over the development of environmentally sensitive land.
LEAD: To the Editor: Readers of the Travel section may be interested in my recent experience in Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: THE sad plight of the savings industry has recently become front-page news. Outside observers have pegged the cost of liquidating or forcing the merger of insolvent savings institutions at $50 billion, or more - well above the roughly $20 billion available to the industry's deposit insurer, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, through 1990.
LEAD: BAD BEHAVIOR By Mary Gaitskill. 203 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $15.95.
LEAD: Because of a production error, the following letter from the Borough President of Manhattan appeared in only some of last week's editions.

LEAD: IT is becoming harder to shock the public in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's land of falling taboos, but the Moscow State University drama players succeeded last month with their performance of ''The Black Man'' at a theater near the Kremlin.
LEAD: PALM-OF-THE-HAND STORIES By Yasunari Kawabata. Translated by Lane Dunlop and J. Martin Holman. 238 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: North Point Press. $19.95.

LEAD: THE RETURN. By Richard Maynard. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) In this science-fiction thriller, the second novel by the Australian writer Richard Maynard, seven astronauts leave Earth in search of life on other planets. They have no reason to believe that their society's social and technological development will not continue to flourish.

LEAD: The marriage of Carol Elizabeth Meyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Meyer of Great Falls, Mont., to Lloyd Goodwin Westerman, a son of Frances Westerman Collins of New York and White Meadow Lake, N.J., and the late Joel Westerman, took place last evening at the Meadow Lark Country Club in Great Falls.

LEAD: The Boston Licensing Board Thursday rejected Boston College's petition for a license to serve alcohol at its Alumni Stadium football field and in the Silvio O. Conte Arena. At a hearing on the petition Wednesday, residents of Newton and the Brighton section of Boston near the college asked that the license be denied.

LEAD: In one of his stories of the 1890's, ''In the Year of Jubilee,'' the English novelist George Gissing describes an underground station in late Victorian London: ''High and low, on every available yard of wall, advertisements clamoured to the eye; theatrs, journals, soaps, medicines, concerts, furniture, wines, prayer-meetings - all the produce and refuse of civilization announced in staring letters, in daubed effigies, base, paltry, grotesque.

LEAD: BY the end of the fall harvest, world grain supplies could be the tightest since World War II. While the Department of Agriculture says there is little danger that the world will run out of food, some experts outside the Government insist that the extent of the damage is being seriously understated.

LEAD: THE last few weeks have brought the chaos of civil war to Douglas Elliman, a 77-year-old industry leader known for quiet integrity in the business of selling Manhattan co-ops and managing posh apartment buildings.

LEAD: The target was ''Tex-Moishe,'' a swindler of sunglasses, a master predator of packaging tape, a brigand who fleeced his way up and down the East Coast, stealing millions from merchants of light bulbs.

LEAD: NEWARK passed a turning point last year when it tore down four public housing high-rises. What it was turning toward, however, is still a matter of debate.
LEAD: The Burmese Government sought to buy time from its restive population today with the publication of extensive self-criticism and a plea for time to explore economic and political restructuring.

LEAD: Jimmy Carter met here with a senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, an Egyptian Foreign Ministry official and a P.L.O. official said today.
LEAD: WHEN an elderly person dies, it is not uncommmon for a family member living far away to inherit the home in which that senior relative had been living.

LEAD: A Connecticut state trooper remained in critical condition yesterday as authorities sought to confirm the identity of a suspect in a shootout in which a New Haven police detective was also wounded.

That's the prognosis if Gaetti undergoes arthroscopic surgery, as the team physician, Dr. Harvey O'Phelan, has recommended. Gaetti, who had hoped to return to the lineup without surgery, will get a second opinion tomorrow.(

LEAD: The Massachuetts system for the mentally ill, now in the midst of a five-year overhaul, is being faulted for poor care and unsafe conditions by legislators, patient advocates and mental health professionals and administrators.

LEAD: Officials at the Walters Art Gallery said today that a ''sophisticated'' thief concealed the removal of $500,000 in small Asian works during the curator's vacation so carefully that staff members didn't realize they were gone.

LEAD: NOW that virtually everyone in Pakistan seems to think that President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was killed by someone through an elaborately planned operation, many are trying to guess who would have most benefited from his death.
LEAD: WHENEVER your correct strategy calls for an attack on the queenside, it is wise to an equal part of your attention to what might happen on the other wing.

LEAD: At times during his Administration, President Johnson's always eccentric behavior took a ''huge leap into unreason,'' according to Richard N. Goodwin, a special assistant to the President in 1964 and 1965.

LEAD: A Federal district judge refused Friday to dismiss criminal charges against a former C.I.A. agent accused of conspiring to ship arms illegally to the rebels in Nicaragua and of concealing the covert operation.

LEAD: Being in fashion is one great feeling money can buy. But most of us sense a real gulf, if not an existential chasm, between the price of beautiful clothes and the cost of their materials and labor. Consider, for instance, a $300 evening dress by Victor Costa, which may be nearly a line-for-line copy of another designer dress costing $3,000.

LEAD: IN the 1960's, political marches and demonstrations often resulted in violent confrontation between protesters and the police. But since then, mass protests have become increasingly commonplace, coordinated and even cooperative affairs, as police departments around the country adapted their tactics to include negotiation and restraint.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''I've been trying to sell a home for 60 days, and I think I'm 10 minutes away from one,'' Frank Morano said last week. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IT's being promoted as a statewide theater festival - a jubilee, in fact. For the second summer, New Jersey's professional theaters are getting a chance to take a show on the road - within the state. Last year, six theater companies gave five or six performances each in the Railroad Terminal Building at Liberty State Park in Jersey
LEAD: ''IT'S amazing what a difference a year makes,'' said Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, a Democrat.

Much less ambitious than the subtitle suggests, ''Your Money or Your Life: Economy and Religion in the Middle Ages'' focuses on a shift in the church's attitude toward usury over the course of the 13th century ''to show how an ideological obstacle can fetter or delay the development of a new economic system.

Edward W. Horne, the town judge of East

LEAD: At first glance, the ballet barre appears to be made of wood, but upon closer examination, it turns out to be of cast iron. This is a no-frills dance studio. Functional to be sure; yet, by American standards, drab, cramped, cold and dimly lighted. Like almost everything else in China, it exudes an aura of hardship, stoically endured.

LEAD: JULY 20 was a historic day in the political careers of two Americans. Michael S. Dukakis was selected by the Democratic National Convention to run for President, and in one of those monumental coincidences, I was chosen by the Hampton Democratic Caucus to be Justice of the Peace. (That's Hampton Connecticut with its 1,400 souls, not Hamden, not East Hampton, not even the Hamptons on Long Island.) What's that you say?
LEAD: The Kellogg Company has announced a 25-state recall of about 29,000 boxes of Frosted Mini-Wheats Biscuits cereal that may contain too much vitamin A and cause a burning sensation in the mouth.

LEAD: EVER since Alan Greenspan became chairman of the Federal Reserve Board a year ago this month, the big question has been whether he would be as effective an inflation fighter as his predecessor, Paul A. Volcker. Now that the Federal Reserve has decided that inflation is indeed a threat, Mr. Greenspan's strategy is becoming evident for the first time.

LEAD: True, the Democrats started this year's sniping. ''Where ... was ... George?'' they chanted, to Senator Edward Kennedy's lead, during their Atlanta convention. ''Poor George,'' said Ann Richards, the keynote speaker, ''he can't help it. He was born with a silver foot in his mouth.'' Stung, the Republicans retaliated last week - and ran the name-calling into the ground.

LEAD: Six years ago, while the young director Des McAnuff's audacious musical play, ''The Death of von Richthofen as Witnessed From Earth,'' was running at the Public Theater, its creator was contacted by David Singer, a young producer with another bold project. How would Mr. McAnuff like to adapt and direct a musical based on Jules Verne's novel ''Around the World in 80 Days'' to be a Radio City Music Hall extravaganza?
LEAD: VICE PRESIDENT BUSH walked onto the stage of the Republican National Convention last week and, after eight often trying years, became what he had always claimed he was: his own man.

LEAD: The trade deficit worsened in June, coming in at $12.5 billion, the largest since February. Imports in June rose 5.7 percent, to $39.3 billion, and exports fell 2.4 percent, to $26.8 billion. That was taken as a sign that the American economy, and its appetite for foreign goods, remains strong, perhaps strong enough to persuade the Fed that it must further tighten up on the money supply.
LEAD: Five children died in their beds early this morning as smoke from a kitchen fire filled and blackened their bedrooms in a housing project here.
LEAD: The Argentine Congress has adopted a law against discrimination on the basis of race, religion or national origin that Jewish leaders have hailed as a historic accomplishment.

LEAD: At the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., Melissa Ann Wheeler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Phillip Wheeler of Greenwich and Verbier, Switzerland, was married yesterday to Reeve Byron Waud, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius B. Waud of Lake Forest, Ill. Dr. Olin C. Robison, the president of Middlebury College and a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Margarita Gatchalian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jose A. Gatchalian of Manila and Benicia, Calif., was married yesterday to Denny J. Jarecki, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Jarecki of Waukesha, Wis. The Rev. Christopher Maloney performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Notre Dame in New York.

LEAD: THE recent hot spell delayed lawn work especially seeding or sodding of new lawns; since cooler growing weather is coming next month, major lawn work can now be organized; for established lawns continue setting mowers to cut high - at least two inches - to encourage deep root growth. If they have finished blooming, dig carefully, divide roots and replant day lilies, phlox, astilbes and other spring-blooming perennials.

LEAD: There are two contexts in which the magnitude of a trade should be judged. The first is the extent of news media coverage and public interest in a deal. In this respect, l'affaire Gretzky ranks with the Tom Seaver, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and O. J. Simpson trades as a mega-event. The second and more important criterion relates to the impact of the trade on the teams involved.
LEAD: A WHOLE NEW BALL GAME An Interpretation of American Sports. By Allen Guttmann. 233 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $10.95.

LEAD: AT last, real tomatoes are back. Though fancy shops have taken to stocking them all winter long, tomatoes from hydroponic farms in Israel and the Netherlands never taste like the sun-ripened ones from your garden or the farm down the road. As for those pale pink numbers from Florida, we won't even discuss them.

LEAD: IT may seem like the dull television, but at the J. C. Penney Company, merchandise buyers have been known to watch lengthy television shows starring nothing but shoes, followed by more shoes - and then stick around for the sock show.

LEAD: Women who follow their own personal style are the genuine leaders of fashion. The women pictured here, for instance, have all created an individual look that is a variation on an established and elegant theme. The timeless simplicity of their long camel-colored coats signals a revival of classic American clothes for this fall and winter.

LEAD: IT is summer and the nights are hot and sultry, but with the air-conditioner to cool the house, the heat on these hot nights is hardly noticed, and the nights hold little in them to be remembered. It was not this way during the summer nights of my childhood. The heat was noticed, and I well remember those nights.

LEAD: As cars left the Sands Country Club with headlights on and golfers could hardly see the flags from 150 yards, the second round of the $225,000 Atlantic City Classic was finally suspended for obvious reasons at 7:35 P.M. this evening.

LEAD: Back in 1974, Francis Ford Coppola was already mentioning the auto-industry maverick Preston Tucker as a future film subject. And Martin Scorsese had been given a copy of Nikos Kazantzakis's ''Last Temptation of Christ'' while making ''Boxcar Bertha,'' which was released in 1972. When a project hangs over a film maker's career for a decade and a half, how can it fail to become a monumental albatross?

LEAD: HERITAGE FESTIVAL The folks at the Huntington Historical Society must be doing something right; they've been doing it for 25 years now, the ''it'' being the annual Heritage Festival. And today's the day for the special 25th anniversary edition of the festival. From 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. the Heckscher Ballfield, off 25A, will be alive with activities that take in the entire family: ice cream making and weaving for small fry; more than 100 antique and knickknack dealers for browsers and collectors; a new project, ''Count Me In!

LEAD: The slogan ''welfare-to-work'' sounds beguilingly simple. But the reality of finding a job and getting off public assistance is neither smooth nor speedy, according to Project Match, an organization here dedicated to helping unemployed mothers, school dropouts and others hold jobs, even if they start out by losing a succession of them.

LEAD: The standard line is, ''I don't look at the scoreboard.'' It goes along with, ''I never pay attention to the crowd'' and ''I don't read the papers.''

LEAD: TO summer theatergoers looking for a real - indeed, a surreal and radical - change of pace, ''Princess Ivona,'' a 1935 play about a girl who has been variously described as charmless, awkward, apathetic and ugly, may be just the thing.
LEAD: After almost eight years of a war that has claimed an estimated one million lives, a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq was reported holding tonight.

LEAD: The four corner buildings at Broadway and 39th Street once were centers for textile merchants who served the Garment District. But while three of the buildings were being transformed into malls of designer showrooms, 1412 Broadway was held to the old ways by Arnold Steinberg, its owner for 20 years.

LEAD: Frances Ann Alling and Christopher Travis Tully, both graduates of Lynchburg College, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, N.J., by the Rev. Jeffrey B. MacKnight.
LEAD: MEMOIR OF A MODERNIST'S DAUGHTER By Eleanor Munro. 271 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.
LEAD: Beneath the four white marble minarets of a mosque that looms over this capital, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was buried today in a military funeral attended by at least 100,000 Pakistanis.

LEAD: At the First Presbyterian Church in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., Melanie Anne Maslow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maslow of Dallas, Pa., was married yesterday to F. Paul Lumia, a son of Col. and Mrs. S. Albert Lumia of Bear Creek, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Wallace F. Stettler performed the ceremony.

LEAD: North and South Korea once again failed today to make headway in their second day of talks at this border village, but both sides said they would meet again Monday to discuss terms for a joint parliamentary meeting.

LEAD: SUSSEX AIR SHOW Champion aerobatic pilots, wing-walkers, World War II fighters and bombers, flying comedy acts and a parachute demonstration will all be part of the annual air show at the Sussex Airport Friday through next Sunday.

LEAD: The bomb blast that killed eight British soldiers today in Northern Ireland is part of a stepped-up campaign by the Irish Republican Army in recent months to target British troops there and elsewhere in Europe.

LEAD: The French Government announced an agreement today on the future of New Caledonia that offers amnesty for many jailed Melanesian separatists and sets rules for a referendum in 1998 on independence for the South Pacific territory.

LEAD: Dr. Christina Brock Casals-Ariet, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jordi Casals-Ariet of New York and Port Jefferson, L.I., and David Mason Little 3d, a son of Mrs. Little Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., and Chocorua, N.H., and the late Dr. Little, were married yesterday.

LEAD: Seven months after the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was thrust into the middle of the Yonkers housing desegregation dispute, the main consequences have been a convoluted court case, confusion over the church's stand and a palpably frustrated John Cardinal O'Connor.

LEAD: The publishing industry witnessed further consolidation last week when Random House Inc. agreed to buy the Crown Publishing Group. LEAD: ALTHOUGH gypsum wallboard, more often called drywall, is much easier to apply than plaster, one part of the process is a common stumbling block: sealing the seams between panels with drywall tape. This is a crucial step in finishing a surface, because if done poorly the taped seams are difficult to disguise by sanding and painting.

LEAD: Reasons abound for the powerful and the not so powerful to seek haven for themselves or their sons in time of war.

LEAD: All the principal roles except Schaunard changed hands at the New York City Opera's ''Boheme'' on Saturday afternoon, and the new team gave an honest, unpretentious, basically effective performance of the opera: a performance in which one could feel afresh the admiration and affection that is due this perfectly constructed work.

LEAD: IT is reminiscent of when the Beatles were all the rage and Joe Namath was the proprietor of Bachelors III, although on a much smaller scale. Andre Agassi, his streaked, blond shoulder-length hair blowing in the wind, trotted into the men's locker room at Newark Academy an hour before yesterday's match, cradling still another bouquet of flowers given to him by a female admirer.

LEAD: Given the growing popularity of baseball cards on the major and minor league levels, perhaps it was inevitable that the craze would spread to the amateur level. And when it did, one logical source was the Cape Cod League.
LEAD: Gerald Young's two-out single in the 14th inning drove in Billy Hatcher with the winning run as the Houston Astros beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-1, today.

Blond, also of Far Rockaway, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Israel Chait officiated, assisted by Rabbis Walter S.
LEAD: John A. Livingston, a naval architect and marine engineer, died of heart failure Tuesday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Australian Inter-State Championships, an event with no American equivalent, came to a surprising end here Friday night. New South Wales, which has long been dominant, seemed likely to sweep the board but wound up in second place in all three events.
LEAD: The name at the top of the list was the ever-familiar one.

LEAD: William Styron joined the ranks of Robert Frost, Elliot Carter, Willem de Kooning and 25 equally illustrious Americans yesterday when he received the Edward MacDowell Medal for excellence in the arts, for his achievements as a writer.
LEAD: A 3-year-old girl was killed last night when a fire swept through the bedroom of her home in Rochdale Village, Queens, the police said.
LEAD: A $130 million judgment against the Hunt brothers is the latest in a series of problems faced by the sons of the late Texas oilman H. L. Hunt.
LEAD: Jean-Paul Aron, a philosopher and writer who announced last year that he was suffering from AIDS, died Saturday, hospital officials said. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: Richard R. Green will move into his first full academic year as New York City's Schools Chancellor next month resolved to further decentralize the 942,000-student school system and to broaden the role that schools and teachers play in the non-academic lives of their students.

LEAD: For auto racing fans who attended this past weekend's activities at the raceway in Pocono, Pa., the 500-mile Indy-car race yesterday may not have been the most entertaining event. One of the curtain raisers was the Coors RaceTruck Challenge for showroom stock mini-pickup trucks, and it is an event that is fast gaining popularity.

LEAD: A crowd of 27,433 turned out to see Sporting Cristal of Peru capture the Marlboro Cup soccer tournament at Giants Stadium this afternoon with a 4-0 victory over Barcelona of Guayaquil, Ecuador. In the consolation game, Benfica of Portugal defeated Nacional of Medellin, Colombia, 3-2.

LEAD: Forty Niner and Seeking the Gold are developing as close and consistent a rivalry as racing has ever seen, but the 3-year-old sons of Mr. Prospector now seem likely to head separate ways for a while.

LEAD: The Dukakis administration, facing sluggish tax revenues, has been forced for the third time in two months to borrow $200 million to cover state expenses. And Massachusetts officials said more short-term borrowing may be necessary.
LEAD: It's beginning to look like a daily habit -a man in a white tuxedo hops out of a limousine and spends a couple of minutes handing out $50 bills to passers-by before being chauffeured away.

LEAD: The scene might have been one drawn from ''The Great Gatsby'': men in dinner jackets and women in evening dresses sipped champagne, nibbled petits fours and danced to jazz under a billowing white tent on the harbor here Saturday night.

LEAD: James Miles Hubball, who was headmaster of the Buckley School in Manhattan for 25 years until his retirement in 1972, died after a brief illness yesterday at his home in Southport, Conn. A former resident of Manhattan, he also had a home on Sanibel Island on the Gulf coast of Florida. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: Gale-force winds whipped more than 300,000 acres of wildfire across Yellowstone National Park on Saturday, the worst day of fires in the park's history. Roads have been closed once again and a resort village evacuated Saturday remained closed today.

LEAD: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., Dr. Barbara Ann Haber, a postdoctoral fellow in pediatrics, and Dr. Jonathan Andrew Flick, an assistant professor of pediatrics, both at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, were married yesterday by Rabbi Jack Stern.

LEAD: There are more and more working couples in the United States Foreign Service, and one of them consists of Robert B. Oakley, the National Security Council specialist on the Middle East at the White House, and his wife, Phyllis B. Oakley, the deputy spokeswoman of the State Department.

LEAD: Seven people were killed and 33 others, including a dozen firefighters, were injured yesterday when a fire raced through a basement social club that had been operating illegally in the Bronx, the authorities said.

LEAD: About 10,000 people marched through the capital today, shouting ''Freedom!'' and ''Russians go home!'' on the 20th anniversary of the Soviet-led invasion that crushed the ''Prague Spring'' of 1968.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: A 4-month-old boy was killed when struck by a van while picnicking in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx last night, the police said. They said the infant, Justo Martinez, was in his stroller next to his mother, Luisa Martinez, 21, near West 246th Street and Manson Road, when hit by the van, driven by Lorgio Cano, 59, of 566 East 191st Street.
LEAD: The trail just outside the Glacier Peak National Wilderness area here has seen so much motorized traffic lately that some hikers have started calling it the Interstate.
LEAD: Twenty-two members and supporters of American Indian tribes walked up a seven-mile mountain road to President Reagan's ranch Saturday, seeking a dialogue on Indian rights.

LEAD: Ellen Dolgins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Dolgins of Neponsit, Queens, and Jeffery A. Bosch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Bosch of Wading River, L.I., were married yesterday at the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

LEAD: Wall Street knows Jack Nash and Leon Levy for the decades they spent running Oppenheimer & Company. Leveraged buyout specialists know them from Odyssey Partners, the investment boutique they opened when they left the brokerage business in 1982.

LEAD: Marjorie D. Seidel, a daughter of Herbert B. Seidel of St. Louis and the late Gayle Sosin Seidel, was married yesterday to Jay A. Yelon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Yelon of Brooklyn. Rabbis Alan Lavin and Ezra Finklestein officiated at Temple Shalom in Brooklyn. Mrs. Yelon, a classified advertising saleswoman at The New York Times, graduated from the University of Hartford.

LEAD: More than two tons of cocaine and $2 million in cash - stashed in grocery bags that said ''Just Say No to Drugs'' - were seized late Saturday at a Queens apartment in what the authorities called the largest drug raid in New York City, officials said yesterday.

LEAD: TO the average recreational athlete, the mere mention of a triathlon might conjure up images of men and women on a near fanatical mission, trying to push their bodies through endless miles of pain and anguish in the waters and roadways of Hawaii.

LEAD: ''There's a big residue of good will about New York City schools. You might even call it a consensus. It's not simply the people who know that the future of the city is tied to the schools, but there is still a love for the New York City public schools by those who have been part of it. A lot of people went to these schools.

LEAD: A front page article from Huntington, Ind., about the Bush-Quayle campaign and the Quotation of the Day in some copies Saturday gave an incorrect serial number for Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana. His serial number is 303504096.
LEAD: A new retailing concept, medium-sized specialty stores that provide clothing for affluent professional women in a setting where shopping can be quick and efficient, has run into problems.

LEAD: Vice President Bush and Senator Lloyd Bentsen each had a son who enlisted in the Texas Air National Guard in 1968. But their commanding officer at the time said in an interview today that neither son was admitted because of his affluent background or high-level connections.

LEAD: On the other side of the diplomatic coin, being ambassador to the United States is often a stepping stone to greater things. Five years ago Yugoslavia's Ambassador, Budimir Loncar, returned home from Washington and was soon appointed Deputy Foreign Minister. Now he is Foreign Minister in Belgrade.
LEAD: For the first time since the 1920's, the tide of immigration is at flood stage in New York City, with millions of Asian, Caribbean and European newcomers in search of a better life.
LEAD: Next month's issue of Conde Nast Traveler warns of encephalitis in Japan, tear gas in the South Korean city welcoming the Olympics and a ripoff cab ride in Rome.

LEAD: A fire broke out tonight in the locomotive of an Amtrak passenger train heading from New York to Washington, forcing the evacuation of the 172 passengers on board, an Amtrak official said. The passengers of Train 123 were moved to a rear car, then taken by bus to Washington, said an Amtrak spokeswoman, Marci Larson.

LEAD: Anheuser-Busch Inc. will begin the first phase of its national campaign for Michelob Dry on Sept. 1 in selected markets. They are Fresno and Santa Barbara, Calif.,; Tallahassee, Fla.; Dayton, Ohio, and Houston.

LEAD: WHEN the Chubb Corporation began offering rain insurance two years ago to help farmers hedge against drought, it never imagined that the insurance would produce a costly legal battle. But now that Chubb, saying its agent badly oversold the rain insurance, has refused to issue the policies to 6,200 farmers, lawsuits are piling up.

LEAD: In the late 1970's, the English Beat mixed reggae and rock with political messages and complicated lyrics about romance, wrapping intelligent words in music so catchy that it reached a large pop audience. Two singers from the English Beat, Ranking Roger and Dave Wakeling, formed General Public in the early 1980's and now, a year after the breakup of General Public, Ranking Roger has emerged with his own band.

LEAD: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity trade union called a strike tonight at the big Lenin shipyard in Gdansk for Monday after the Government refused an earlier offer of talks with the union's national leaders to defuse a wave of labor unrest.

LEAD: Schubert's ''Rosamunde'' Overture, the Beethoven Violin Concerto and excerpts from Wagner's ''Gotterdammerung'' form the program for the benefit concert that opens the New York Philharmonic season, on Sept. 14 at 7:30 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. Zubin Mehta is to conduct, with Isaac Stern as the soloist in the Beethoven.
LEAD: A car bomb exploded in mainly Moslem West Beirut today, wounding 18 people, including three Syrian soldiers. The police found and dismantled another bomb in another part of town.

LEAD: The expansion of the military's role in drug enforcement has been a popular idea in Congress recently despite strong opposition from the armed forces and its supporters.

LEAD: A 9-month-old boy has become the sixth person to die from injuries suffered in a fire early Saturday at the Currie's Woods housing project here, officials said. LEAD: Pakistani and American teams began detailed examinations this weekend of the wreckage of the aircraft in which President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was killed on Wednesday along with the United States Ambassador to Pakistan and 28 others.

The agency already handles the importer's Cutty Sark Scots Whisky, B&B DOM Liqueur and Metaxa Greek Liqueur. The budget is $7 million to $8 million. The Kobrand Corporation sold Beefeater to Buckingham Wile's parent, Whitbred North America, in March.

LEAD: A HOSTILE takeover bid has worked magic on the stock of Interco, a St. Louis company not highly rated by Wall Street, but one whose subsidiaries in shoes, furniture and apparel are among the best known in the country.

LEAD: Nancy Rachel Stone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Stone of Washington, and Joel Benjamin Poznanksy, the son of Drs. Jack and Dulcie Poznansky of London, were married yesterday at the Westin Hotel in Washington by Rabbi Stanley Rabinowitz.

LEAD: A unit of the General Motors Corporation plans to lay off 550 workers at its bearing manufacturing plant here and move its spindle bearing operations to Sandusky, Ohio, officials of New Departure-Hyatt Bearings said.

LEAD: BUDDY RYAN, twirling a whistle on a cord back and forth in his right hand, stalks the Philadelphia Eagles' practice as if he were a cop patroling a bustling beat. It is the last blistering day of the Eagles' two-a-day practices, and for players new and old, Ryan has left no doubt that this season his Eagles will fly all for one and one for all.

LEAD: A half-century-old cinematic tradition on upper Broadway - as eccentric, small-scale and neighborly as the Upper West Side used to be - will end next Sunday as the Embassy 72d Street Twin Theater turns out its lights for the last time.
LEAD: Big offerings of new short- to intermediate-term securities highlight this week's Treasury calendar.

LEAD: Just as Greece seemed to be recovering from an unusual bout of terrorist attacks, a squad of urban guerrillas seized a police station here without firing a shot, tied up the officers inside and stole a small arsenal of weapons.

LEAD: Lloyd Highbloom has resigned as executive vice president, director of business development and a board member of DDB Needham Worldwide to pursue a new career. In a weekend announcement, he said he would disclose his plans later.
LEAD: The United States Olympic Committee has set Sept. 2 as its target date for resolving all issues of Olympic team eligibility, but at least one case is likely to continue beyond that date.
LEAD: The Soviet Union today observed the 20th anniversary of its invasion of Czechoslovakia with an enforced silence in the streets and in the press.

LEAD: Amy Einsidler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Roy Einsidler of Lawrence, L.I., and New York, and Keith Martin Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan L. Lewis of Rochester, were married yesterday. Rabbi Robert J. Eisen officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.
LEAD: Third-world countries need $43 billion worth of repairs to their roads because they failed to spend $12 billion to maintain them in the last decade, the World Bank said in a recent report.

LEAD: Whether George Bush or Michael Dukakis gets elected in November, getting inaugurated in January will cost him more than it cost Ronald Reagan. LEAD: QUESTION: When Don Sutton was released by the Dodgers earlier this month, reports about his career pointed out that he was one of 10 pitchers in major league history with 3,000 or more strikeouts. Did he ever lead the league in strikeouts for a season?

LEAD: For tennis fans who have been shut out of tickets to the United States Open, beginning Aug. 29 at Flushing Meadow Park in Queens, you are not alone: all 13 day sessions and 2 of 8 night sessions are already sold out, according to the United States Tennis Association. But there is a ''replacement activity'' on 18 field courts at the U.S.T.A.

LEAD: The Gannett Company and Knight-Ridder Inc. said Friday that they would wait until Sept. 8 to argue for a partial merger of their Detroit newspapers rather than immediately appeal a Federal court's 30-day restraining order against it.

LEAD: Patricia Marie, a Phoenix pottery collector, was trembling with emotion as she signed two checks totaling $9,500 and received two polished vases in return.

LEAD: Some coaches describe roster cuts as one of their more unpleasant duties. After a dreadful performance by the Giants' special teams unit Saturday night against the Pittsburgh Steelers, Coach Bill Parcells may find one or two decisions are easy.

LEAD: The Chevron Corporation said Friday that its vice chairman, Kenneth T. Derr, had been elected chairman and chief executive, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Derr, who is 52 years old, succeeds George M. Keller, who will retire at the end of the year at the age of 65.
LEAD: Bobby Rahal won the crashed-filled Quaker State 500 Indy-car race today, ending Chevrolet's seasonlong dominance and taking the series point lead.
LEAD: A devastating earthquake rumbled across eastern India and Nepal before dawn Sunday, killing more than 700 people.
LEAD: If summer means fun and frolic in the park, or a walk in a gentle breeze on the waterfront, then perhaps summer is finally beginning.
LEAD: Robert S. Potter, a lawyer, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: Soldiers have taken up positions in downtown Rangoon and barbed wire has been stretched across some streets in anticipation of more anti-Government demonstrations in the Burmese capital on Monday, diplomats said today.

LEAD: A battle is being fought for the heart and mind of public television. On one side are the 186 stations in the Public Broadcasting System, struggling to keep pace with cable channels that duplicate their fare and siphon viewers. On the other side is a well-organized group of independent producers who say that public television has pandered to an affluent audience while neglecting its mandate to create innovative programming.

LEAD: With unemployment at a 10-year low and factory output near capacity, is inflation just around the corner? Probably not, but only because the Federal Reserve seems determined to do whatever is necessary to maintain price stability. The Fed's tough stance deserves support.
