LEAD: Brendan Malone, an assistant with the Knicks and former head coach at Rhode Island, was named an assistant coach with the Detroit Pistons today.

LEAD: A growing number of companies, anticipating that rapid growth in medical costs will continue, are seriously considering ways to limit their obligations for retired workers' health costs, benefits consultants say.

LEAD: COMPANIES Wickes's chairman wants to take the company private in a leveraged buyout valued at $2.6 billion in cash and debt, with backing from Drexel Burnham Lambert. Sanford C. Sigoloff, the turnaround specialist who led Wickes out of bankruptcy in 1985, has grown frustrated with Wall Street as the company's stock failed to recover from the October plunge.

LEAD: Participants in the India Day Parade riding on a float down Madison Avenue at 43rd Street yesterday. LEAD: In a fifth-floor hospital room, a woman worries about who will raise her son if she dies of AIDS. Nearby, another woman lingers, well enough to leave if she had a home but too sick to return to the streets.

LEAD: In picking Senator Dan Quayle as his Vice Presidential partner, George Bush didn't remove the doubts about his leadership; he multiplied them. His judgment is now an issue more than ever - not whether this bird from Indiana can fly or whether he dodged the Vietnam draft but whether Bush would pick the best available people to help govern the country.

LEAD: The Government oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, will raise its prices for crude oil exports to customers in the Western Hemisphere on Sept. 1, but the prices will not change for exports to Europe.

LEAD: The Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Pacific division has been tapped to handle the Asics Tiger Corporation's athletic shoes and active wear account in the United States. The budget is $7 million. No agency search was conducted. The client, whose parent company is based in Tokyo, said it had chosen the shop because of its familiarity with the Pacific Rim and Tokyo affiliates.

LEAD: Asian and Eastern European films will occupy a prominent place at the 26th New York Film Festival, opening Sept. 23 at Lincoln Center, and movies from China, South Korea, Portugal and Rumania will be shown at the annual event for the first time.

LEAD: THE altitude here is 6,600 feet above sea level. The new arrival from a lower altitude who begins working out immediately feels the difference. Within a minute or two, the breath comes in ragged gasps and it seems impossible to draw enough air into the lungs. The pace of the workout is slower, and the heart beats faster.

LEAD: AN angler's skills should increase with experience, but the graybeard often makes little attempt to be innovative, relying on techniques, lures or flies that never fully embrace all of the challenges he encounters.
LEAD: Before the game, Dave Johnson gathered the Mets and told them to quit worrying about their three-month slump. Go out and have some fun again, he said, and remember you're still in first place.

LEAD: The first rule of choosing a running mate is taken from the Hippocratic oath: first, do no harm.
LEAD: The body of a non-nuclear Soviet rocket crashed early today in northeastern Canada after lighting up the sky from New Mexico to Michigan as it fell from orbit, the Defense Department said.
LEAD: Ethnic clashes in northern Burundi last week left about 3,000 people dead and sent at least 16,000 fleeing across the border to escape the bloodbath, a diplomat said today.

LEAD: Even young ad agencies are jumping into the acquisition game. Hawley Martin Partners, which opened its doors in Richmond two weeks ago, has acquired that city's Ford & Westbrook in an exchange of stock. LEAD: Largely hidden from press and public attention by its complexity, a plan to revitalize the depressed United States uranium-mining industry with huge injections of public money has quietly won approval in the Senate and awaits action in the House.

LEAD: IN Atlanta 91 percent more consumers have video cassette recorders than in Buffalo. Hispanic families in Houston show higher loyalty to retail grocers than Hispanic families in Chicago do. Women are 31 percent more likely than men to cite price as a reason for choosing one store over another. And so the differences, sometimes unaccountable, go.

LEAD: Jack Morris pitched a two-hitter for his 21st career shutout and the Detroit Tigers completed a four-game sweep today with a 5-0 victory over the error-plagued Chicago White Sox. The Tigers lead the Red Sox by four games and the Yankees by six games in the American League East.
LEAD: A changing of the guard has occurred at the New York branch of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. Toshiichi Hashimoto, who is 56 years old, has become the new general manager.
LEAD: Iran and Iraq traded accusations of cease-fire violations today, but United Nations officials supervising the day-old truce said it was still in place.

LEAD: THE lines are memorized, as if he were reciting a favorite bedtime story, one that begins with ''Once upon a time,'' and has the usual happy ending. Andrew Maynard hasn't finished writing his story yet, but that does not lessen his enthusiasm for giving listeners a detailed account of what has transpired thus far.

LEAD: In recent years the most critical stage in the appointment of United States ambassadors has been the confirmation proceedings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, where partisan politics can swamp a nomination.

LEAD: As Yonkers enters a potentially pivotal week, it faces several possibilities - the jailing of four City Councilmen who have resisted a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, the resumption of bankrupting fines, or perhaps a resolution of the conflict between the city and the court. Still, many residents, developers and public officials are looking beyond the immediate turmoil to what the future holds for the embattled city of 194,000.

LEAD: * Spain may have to raise its inflation target of 3 percent for the year, after an unexpectedly sharp rise in the consumer price index. The index rose 1.3 percent in July, which puts inflation so far this year at 2.9 percent. That compared with monthly rises of four-tenths of 1 percent in June and 1 percent in July last year.
LEAD: The dog days of summer have enveloped the credit markets, but analysts said that developments this week could shake participants out of their pre-Labor Day torpor.

LEAD: It's becoming fashionable among TV and radio correspondents on the scene and politicians in Washington to pronounce Nicaragua the way the Nicaraguans do. Other countries south of the border get standard American treatment - mex-ih-co not meh-hee-co, bruh-zill not brah-seel, chilly not chee-lay. But the standard nicka-rahg-wuh often comes out nee-kha-rahg-wah, rolling the r and curling the g.

LEAD: A flier put out by the Army warns military personnel to keep an eye out for suspicious actions, to listen for foreign accents and to beware of ''James Bond'' characters. Report them, the flier instructs. CALL SPY. The flier, a promotion for a counterespionage toll-free telephone number, is distributed to Army personnel nationwide by the Army Intelligence and Security Command.

Rabbi Simon Glustrom performed the ceremony at the Water's Edge at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

LEAD: It's been nearly two years since New York City Transportation Commissioner Ross Sandler presented a ''menu of options'' to reduce traffic congestion in central Manhattan. He wanted the city to decide by February 1987 which meal to order. Yet no plan has yet emerged from his department, nor has there been action on any front.

LEAD: The Jets, who had avoided the avalanche of injuries that marked their last few seasons, got bad news today: Bob Crable, the virtual captain of the defense, will undergo exploratory knee surgery Monday that will keep him out of the season's opener, at least.

LEAD: The defeat was like all the others this summer. It began and then it was over, quickly, quietly, almost sadly for the Yankees. They played, they lost, they dressed and left. The lone exception was Don Mattingly, who sat in front of his locker yesterday and let his anger spill out.

LEAD: Cesar Chavez ended his 36-day fast today by breaking bread with the children of Robert F. Kennedy at a Mass as thousands showed their support for the farm labor leader's boycott of California table grapes.

LEAD: In what United States Government agencies describe as a limited test program, about 100 American National Guardsmen have for the first time been deployed along the United States-Mexico border seeking to decrease the flow of drugs from Mexico.

LEAD: A protest challenging the midnight curfew at Washington Square Park ended Saturday night in 19 arrests. Later, demonstrators asserted that the police had singled out leaders of the protest for arrest.
LEAD: The British Government began a wide-ranging review of its security arrangements in Northern Ireland today after eight British soldiers were killed in an Irish Republican Army attack.

LEAD: In 1987 the Justice Department placed Kurt Waldheim, the President of Austria, on its ''watch list'' of people suspected of involvement in war crimes. The department based its decision mainly on World War II German Army documents.

LEAD: Juli Inkster, who was 10 shots behind Beth Daniel with 14 holes to go today, charged back with a string of four consecutive birdies and a six-under-par 65 to force a playoff at the Sands Country Club. Then Inkster tapped in a 2-foot par putt after a tricky downhill chip to beat a tired and fading Daniel on the first hole to win the third Atlantic City Classic.

LEAD: A boyhood dream came true for Davis Phinney today when he won the 14th edition of the Coors International Bicycle Classic here in his hometown. LEAD: The Washington Cathedral, the great Gothic edifice towering above the northwest quadrant of the District of Columbia, was constructed to fulfill the intention of the city's original planners to have ''a great church for national purposes.'' LEAD: Charges by a former White House aide that Lyndon B. Johnson displayed paranoid and irrational behavior as President have provoked criticism and hostility from several other officials who served in the Johnson Administration.

LEAD: Huey Newton, the former Black Panther leader, refused to leave prison on his scheduled release date today, demanding that officials also free Elmer Pratt, a former Panther.

LEAD: To Kurt Masur and the Israel Philharmonic fell the privilege of representing Haydn's most popular symphonic work in the Mostly Mozart festival's Haydn Week at Avery Fisher Hall. LEAD: Last year a Federal court finally smashed a milk dealers' cartel, handing consumers an immediate benefit in the form of lower milk prices. But now that victory appears threatened: the dealers' cartel could be replaced by a dairy farmers' cartel.

LEAD: Ali Haji-Sheikh was cut by the Washington Redskins yesterday, even though he did not miss an extra point or field-goal attempt during the preseason. His job was in jeopardy from the start of training camp because the Redskins' top draft choice was Chip Lohmiller. . . . The New England Patriots said they intend to place the quarterback Tony Eason on the injured reserve list next week, because he has not recovered sufficiently from off-season surgery on his throwing arm.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: William N. King, a retired Army master sergeant and the first enlisted man to make an official parachute jump, died Saturday at his home in Phenix City, Ala. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE tomato crop in the Northeast is late this year because of an exceptionally wet spring and early summer, but finally my garden is full of big, ripe beauties. One of my first cooking rituals when the crop comes in is to make a cold tomato-and-herb soup.

LEAD: There is still enough bad news to fill the headlines - earthquakes, tribal massacres, terrorism and such. But something is happening in the world, a movement away from the fist and the gun. It remains true in many places, as Mao Zedong proclaimed, that ''power comes from the barrel of the gun.'' But the notion is also spreading that such power has limited use and sooner or later brings only unsatisfactory results.

LEAD: Officials of the Birmingham Steel Corporation said today they were interested in buying the Baytown steel plant owned by the USX Corporation if a deal to sell it to Iraq falls through.

LEAD: Restaurant industry experts are predicting that the fast food business will undergo a technological revolution in the next few years that will place increasing numbers of robots and other labor-saving devices in the kitchens. The machines will flip hamburgers, bag french fries, spread pizza dough, fry chicken, bake biscuits, stuff burritos and deliver drive-in orders to cars in about half the time and at about half the cost that human workers require.

LEAD: The controversy grows over Senator Dan Quayle's decision to enlist in the National Guard in 1969, thereby reducing the threat of his exposure to combat in Vietnam. LEAD: The enduring appeal of Claude Lelouch's film ''A Man and a Woman'' is largely due to its aura of head-over-heels love. Mr. Lelouch has tried and tried in the 22 years since to recapture that film's easy allure (most blatantly in ''A Man and a Woman: 20 Years Later'') but the job seems to get tougher and tougher.

LEAD: After Governor Dukakis's great speech, George Bush absolutely had to make a great speech too. LEAD: HAS Reaganomics left Americans better off than than were eight years ago? Inflation is indeed down to 4 percent from 13 percent, and the banks' prime interest rate is now less than half the 21 percent briefly experienced during the credit crunch of 1981.

LEAD: FOR much of the last decade, commercial space developers in New Jersey have been pushing westward and building mainly to accommodate the growth of New Jersey-based companies and the desire of New York companies for cheaper alternatives to high Manhattan rent.

LEAD: Britain's economy grew at a faster-than-expected 1.3 percent rate in the second quarter from the first quarter, the Government said today. The country's inflation-adjusted gross domestic product, measured by the total output of goods and services, rose 5.1 percent from the second quarter of 1987, the Central Statistics Office said.
LEAD: Fueled by higher food prices caused by the drought, consumer prices edged upward by four-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported today.
LEAD: The Mets, who still deny that they can ''turn it on,'' turned it on again tonight and beat the Los Angeles Dodgers for the second straight game, 5-1.

LEAD: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that Raymond W. Smith, president and chief operating officer, would succeed Thomas E. Bolger as chief executive when he retires on Dec. 31. Mr. Bolger, 61 years old, will remain chairman for a transition period into 1989, Bell Atlantic said.

LEAD: Rick Sutcliffe said yesterday that reports the Chicago Cubs were thinking about trading him were a misunderstanding. ''It was my agent, Barry Axelrod, who had asked the Cubs about the clause in my contract concerning what eight teams I would not play for, and not the Cubs who made the request,'' Sutcliffe said.

LEAD: The trade bill signed yesterday by President Reagan includes everything from accounting changes, symbolic amendments and special favors to broad policy measures that may eventually give the Government a much stronger hand in trade talks.

LEAD: The search for honky-tonk heaven continues in Texas. Since the outlaw country movement of the late 1970's, songwriters in Austin have minutely examined the myth of the honky-tonk, where romance and fistfights and music and drink, exaltation and self-destruction all swirl together. Austin's younger songwriters can't take the myth in full seriousness, but they can't shake it off, either.

LEAD: The Boeing Company said it would announce an aircraft sale today and that the deal would mark a record annual order rate. Boeing declined to elaborate, but a Prudential-Bache analyst, Paul Nisbet, speculated that Delta Air Lines Inc. might have ordered aircraft worth $4 billion to $6 billion. A Delta spokesman said the airline was considering a big purchase but would have no announcement until later in the year.

LEAD: Herbert von Karajan will conduct the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra in three concerts at Carnegie Hall in February, it was announced yesterday. The concerts will mark Mr. Karajan's first appearance in New York since 1982 and his first concerts in Manhattan with the Vienna orchestra.

LEAD: IN 1981, Michael Pangia, a stockbroker, needed a new cornice built for his Brooklyn town house. ''Without a cornice, the building looked empty, like a person without a head,'' he said. A year later, his house had a cornice and at the age of 38, Mr. Pangia had a new job: designer and builder of cornices.

LEAD: A 22-year-old man was shot to death by the police and an officer was wounded yesterday during a gun battle in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

LEAD: John Vanbiesbrouck, the Rangers' goalie who severely cut his left wrist on June 13 when the glass top of a coffee table at his home in Rye, N.Y., broke under his weight, said yesterday he would report to Three Rivers, Quebec, on Sept. 10 when the Rangers begin preseason training. After the 24-year-old goalie underwent five hours of microsurgery to repair three severed tendons and a sliced nerve, the team announced he was not expected back for four to six months.

LEAD: Michael H. Reingold, 52 years old, has been named president of the Boston office of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS, which alone brings in billings of $150 million and has a staff of 200. The overall agency's billings exceed $600 million.

LEAD: Long-term unemployment in Britain has fallen below one million for the first time in more than five years, the Government reported today. LEAD: The nation's trade deficit shrank 14.9 percent in this year's second quarter on a balance-of-payments basis, helped by a record high level of exports and the first quarterly decline in imports in three years.

LEAD: Representatives of two groups with large positions in Texaco Inc. stock met yesterday with James W. Kinnear, Texaco's chief executive, about ways they could have more say on the company's board.
LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis's campaign today accused Vice President Bush of ducking an early debate, with the Democratic nominee vowing to show up anyway.
LEAD: Try to imagine Dan Quayle as President of the United States.

LEAD: National City Bank, a unit of the National City Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 5/8 percent deposit notes due in 1993, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

LEAD: THE California lottery this week offered its second-biggest jackpot: $35 million. Broadcasts and newspapers statewide were filled with reports about it and it seemed as though everyone was asking, ''What would you do with the money if you won the $35 million?'' and at the same time trying to devise a system for picking the six numbers that the state would draw from a hopper.

LEAD: Sixteen-year-old Arantxa Sanchez got a good look at the best in women's tennis today, and it's a good thing she didn't blink. LEAD: The International Monetary Fund approved a $1.4 billion loan to Brazil on Tuesday, to go along with proposed new loans of $5.2 billion from commercial banks, an I.M.F. spokesman said.

LEAD: A police sergeant, testifying at an unusual court hearing, said yesterday that he accidentally fired his service revolver last Tuesday - fatally shooting his partner - after a suspect pushed his gun hand.
LEAD: STEVEN DITCH, who took the heat-resistant epoxy resin material used for laboratory counters and turned it into kitchen counter tops and tables, now has an improved Tuff Top.
LEAD: The latest round of labor unrest in Poland appeared on the wane today, as strikes ended at five coal mines and work resumed at a rail repair yard and large turbine factory.

LEAD: The slogans and speeches in the three Baltic republics Tuesday night must have burned the ears of the more conservative colleagues of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. The speakers, Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians who had received official permission to assemble, called for independence from Moscow, equated Communism with the Nazi swastika and accused the Soviet authorities of falsifying history.

LEAD: The recent development of a test to determine whether people are destined to develop a devastating, inherited neurological disorder known as Huntington's disease is causing considerable anguish among potential beneficiaries. Many, it seems, simply would prefer not to know whether they will develop the incurable disorder, even though the information may help them plan better for their future.

LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle tried tonight to move beyond what he called ''the distractions'' of the controversy over his military record by denouncing Michael S. Dukakis as ''anti-defense.''

LEAD: The State Public Utilities Commission today ordered GTE California to cut its telephone rates by $218 million. LEAD: HORSE RACING Claramount Wins Easily: Claramount splashed to a front-running 20-length victory over Whodam and Cavanagh Special in the $124,600 West Point Handicap for New York-breds yesterday at Saratoga. LEAD: A small earthquake rattled a section of northeastern Salt Lake City, but was not related to a series of tremors that shook central Utah earlier this month, seismologists said. The quake, measuring 2.1 on the Richter scale of ground motion, occurred at 11:13 P.M. M.D.T. on Tuesday.

LEAD: Japan's Prime Minister, Noboru Takeshita, arrived in China today for his first state visit, amid wary hopes in the Japanese business community that an elusive prize - access to China's huge market and cheap labor - may be within its grasp.

LEAD: When two well-known Swiss food companies, Nestle and Jacob Suchard, made hostile bids for Rowntree P.L.C., the British confectioner, last spring, their competing offers sparked a debate that is still raging throughout Europe: Why can Swiss corporations succeed in hostile takeovers in other countries, while it is well-nigh impossible to succeed in a hostile bid against a Swiss company?

LEAD: West Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, led a series of Europe-wide interest rate increases today aimed at stopping the dollar's recent advance.

LEAD: The operators of Grand Central Terminal revealed plans yesterday to improve sanitation around the dowdy old station by expanding a loading dock and garbage-collection site - next to the Grand Hyatt Hotel.

LEAD: Columbia University opens a handsome 417-bed dormitory today that officials say symbolizes the completion of a dream, a national student body. But it also means Columbia's undergraduate college will take in far fewer students from the New York metropolitan region.

LEAD: The British Government, trying to curb inflation, pushed up interest rates today to a two-and-a-half-year high after announcing a record trade deficit for July that was almost double the previous record.

LEAD: Singing for Others' Suppers
LEAD: Diplomats reported progress today in talks to set a timetable for the withdrawal of 47,000 Cuban troops from Angola.
LEAD: A fire destroyed much of Lisbon's historic shopping district, killed one person and injured 43 today before firemen brought it under control.
LEAD: John Elway passed for two touchdowns to Ricky Nattiel before leaving the game with a strained right shoulder, leading the Denver Broncos past the Indianapolis Colts, 21-20, tonight.

LEAD: Construction of a new, 30-story control tower that officials say will greatly enhance air safety and slightly reduce flight delays at Kennedy International Airport was unanimously approved yesterday by the commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

LEAD: Torrential rains battered the northern town of Kousseri on Wednesday, killing one person and leaving more than 1,000 homeless, the Cameroon radio said today. The four-hour downpour destroyed 315 houses of mud and thatch, the radio said.

LEAD: When George Bush selected his running mate last week, his aides said he aimed for an attractive young conservative with no political baggage built up from long exposure to national politics - a sort of Jack Kemp without Jack Kemp.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Alcala **(March 18, 1988), 349 Amsterdam Avenue, at 77th Street (769-9600) - This is a warm and inviting place, with a long marble-topped tapas bar and an elevated brick-walled dining room.

LEAD: ''Coverup: Behind the Iran-Contra Affair'' loses force as the movie makers run out of evidence that a shadowy right-wing group has been conducting American foreign policy and threatening constitutional rights, and settle for surmise, speculation and the tricks of film making to bolster their case.

LEAD: Like Yeats's rough beast in ''The Second Coming,'' apostles of political murder are slouching back into view. The State Department reports that terrorist incidents worldwide climbed to 832 last year, a 7 percent jump. The precision is misleading, since there's no rule for distinguishing one person's ''terrorist'' from another's ''freedom fighter.

LEAD: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's Australian holding company, reported yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter ended June 30 had plunged 67.5 percent even though its revenues had increased 23.3 percent.

LEAD: The rainout here three weeks ago precipitated an entire array of discomforting changes for the Yankees. Schedules were shuffled. Travel arrangements were reworked, and an expected day off evaporated in an instant. It left both plans and people upset.

LEAD: ''So the idea that you have to be long on the tooth to be qualified for the national ticket is one that I reject, speaking as one who is relatively long in the tooth these days.'' - Vice President Bush. [ D17:3. ]

LEAD: The City Council will meet Friday under a Federal judge's order to reconsider its opposition to a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, but Councilmen fighting the order said they saw no hope of change.

LEAD: West German officials today identified a former United States Army sergeant living in West Germany as the key figure in an espionage network that transferred secret NATO military documents to Soviet-bloc agents.

LEAD: For a century or so, the term ''test match'' has referred to cricket contests between different segments of what used to be the British Empire. And the Australians and the New Zealanders borrowed the term for their regular bridge battles. Until a decade ago, Australia was dominant, but the pendulum then swung the other way.

LEAD: Dr. Edgar Jackson, right, trying to enter the Hillcrest Clinic yesterday as demonstrators blocked the entrance. The protesters kept staff members and patients from entering for most of the morning. It was the latest in a series of anti-abortion demonstrations that began last month during the Democratic National Convention.

''Two slices, please,'' he said. ''Sorry,'' the clerk said. ''Only hard currency today.
LEAD: Joseph P. Maggio, who owned a design firm bearing his name in Manhattan, died of a heart attack last Saturday at his home in South Egremont, Mass. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: In the 1940's Robert B. Peltz used to spend Saturdays unloading crates of apples at his father's produce warehouse. He would earn $3 for moving 850 crates. ''I thought I was overpaid,'' Mr. Peltz remembered.

LEAD: Diane Ruth Spiro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Spiro of Kings Point, L.I., was married last evening to Steven Kletz, the son of Blanche Kletz of New York and the late Sidney Kletz. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony at the Spiro home.

LEAD: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man accused of manslaughter in the shooting of a police officer last week told a detective later that he did not push or touch a sergeant who fired the fatal shot, according to court testimony yesterday.

LEAD: The Zapata Corporation has agreed to sell the assets of its Zapata Financial Services unit to Citicorp North America Inc. for $153 million. LEAD: Thanks to an impressive international tour by the Islip garbage barge, followed by a summer of syringes in the sand, Long Island is now in a strong position to declare itself America's most interesting solid waste mess.
LEAD: The only player who played the historic Baltusrol Golf Club at even par for three rounds won the Met Open today.

LEAD: Andrew W. L. Brown, a retired official of the United Automobile Workers, died of heart failure Aug. 16 at St. John Hospital in Detroit. He was 73 years old and lived in Grosse Pointe Park.

LEAD: When a widowed Midwestern farmer named Gary Simmons (Tom Berenger) falls in love with a demure young newcomer named Katie Phillips (Debra Winger), he wants her to know everything about his world. So he takes her camping and hunting, but these prove not to be ordinary recreational outings. The campsite is at a white-supremacist outpost in Montana, where vacationers dress in Ku Klux Klan robes and burn crosses as they gather to sing ''Amazing Grace.

LEAD: A Washington Post/ABC News Poll published today showed Vice President Bush leading Michael S. Dukakis by 48 percent to 46 percent, with Mr. Bush gaining ground especially among political independents and young people.

LEAD: A free performance of music, from inspirational songs to original jazz pieces, is to be given by an a cappella sextet, Take 6, tonight at 8 in the WQXR Auditorium at The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street.
LEAD: The Control Data Corporation, based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that it had sold computers valued at $4.1 million to five industry institutes in China.
LEAD: The dollar fell against all major currencies in busy trading yesterday after the central banks of West Germany and several European nations raised key interest rates.

LEAD: Arnold L. Raphel, the Ambassador to Pakistan, who was killed in a plane crash with President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq last week, was the 152d American diplomat since 1780 to lose his life while performing duties overseas, according to the State Department.

LEAD: A gunman in a car fired about 18 shots at a crowd outside a pool hall Wednesday, wounding eight people in an attack the police said was carried out in revenge for a gang shooting earlier this week. No arrests were made, and none of the witnesses could provide a description of the vehicle, Police Officer Ralph Askew said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: By dialing an 800 number, a person can make a non-deductible contribution by check, charge or money order to the North Defense Trust, a fund established by former United States Naval Academy classmates of Oliver L. North, the star of last summer's Iran-contra hearings.

LEAD: The Dillon Companies, a supermarket chain based in Hutchinson, Kan., said its Kwik Shop Inc. subsidiary had agreed to buy forty-six 7-Eleven convenience stores from the Southland Corporation, based in Dallas. Terms were not disclosed. Dillon, a unit of the Kroger Company, said it would operate the stores as part of its Kwik Shop chain.

LEAD: Harvie Swartz, a bassist, is to lead his group Urban Earth in a free concert tomorrow at 4 P.M. at the Rotunda in Riverside Park, at West 79th Street near the Hudson River Boat Basin. Information: 408-0263.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Children's Museum will be closed from Sept. 6 through Sept. 30 while improvements are made to accommodate more visitors and school tours. A computerized visitor-orientation system and an exhibition area for preschool children is to be completed, and repairs and painting will be done during the closing.

LEAD: The National Association of Black Journalists, meeting here this week, had mixed reviews of gains by minority groups in the profession over the last 20 years: cheers for some progress in hiring and dismay over the lack of promotions to management positions.

LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation has assured a court that it will keep $3 billion in assets, the amount the Indian Government claims as compensation for the 1984 gas disaster that killed more than 2,800 people.

LEAD: Mike Schmidt, the Philadelphia Phillies' third baseman, has a tear in the rotator cuff of his right shoulder and will undergo tests next week to determine the extent of the injury, the club said today. If the tear is partial, said Dr. Phillip Marone, the team physician, it could heal with rest. A full tear might require surgery.

LEAD: Soviet soldiers sat shirtless in the morning sun at the airport here today, watching Hind helicopters loaded with rockets lift in a swirl of dust toward the ridges of the Hindu Kush, the broad mountain range to the northeast. A soldier carrying a guitar walked past a Russian man in his 20's, wearing wraparound sunglasses, jeans and running shoes, gripping a submachine gun.
LEAD: Two formerly all-male enclaves - the Friars Club and the Union League Club -have settled sex discrimination complaints with New York City, officials said yesterday.
LEAD: One or more of the Wickes Companies' operating units would be sold if a management-led investor group succeeded in buying the company, the group disclosed yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The jet carrying Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, and his entourage was grounded for repairs today after a passenger door was forced closed in an incorrect position.

LEAD: Transportation specialists grappling with rural America's problems of growing isolation in an increasingly urban nation have found some innovative solutions scattered from upstate New York to northwest Nebraska and central Virginia to the Ohio shores of Lake Erie.
LEAD: Suspicious cuts in some O ring seals that were intended for use on space shuttle booster rockets have led to a Federal investigation, officials said today.
LEAD: Vice President Salvador H. Laurel and opposition leaders today announced the formation of a new coalition to challenge President Corazon C. Aquino.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has expanded the powers of its Interior Ministry troops, granting them broader authority to bear arms, suppress public demonstrations and enter private homes in pursuit of criminals.
